text:
FANTASTIC! I made this recipe 3 times before I really feel like I got it just right! Here are my discoveries: 1. I added just a dash of nutmeg and ground cloves. 2. I halved the recipe and made two 7 1/2" x 9" loaves, but the first time I used the temperature and time given in the recipe, resulting in two doughy (but delicious) uncooked loaves. If making two loaves, do 325 degrees for 1 hr 10 mins, they bake perfectly! 3. I can't really make the butter and sugar in the beginning "cream" together, there's just too much sugar, (but don't change the sugar amount!) So don't worry if it doesn't look creamy. 4. I used an electric mixer to mix the wet ingredients together, but I hand-mixed the flour into the mixture. Try #2 I used the electric mixer to incorporate the flour, the loaves turned out to be a bit too light and airy for me, like cake. Hand-mixing in the flour created a denser, more bread-like consistency. 5. Making a crumbly topping is a MUST. I took a topping recipe from Zucchini Bread IV from this site, but I modified it just a little bit for two loaves: ~ 1/2 cup packed brown sugar ~ 1/2 cup all-purpose flour ~ 2 or 3 tablespoons butter or margarine ~ 1 teaspoon cinnamon ~ 1/3 cup chopped walnuts or pecans. I microwaved the butter for just a while to make it nice and soft, mixed it  together with a fork until it was cumbly, and spooned it over the loaves before putting it in the oven. This bread is SO good and easy, even for a novice baker like myself!

text:
The very best even with my lower fat changes! My changes not only cut the fat in half, but also cut the calories in each serving by 100. 
NOTE: I halved the recipe. My changes for half the recipe: 2 TBS butter & 1/4 cup of applesauce instead of all butter. In the batter I used 1 c Splenda and 1/2 c sugar. I used 1 c whole wheat flour and 1 1/4 c all purpose flour.  I used 2 eggs and light sour cream. My 2 loaves baked in an hour. No one would guess they are lower fat and calorie. They were perfect in taste and texture. Next time I'm going to try all Splenda and applesauce and will give an update on the results.

Just wanted to add this:  if you make this bread with FAT-FREE sour cream instead of the regular kind, it won't turn out the same! It is dry and crumbly... not as good as the first batch... I won't make this mistake again. (It tastes ok, but not as rich - so not too good.)

text:
Yummy!  This is one of the absolutely best banana bread recipes I have ever tried!!!  I had some bananas that were overripe so I decided to make this for my family one morning for breakfast.  I made half of the recipe with 2 eggs and 4 extrmely overripe bananas.  The cinnamon sugar coating was a great touch and I also sprinkled it on top of the bread before baking.  While the bread was cooling, I went to take a shower.  When I got out, everyone was standing around the cooling rack waiting for me to say that it was okay to cut the loaf.:-)  Needless to say, it was well worth the wait.  One thing I did notice was that the loaves did not rise very much.  I know that my baking soda was fresh, so I'm not sure why the bread didn't rise.  I don't know if anyone else experienced this.  ***** just made this again this weekend.  Made half the recipe, and used a long and deep loaf pan (from which you can get slices the size of Starbucks breads). I used 4.5 ripe bananas, 1 cup of sugar, 2 tsp. of vanilla, didn't have sour cream, so I used about 6 ounces of nonfat yogurt, and lots of cinnamon and sugar on the bottom and top of the pan.  I also laid out a row of walnuts down the middle of the loaf pan before baking, and the presentation was very pretty.  I also had to bake it for about 15 minutes more than the time called for in the recipe.  The bread turned out yummy and not too sweet...perfect!!

text:
I modified a little:  Strudel on top and white/wheat flour split.  I'll make them completely whole wheat from now on, since I'm finding that whole wheat flour is virtually indistinguishable from regular white in this recipe.

I add a basic strudel on top:
1/2 cup all-purpose flour
1/2 cup packed brown sugar
1/3 cup pecans
2 teaspoons ground cinnamon
2-3 tbls butter

I have tried these as large loaves, mini loaves, mini muffins (325 degrees for about 25-30 minutes) and extra-large muffins (325 degrees for about 45 minutes) and have had no problems.  Use the time as a guide, but it's not the time, it's the dough - you know it's done when you have can pull a clean toothpick/knife/fork... 

The most fantastic thing about banana bread is the ability to freeze bananas when they go past ripe and be able to actually USE them in something yummy.  I take bananas that are past the "my kids will eat them" stage and let them sit on the countertop until they go pretty close to black - you can let them get pretty heady.  Then I stick them in a ziplock and pop in the freezer.  When I have enough (6-7) then I pull them all out, let them defrost a little on the counter and then peel them while they are still fairly frozen (makes it MUCH easier to peel them when they are slightly frozen).

text:
I've made this banana bread more times than I can count and it is excellent.  I freeze any over ripe bananas we have whole in their peel in a freezer bag until there's enough for this recipe.  (These are those leftover, spotty bananas that no one is going to eat, but you hate to throw away.)  If you try this expect the banana peel to turn black in the freezer, and be forewarned that the bananas are going to be mooshy from being frozen and may have some liquid inside from freezing and thawing.  Take the bananas out to thaw a bit before you're ready to bake.  When they're partially thawed just take the peel off and plop the banana and any liquid in a bowl and mash.  For those having trouble with the bake time, note that the recipe calls for 7x3 pans, which are smaller than standard size loaf pans.  If you are using larger, standard size loaf pans you will get 3 loaves from this recipe.  Bake at 300, but it will take more than an hour because the loaves are larger.  My large loaves usually take about 75 minutes.

text:
This was delicious! Instead of making the mini-loaves, I was able to half the batter and make two 9 1/2 x 5 in. loaves. Don't worry, you might think that you are filling the pans up too high, but it works. Due to this change, I needed to increase the temp. to 325 and bake for about 10 minutes longer. I also highly suggest that you make the topping that is on the "Banana Crumb Muffins" recipe on this site (there are 2 recipes on this site, use the top-rated one with the picture). This made it 10 times better! The only other thing I did differently was using maple syrup in place of the vanilla. I realized I was out of vanilla extract as I was mixing the dough and researched substitutions online. This actually worked, though I'm not sure how it would work in other recipes such as cookies, etc.

text:
Simply Wonderful!  A very tender crumb ... moist ... sweet ... delicious!
Since I had only 4 average size bananas, which made about 2 cups mashed, I added 1/2 cup softened butter, 2 eggs, 1/2 cup sour cream, 1 tsp vanilla, 1 tsp cinnamon. I used 2 and 1/2 cups flour, 1 tsp baking soda and 1/4 cup chopped walnuts.  I left out the salt to reduce the sodium, as I always do when baking anything but yeast bread.  I did add a dash of nutmeg, as my family likes this spice.  I also sprinked the top with the cinnamon sugar mixture.  I made one large 9x5 loaf and six muffins.  I baked the muffins for 18 minutes at 400 degrees.  When I took them out, I then reduced the oven to 325 degrees put in the loaf right away and baked the loaf for 1 hour and 15 minutes.  I enjoyed a muffin with a cup of tea while the bread was baking and filling the house with it's wonderful aroma. Thank you for the recipe.

text:
Yummy nana-bread (as my little one would say)!

I read everyone's comments and did my own modification. I used 2 cups of white sugar and a 1/2 cup of brown, instead of the 3 cups white sugar called for. I also sprinkled some of the cinnamon and sugar mixture on top. My mini loaf pans were a bit smaller. They are about 6"x3" and I was able to fill 7 of them (I filled them 2/3 of the way). I set the oven to 300 and the loaves were ready in exactly 50 minutes -- I poked one with a knife and it came out clean. The bread was very moist with just the right amount of sweetness. Great recipe. I'll be making more for christmas gifts :)

I tried this recipe simply because I had bananas that were getting over ripe, and although I only used only four large ones, it had plenty of banana flavor. Overall the recipe was good, with rich flavor, and a very light hint of tang. But, I definately felt it was too sweet, and if I decide to make it again, I will reduce the sugar considerably, its just too much to dust the pans with sugar, and then add the large amount of sugar the recipe calls for. The slightly crunchy crust was wonderful and I wouldn't change that part of it. I Will consider making again, and reducing sugar.

text:
This is the best banana bread recipe I've tried, ever! I did make some changes -- I substituted applesauce for 1/2 of the butter, used lowfat sour cream, and cut the sugar to ~1.5 cups (the applesauce & bananas sweeten this bread plenty). It turned out great -- like I just got it from Starbucks!

Also, this freezes really well, just wrap in Saran wrap & foil, and put in a ziploc bag. Perfect! **BY THE WAY: Until recently, I thought my oven and I were a disaster with quickbreads (pumpkin, banana, etc) -- then found that buying brand new baking soda and powder makes ALL THE DIFFERENCE (thanks, Mom). You should replace it every year at least (look at the expiration date) -- now you know, too!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/541309.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was most certainly an excellent and versatile banana bread recipe. I was rather skeptical about the sour cream at the beginning, but it made for a great balancer with the sweetness of the bread.

Personally, I did not need that many loaves of the bread (although the one I baked disappeared in about 10 minutes), so I decided to take the recipe and scale it to "8" (which would give me the batter for 1 loaf of bread versus 4). 

*PLEASE NOTE: the scaler of the recipe does not accommodate for the sour cream, so for my recipe making 1 loaf of bread, I only had to use 4 oz of sour cream, rather than the full 16 oz (one container). I also used light sour cream to scale back some calories from the servings. 

In addition, I added a little crust to the surface of the bread to make it slightly crunchy. Just sprinkle it on top of the batter once it is in the loaf pan. I based it off of the crust from the "Zucchini Bread IV" recipe, but modified for my portion size. 
For the one loaf, it goes as follows:
- 1/8 cup brown sugar
- 1/8 cup all-purpose flour
- 1/4 tablespoon butter
- 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
After about an hour, I'd also suggest melting a pat of butter and drizzling it on the top of the bread, just so the crust can glaze over just a bit.

Since I only had a 8.5" x 4.5" loaf pan available, I adjusted the cooking time to roughly 1 hour and 15 minutes (still at 300 degrees) and let the bread sit for 10 minutes before taking it out of the loaf pan.

text:
This is a very good banana bread.  And is extremely EASY to make.  When you first pull it out of the oven it doesnt have all the flavor and moistness until it sits for a few hours.  Let it cool a little, and wrap them in aluminum foil and the next day they will have all the flavor and be so moist they melt in your mouth!  UPDATE:  4/9/12  I make this bread all the time!  It is absolutely hands down my favorite banana bread.  I love it fresh out of the oven  smeared with a little butter and days after it is baked it gets even better! I do heavily dust my pans with cinnamon/sugar and also after putting the batter in, dust the tops of the batter as well, so that all sides have a nice sugar crust.  This is great with or without the nuts.  There really isn't anything that I would change in the recipe because it is excellent as written!  I am blown away by all the excellent and thousands of reviews this has now!  When I first made this several years ago it was in the 200-300 review range.  I am so glad to see so many are enjoying like I have!  Thanks for this winning recipe!

I also had trouble with this recipe.  I halved it and followed the measurements exactly.  It took 1 hr 20 minutes at 300 before I felt it was safe to remove from the oven and eat.  Although the toothpick came out clean, both loaves looked "gooey" on top and the texture was very spongy and as if they were not completely baked, even though I do believe they were cooked all the way through. I was going to give one of the loaves to friends as a thank you for babysitting our daughter, but there is no way I could offer the bread to anyone. Sorry to write a negative review, but with so many banana bread recipes and having followed the directions as is, I do not want anyone else to spend time on this "5 star" recipe.

text:
This bread ROCKS!  Now, can I share with you my first attempt at this recipe?  Before making a new recipe, I try to make sure I have all ingredients.  (I don't like to stray the first time.)  I didn't check here because I was SURE we had everything.  But as soon as I started, I realized we didn't have enough butter.  I substituted a container of apple sauce we normally throw in my kids' lunch (abt 1/4 c.) for most of the butter.  When opened the sour cream container in the fridge, I saw that my wife had used most of it in some guacamole she made a couple nights ago.  What was left had goops of avacado in it because she stirred the guac and then double-dipped with the same spoon to get more sour cream.  I substituted vanilla flavored yogurt.  That also meant I didn't have to add vanilla, but probably O.D.'d the sugar content.  Moreover, I halved the recipe.  I forgot that fact when I added cinnamon, baking soda and salt -- another O.D.  Finally, when I went to add nuts, I couldn't find walnuts.  They were apparently eaten without being added to the last grocery list for replacement.  I added pecans instead.  It still turned out great.  None of these hassles were big problem, but I spent probably an extra half-hour in preparation time looking for the ingredients in the fridge/pantry.

text:
Two words: Amazing. Recipe.
I have a couple fun things to do with it though.
1. Instead of using loaf pans, use muffin pans. It takes a couple batches for a twelve-muffin pan, around three or four. But trust me, IT IS AMAZING.
2. Instead of greasing the pan then sprinkling on the cinnamon-sugar mix, mix the butter with the sugar then add cinnamon. Grease the pans with this and create a lovely caramelized bottom and sides to the muffin.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/219965.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a tasty, moist recipe. A tip for Bansreeparikh (and anyone else who found the loaves did not rise): the acidity of sour cream mixes with the baking soda, resulting in a reaction which releases gas. If you mix the baking soda into the batter very thoroughly before filling the loaf pans, this process will be done and the gaseous bubbles may be beaten out of the batter. If this happens, the eggs are the only remaining source of leavening for the bread, so it won't rise as much. Instead, I recommend adding the baking soda last and mixing it just enough to incorporate it. Don't beat the batter too much. Then when you fill the loaf pans, the chemical reaction will continue, causing bubbles which act as leavening. My loaves raised nicely using this method.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-07-24T09:17:57.647
helpfulCount:
9

Yummmmmmmmmy!!  Used all the recommended ingredients but added more cinnamon sugar dusting to the top also before baking.  The cook temp is off.  300 degrees just didn't sound right so I upped the oven to 325 and it was done perfectly in an hour.  I only made two loaves so I halved the ingredients. text:
It was just too tempting to try a recipe with almost unanimous 5-star ratings.  My husband and I both agree that this is the best banana bread we've ever had.  I reduced the recipe to 12 servings, used a 9x5 pan, substituted fat free yogurt for the sour cream, and applesauce for the butter.  I used three bananas for the one pan, and offset the low-fat effect by adding 2/3 c chocolate chips and 1/3 c walnuts.  Wonderful!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you like your banana bread to taste like a very sweet spice cake, you will like this recipe. This loaf tastes good, for a spice cake, which is what I would think I was eating if I did not know it was supposed to be a quickbread. My three criticisms are (1) that the banana flavor is obscured by the excessive amount of ground cinnamon, (2) that the texture is too soft and cake-like for a quickbread, and (3) that the large amount of sugar makes it overly sweet and, again, too cake-like. My family and I agreed that we prefer banana bread that is more banana-flavored, more toothsome, and slightly less sweet. I give it three stars because even though it is neither banana nor bread, it tastes good as a spice cake.

text:
I have made this recipe several times so I wanted to pass on my mistakes.  

First, if you are like me and only have 9x5 bread pans this will make three loaves. 

Next, if you like the denser bread don't use a mixer, smash the bananas and hand mix.  If you like a fluffier bread mix everything.

Finally, one day I ran out of sour cream after 2 cups and used plain Greek yogurt for the other 2 cups and this still turned out awesome!

Hope this helps!!

text:
The reason that some cooks are having trouble with the bake time and/or this bread coming out is that they are using pans that are too large. The recipe specifies 7 X 3 loaf pans--less than half the volume of a regular loaf pan. Try it again, this bread. is worth it.

text:
Very moist and tasty bread - loved it.  I made the exact recipe (which should be a prerequisite for a review -- you shouldn't review a recipe unless you actually made the recipe!).  It occurred to me that the people that had trouble with the bread not being done may have used larger bananas, therefore more wet ingredients.  I found that 6 medium bananas made exactly three cups mashed, which I think is the right proportion for this recipe.  My only complaint is that the recipe is way more than four 3x7 pans' worth!  I increased to six 3x7 pans and still had a god-awful mess in my oven.  I'll use 7 or 8 small pans next time, or use larger loaf pans.  I'll also try substituting some whole wheat flour to be more healthy.  Thanks for sharing this delish recipe!

text:
After seeing how highly rated this recipe is, I really wanted to make it.  However, I also wanted to cut the fat as some of the previous reviewers did.  I cut the recipe in half, and I followed the advice of one reviewer and substituted 2 tablespoons butter and 1/4 cup applesauce for the butter.  I was nervous to replace the sour cream with fat-free because I didn't want a dry and crumbly bread.  So, I used non-fat Greek yogurt because I thought the thickness of it would mimick sour cream.  I have to say that this bread came out very moist and delicious.  It received rave reviews from everyone who ate it.  Thank you to all the reviewers before me who gave such good advice.

text:
Concerned about the baking instructions, I baked the loaves at 325 degrees for 1 hour and ten minutes and they were perfectly done.   I made a topping of ½ cup brown sugar, ½ cup flour, 1 Tablespoon Vietnamese cinnamon, and 3 Tablespoons cold butter cut into the other ingredients with a pastry blender.  The topping was an absolute necessity in my opinion.   My regular banana bread recipe calls for the addition of strongly brewed black coffee and I don’t think I realized how much that ingredient adds a wonderful complexity to the banana flavor until tasting this recipe.

This is a great recipe. I had to modify it a little because my fiance is diabetic, and it was the best batch of banana bread i have ever made. I used apple sauce instead of all the butter. Used whole wheat flour instead of all white flour. Used artificial sweetener for half the sugar. And i did add some chocolate chips along with the walnuts. I had to bake my two loafs for quite a while longer than the 1 hr. The  cinnamon and sugar mixture on the bottom was genius. It added a sweet crispy texture in contrast to the nice moist banana bread and was quite good. Overall, the best banana bread i have made.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a half batch and used two 9x5 in loaf pans.  300 degrees seemed a little low to me, so I upped the temperature to 350 for 60 minutes and they came out perfectly done.  I used 2 eggs, about 1/8 cup additional flour and half white sugar, half brown sugar.  Overall, I thought it was alright, but my husband (the big banana bread enthusiast of the family) didn't care for it much.  He prefers the Extreme Banana Nut Bread recipe also from allrecipes so I'll be going back to it next time.  There's really nothing wrong with this recipe and I would make it again if the rest of the family liked it better, but I think I'll have to find a different way to use up leftover sour cream.

It is an excellent tasting bread, there is no doubt,  BUT...  1 hour at 300 doesn't bake the bread to an appropriate "doneness".  I have baked this several times now, and have to increase the temp in the oven to 330 degrees and bake for 1 hour and 15 minutes for them to be done.  Other than the change in baking time and temp, a wonderful tasting bread.

This recipe was excellent!! Although the 4 loaves that the recipe was supposed to make made a whole bunch more!!  This recipe will make 12 5 11/16" X 3 1/4" X 2" loaves. There were no instructions on that, and being aperson who has never baked bread before I filled it to the top, only to find an ennormous mess in my oven.  Besides that pain, this was east to make and my husband loved it.  I took a few to work and gave a few to my friends, they want more!!  Also- I doubled up on the walnuts!!

text:
There's a reason why almost 75,700 people saved this recipe, it's fantastic!  Thank you Esther for an incredibly moist and delicious banana bread recipe.  I followed a combination of Esther's recipe and some of the reviewers' suggestions.  Here are the only two changes that I made:  1.  Baked at 350 degrees for 55 minutes (that's when my toothpicks came out clean).  2.  Used 1 1/2 c of white sugar and 1/2 c of brown sugar.  Between the very ripe bananas and the 2 c of sugars this banana bread had the perfect amount of sweetness.  Thank you again Esther.  Another great banana bread to try is the Banana Banana Bread.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made is last night but into Muffins! Came out wonderful. I used nonfat sour cream, for the butter I used half butter and half applesauce. Then I coated all the muffin pans with the sugar/cinnamon mix and I made the crumble topping.  1/2 cup packed brown sugar ~ 1/2 cup all-purpose flour ~ 2 or 3 tablespoons butter or margarine ~ 1 teaspoon cinnamon ~ 1/3 cup chopped walnuts or pecans. I microwaved the butter for just a while to make it nice and soft, mixed it together with a fork until it was cumbly, and spooned 1 heaping teaspoon over each muffins before putting it in the oven. I made about 24 muffins.

text:
My friends loved this banana bread! I halfed the recipe and baked it in a 9x5" loaf pan for about 1 hour and 25 minutes.  I used the topping from Banana Crumb Muffins - 1/3 cup packed brown sugar, 2 tbsp flour, 1/8 teaspoon ground cinnamon, 1 tbsp butter, cut together until it resembles coarse cornmeal.  The combination of this topping with the cinnamon sugar coating was delicious!

Excellent!  I used applesauce instead of butter, light sour cream and sprayed my pan with non-stick spray.  I was a little concerned that the bread would stick in the pan with the cinnamon-sugar coating but they didn't.  They came out beautiful and delicious!

text:
Many banana breads are too dry, but this one was almost too moist!  Still, it is one of the best recipes I've tried (and I've tried MANY).  The sour cream gives the cake a luscious texture that really makes this bread stand out from the rest.
The only problem I had was converting the recipe to make fewer loaves.  The recipe does not convert easily, so I had to guess at the appropriate exchanges.  Thankfully, this is a forgiving recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had previously thought the "banana banana bread" was the best banana bread recipe on allrecipes. WRONG! This one is even more moist and more banana-y tasting. It's a *very* wet batter. I made it as written except I put it in 3 loaf pans rather than 4. Because of that I had a little extra cinnamon sugar mixture so I sprinkled that on all 3 loaves prior to baking. It took a full 2 hours to bake, but it came out delicious. It doesn't rise as much as other banana breads I've made, but I attribute that to the moist and dense texture. I kept one loaf out to eat and froze 2 loaves and when I defrosted them they were fantastic, too. This recipe is a keeper!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/655178.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy, moist banana bread.  I reduced sugar to 1 1/2 cups (plenty sweet), used 4 overly ripe bananas + 2 ready to eat bananas.  I sprayed loaf pans with cooking spray then sprinkled cinnamon/sugar from a shaker I already had with mixture.  I used 2 - 8 X 5 inch loaf pans and 2 - 5 3/4 x 3 inch mini loaf pans each filled about 3/4 full. I got nice, full sized loaves as does not raise too much.  I did bake at the 300* but did have to bake longer than recipe states.  The mini pans I removed at 1 hour 10 minutes and the full size pans at 1 hour 20 minutes.  Cooking time will vary on individual ovens so just keep an eye on it and use the toothpick in the middle should come out clean method to check for doneness.  Oh yes, I did add some walnuts. Again, very yummy.  Do try this recipe.

I made this once as it is written and it was fabulous - I just made it again today and had a few changes - I used 9 bananas that I needed to use up and I did not have any vanilla so I used almond extract.  This time it is exploding with banana flavor and the almond extract adds a nice change.  As another reviewer added I mixed the wet ingredients with a mixer and added dry by hand - I made two loaves and 12 reg muffins and 36 mini muffins and they are all wonderful and dense...and I baked at 350 and just watched carefully...the best banana bread recipe you will ever make!!!!

3.5 stars.  I rounded it up to 4 stars b/c I made some adjustments, and some other reviewer noted that it changed the texture of her bread.  Maybe it is the reason for mine's texture.  I just thought the flavor was so so.  I've been looking for the perfect banana bread recipe for some time, and this just isn't it.  I followed the directions except for the fact that I used fat free sour cream and made the recipe into muffins.  Though the result was by no means dry, it was not as moist as I'd like (could this be for the longer cooking time b/c of the lower temperature?)  The flavor was not all there either.  But my bananas were frozen...so I did not want to deduct points off for that.  I tried a crumb topping to add more flavor, but it only marginally helped.  I'm sure the ppl at my husbands work will eat these anyways.

text:
My entire family loves this recipe.  I often use whole wheat flour to make it healthier and I substitute about 1/2 apple sauce or apple butter and 1/2 butter or margarine instead of all butter.  I usually cut the recipe in third and make 1 loaf.  My kids like it with chocolate chips so I add those too.  I also like to do a little topping on it of brown sugar, white sugar, flour, cinnamon and butter.  If I don't have enough sour cream I sub all or 1/2 for vanilla fat free yogurt.  Sometimes I toss in a little bit of cloves or nutmeg for fun. Yummy and so moist.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe 4 times and I love it.  I followed some hints from others to really perfect it.  300 is to low in my opinion I baked at 325 for 1 hour and 15 minutes for the small loafs and about an hour and 30 minutes for the large size otherwise they turn out to doughy.  I also added a dash of nutmeg and liked how that turned out.  I also hand mixed the flour in to make the loaf a little denser.  Also adding a topping is awesome on this bread.  I tried it both ways and everytone liked the one with the topping more. For four loaves 1 cup of brown sugar, 1 cup flour, 6 tablespoons of butter(softened),2 teaspoons of cinnamon, 2/3 cup of chopped walnuts.  MIx together until crumbly and spoon over mixture before cooking. Awesome!

text:
I am not a banana bread person at all. But since I had some bananas in the fridge I went ahead and tried this recipe. I cut the recipe in half and modified the amount of ingredients called for: used 3/4 c of white sugar and 3/4 brown; added a dash of nutmeg and all spice; and no nuts used (personal preference). I had some leftover streusel mix (1/2 c flour, 4Tbs butter, 1 1/2 tsp cinnamon) so I used and drizzzled it on top.  Came out good and the bread alone is super moist. If I make banana bread again, I will only use this recipe.

seriously awesome!!! i had doubts of trying yet another banana bread but this is my keeper!! i halved the recipe and still got 2 decent sized loaves out of it. i did increase the eggs to 2 (instead of 1 1/2) and used 4 bananas. the taste is superb! all the sour cream i had on hand was smart balance and it turned out fine. i dusted my pans with flour and put a topping of brown sugar and cinnamon on top of loaves. i also had my oven at 325 and my small loaf was done after 55min and my larger loaf more like 65-70. and here it is 6hrs after making and one whole loaf has already been eaten!! choose this recipe it is awesome!!

region:

country:
None
text:
I recently made the Creamy Banana Bread on this site which uses cream cheese and really liked it, but I think I liked this recipe even better. I halved the recipe, using 2 eggs and 4 ripe (though not overly ripe) bananas. I only had lite sour cream, so I used half the sour cream and half full-fat plain yogurt. Because I'm lazy, I didn't sprinkle cinnamon and sugar in the pan, just on top of the loaves before baking. I baked the two loaves at 325 for 42 minutes, and the bread was super creamy, light, and just sweet enough, delicious! My husband loved it as well. I think this is my go-to banana bread recipe from now on.

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this bread! Very moist, and awesome warm with a little butter. I agree with some of the other reviewers, I cooked mine at 325 for an hour and 15 minutes, and put foil on for the last 15 to keep the top from burning. I also mixed some brown sugar and butter and spread that over the top during the last 15, so when I pulled it out it was all melted and gooey...YUM!

text:
This is my favorite banana bread recipe thus far. Probably because this came out a lot like cake for me. I halved the recipe and baked it in a Bundt pan @325 for 1 hour and it was perfectly done. I did add a little canola oil (probably 2TB) to the batter before pouring it into my Bundt pan because it was too thick to pour at that point, and I wanted it looser without being wetter (otherwise I'd have added milk). I did not glaze it, but I think that would be appropriate, though not necessary to make it taste good (but necessary to make it taste WOW!). Thank you for the recipe!

userID:
2258032
Display Name:
Sarah
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good starter recipe, but it needs some more flavor!!  I halved this recipe since I only have 2 mini loaf pans.  After tasting the batter as written, I thought it was bland so I made some changes. 1) Melted the butter, then cooled it 2) Reduced sugar to 1 cup and substituded brown sugar for white sugar. 3)Added 1/2 cup cinnamon applesauce 4)Used 4 ripe bananas 5)Used 1 Tablespoon cinnamon and 1 Tablespoon pumpkin pie spice 6)Added 1 zuchinni, grated 7)Used walnuts 8)Mashed two of the bananas with a fork and set aside.  The other two bananas were whipped with the butter for a few minutes. (You want a light and fluffy banana cream)  Then I added the butter, eggs, vanilla, and applesauce.  In a seperate small bowl I combined all the dry ingredients and whisked them before I added them to the batter.  When you incorporate the dry mix, DO NOT OVER MIX!!!  Next, FOLD in the sour cream, the 2 mashed bananas, and nuts with a spatula.  Pour into well greased loaf pans. 9) Sprinkle top with a strussel topping consiting of 1/2 c. brown sugar, 3 TBS chilled butter, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 TBS flour. 10) Bake in a 320 degree oven for 63 minutes on the middle rack.  Cover with foil for the last 15 minutes of baking  There you go... it tastes a lot better with these changes!!!

text:
All I can say is WOW!  I am NOT a Banana bread fan, but this is not your typical banana bread!   I did make changes as follows:  I halved the recipe as I had only 2 ripe bananas, so 1/4 cup butter, just under a full cup of sugar, and two eggs.  8 oz of 5% MF Sour cream.  As a treat, I added about 1/3 cup of Hershey's Special dark chocolate chips.  I did the crumble top that was mentioned in another review (butter, brown sugar, cinnamon and walnuts).  This made exactly two 4 x 7 loaves.  I baked at 325, and they were done in an hour.   They are PERFECT!  Not dense; not cakey, just right!   Try it; you'll really love it!

text:
I followed some of the tips offered by other users and came out with the best banana nut bread I have EVER had. First of all, I only had 4 mushy bananas so I halved the recipe but used 2 eggs.  I also added a dash of nutmeg and ground cloves.  Another tip I am so grateful for is the stand alone mixer vs. hand mixing.  I agree it is way too difficult to cream the sugar and butter so I did all of that bit in the stand alone mixer and then mixed in the flour by hand.  The texture was perfect.  Also for 2 loaves, 325 for 1 hour 10 mins was dead on the perfect time.  Thanks so much for the BEST banana bread you will ever sink your teeth into!!!

text:
1/2d the recipe and had GREAT results. super moist yet light & delicious banana bread! here's what i did.

1. reduced sugar to 1 C white sugar and 1/4 C. brown sugar (for a HALVED recipe)

2. used two eggs.

3. hand mix dry and wet ingredients together until BARELY wet.

4. used 1/2 cup of walnuts, pecans would have worked great aswell.

5. would suggest using a crumb topping (regretting that i didn't right now)
6. in the oven at 325 degrees for about 65 minutes!

this was PERFECT for ONE 5x9 loaf. i was worried that it was going to overflow but it was just right! (and rised perfectly)

text:
Awesome recipe - perfect texture and flavor. The sour cream makes the difference. Impressed my mother-in-law and grandmother-in-law (who is an AMAZING cook). I halved the recipe and only used 3/4 cup of sugar (will probably try Splenda next time). I used a 1/2 cup of chopped pecans and added cloves just because I love them. I used brown sugar in the cinnamon dusting mixture, reserving about 1/3 of it. To that, I added about a T. of softened butter to make a crumble topping; sprinkled it on top and baked it in a large loaf pan (took about 80 min. to cook). The topping was nice and crunchy. Will definitely make this again!

text:
I've made multiple banana bread recipes from here and this one is my favorite- by far! I halved the recipe and got one loaf and five muffins. I baked them at 325, baked them for 45 minutes, took the muffins out, covered the bread with tinfoil, and baked the bread an additional 15 minutes and everything is *perfect*. I didn't measure my spices; I'm sure I added more cinnamon than called for and I added nutmeg. I'll be sticking with this recipe from now on- I'm so happy to have found a recipe that I love!

text:
I have used the EBNB (extreme banana nut bread) recipe from this site for years but I tried something different this Mother's day and all I can say is "Wow!"  This is a far superior recipe for a much more moist bread.  Dusting the pans with cinnamon sugar made a delicious difference.  The only thing I did differently was that I used 2 cups brown sugar and 1 cup white as we prefer the taste of brown sugar in a banana bread.  Simply amazing!! I made 2 larger loaves (9×4?) and had to bake them at 325 for nearly an hour and a half but they could not have turned out better!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best banana bread I've ever tried. However, there's no way  that amount of batter is going to fit into four 7x3 pans. I mixed it in a Kitchen-Aid mixer with a very large, very deep bowl, and the batter was over the top of the beater! I filled 6 7x3 pans and got lots of spillage (I anticipated this and put the small pans on a cookie sheet), probably could have filled at least 8.  Also, no way does this bake completely in one hour at 300 degs. After the first hour, I turned it up to 325 degs and gave it another 20 to 30 minutes. Eventually, I ended up with some salvageable loaves, and we even ate the free-form baked batter that went onto the cookie sheet. It was totally delicious, and worth trying again to find the right baking pans and temperature combination.

country:
None
text:
Very rich and moist. I halved the recipe and followed the recipe exactly except few minor changes: 1. Sprinkled white sugar only after greasing the pan (next time I will do cinnamon). 2. Cut down sugar to half (I just prefer not too sweet). 4. Used half vegetable oil and half applesauce (no butter). 3. 10 minutes before taking out of the oven I sprinkled brown sugar, cinnamon, and cocoa on top (all of them in generous amount!). Oh and using half the recipe, I used 2 eggs instead of 1.5 (too lazy to get 2TBSP out of 1 egg).
Now this one is quite important, I baked almost 1 hr and 15 minutes. (And I only used HALF of the recipe in ONE loaf pan, so timing may vary depending on the pan you use too.) Thank you for uploading this recipe. My family absolutely loved it! I will definitely make it again (as long as there are left over bananas around this house lol)

text:
I don't usually review recipes but I just have to comment on this one. Don't listen to any of the 'top reviews'; you don't need to change any of the directions or ingredient amounts for this bread! It's amazing as it is written! And it definitely DOESN'T NEED A TOPPING! Are you kidding me?!

I make this for a cafeteria (because everyone begs me to) and the recipe is very forgiving. I frequently quadruple the amounts (or more) and everything still comes out great. I don't even measure everything exactly, and it always works out fine. You can throw in a couple extra bananas, less flour, more baking soda, whatever, and it still turns out great. 

This banana bread is famous at the place I work and people get really excited when they see I have made it.

text:
Ok this bread is to die for! It almost got several less stars when I checked it at an hour it was completely RAW and cold. I saw another reviewer said the same thing....I refused to give up on it and turned the temp to 325 and cooked an extra 18 minutes. PERFECT! I used SaraLady19's advice and added the crumb topping (1/2 cup brown sugar 1/2 cup flour and 2 tbl butter) over the top before baking and it kept it from getting too dark. Instead of walnuts I added 1 cup of chocolate chips...SOO moist sooo delicious!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would have given 5 stars had this been called Banana Sour Cream Cake. It is far too rich (not to mention calories) to be called a bread. As promised it is indeed moist, maybe too much so as it tended to stick to my pans (all 4 of them). Then again, maybe that's because the recipe called for the pan to be buttered and my pans are Teflon coated. In any case, I think the combination of buttering the pan with the sugar/cinnamon layer created the sticking problem.

Also, because this called for 4 pans and I noted only 1 cup of walnuts, I opted to split the batter in half. To the first half I added the full 1 cup of walnuts and to the 2nd half, I added a cup of semi-sweet chocolate chips. (One of my guests is allergic to nuts).

The flavor was quite good, particularly the one with the chocolate.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I discovered halfway through making this that my sour cream was 4 months out of date, so I improvised with whole milk and vinegar instead, using 11 oz total, instead of the 16 oz of sour cream. Turned out fine!

Some people like their banana bread firm throughout, and with a softer crust, but others like it like this recipe, more of a coffee cake texture. It turned out with a lovely crunchy outer coating and very tender inside. More of a bananas foster flavor than the traditional banana bread, but I'm in love.

I did have to increase the time of cooking, but it wasn't much. If you don't know basic rules of baking, such as sticking in a knife or toothpick to test how done it is, then you fail at life.

text:
This bread was wonderful! It's such a great recipe. The bread came out super moist and full of rich banana flavor. I did halve the recipe and made two 8x3 inch delicious loaves. I used 1 over ripe banana and 2 regular ones since I didn't have enough. I don't believe it affected the flavor too much. I also used only 1 cup of sugar, since I don't really like super sweet bread. The baking time is spot on, 1 hour was the perfect timing for my bread. This banana bread recipe is definitely one that I will use again!

userID:
5553328
Display Name:
JoJoBear
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7124905.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these twice now. The first time was great, the second time was even better. I made 3 loaves the first time, gave one to my father in law who loved it. He asked me to make it for his birthday which I did last night. I did make a few changes the second time. I didn't use the full coating ingredients. The first time I had more than half left over. I used 2 tablespoons of white sugar and 1/2 teas cinnamon, sprinkled over greased pans and still had leftover. I added 1 1/2 cups of white sugar and 1 cup packed brown sugar. I used 7 very ripe bananas instead of 6. I didn't have enough sour cream so I used 8 ounces of sour cream and 8 ounces of Greek style yogurt. I added 2 1/2 teas of vanilla. I also toasted the pecans at 175 C degrees for 10 minutes before chopping. I added a 1/2 teas of nutmeg as well. I used a 9x9" round pan and baked it for 1 hour and 45 mins at 160 C degrees. It also made one extra loaf which baked perfect at 160 C for 1 hour and 25 mins. I have a smaller oven and takes a bit longer to cook. It turned out perfect, not to sweet, moist, soft and melts in your mouth. The crust topping makes it that much better, if possible. The crunchy topping and soft middle is the perfect match. I've never had banana bread this good. This is the one and only banana bread recipe for me. Thank you so much for this recipe.

text:
This was the best Banana Bread I have ever made and my husband "actually" loved it!  It didn't get completely done in 1 hour. I was afraid it would burn so I turned the heat down to 300 degrees and let it bake another 15 minutes...it came out great. No one in my family likes Walnuts so I used Pecans.  I toasted them first in a pan on the stove and just as they were finished I added a tablespoon of sugar and 2 pinches of salt then a teaspoon of butter and it put a very nice glaze on the nuts...then I added it to the batter.  We really loved this recipe and will defiantly bake it again!

text:
This banana bread is wonderful!!  Make sure you springke the pan with the cinnamon/sugar mixture.  This addsa nice little crunch to the outside edges.  I baked mine in three loaf pans for 1 hr 10 min. on 300'. Like another reviewer, I also mixed up 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup flour, 3 Tbs. butter and 1/2 cup chopped walnuts.  I sprinkled all of this on top prior to baking.  WOW!!!  Best banana bread I have EVER had.  My husband isn't a big banana bread fan, but he ranted and raved about this one.  PS. I covered the tops of the loaves with an aluminum tent for the final 20 minutes to prevent the tops from browning too much.

userID:
761116
Display Name:
Julie Ann White
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
25
favoritesCount:
142
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1166464.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very easy recipe which makes it a keeper for me. I found the bread had a good crumb and a decent banana flavor. I halved the ecipe as I only had three bananas and didn't need four loaves anyway. I got lazy in the half-recipe and used two eggs instead of using a one and a half-egg, I just added about two tbsps more flour. I also used plain greek yogurt in place of the sour cream - it's what I had on hand. I used a glass loaf pan for one and a disposable aluminum tin for the other, then precisely measured the batter in half between the two pans to see how the time came out (since there is quite a lot of issues mentioned). The glass pan loaf was done in 70 minutes (it was probably passable at 60, but I thought it needed that tiny bit extra). The aluminum tin was still visually batter-y between the cracks at 70 minutes - it needed 30 minutes more for a total of 100 minutes baked at 300 degrees. I covered both loaves with foil at the 50-minute mark to control the dark top.
Review:

5

This is by far THE best banana bread I've ever made/eaten! I made the recipe exactly as statet. I only had 2 bananas so I made 10 servings on the recipe page and hit the calculate button and follwed the recipe as stated. I used a "standard" meatloaf/bread glass loaf dish but had to bake it for 1 hour and 25 minutes. It turned out PERFECT! This recipe is definitely a keeper. Everyone raved that it was the best banana bread they'd ever had! CORRECTION- I just realized I altered the serving size for the recipe I made but still added the full 16 oz.of sour cream! country:
None
text:
Before trying this, I read all the "negative" comments, suggestions and changes people made. Accordingly,  I just made this recipe with these changes:  I set the oven at 325; I used only 2 1/2 cups of sugar; I used light sour cream;  I filled only 3 regular (9x5) loaf pans only half-full plus one smaller foil pan. I just tasted a small slice: a very moist, sweet banana bread (more like cake).  Although I tested each with a toothpick which did come out clean, I probably will leave it in a bit over an hour next time.  I added chocolate chips to one loaf and found that the very bottom of that one could have done with one or two minutes more of baking.  All in all, a most delicious banana bread to add to my collection. As with most quickbreads, probably best to save slicing for after one or two days of ripening.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was excellent. I bake in a counter top convection oven, so I scaled the recipe to 21 servings (2 eggs; yield: 3 mini-loaves), adjusted the temperature to 275 F. and the cooking time to 40 minutes. I used these settings for the first 2 mini-loaves. For the third mini-loaf, I changed the cooking time to 35 minutes. I covered all of the loaves with an aluminum foil "tent" during the last 15 minutes of baking time. Other "tweaks" included: (1) I used 2 cups all-purpose flour and 1 cup whole wheat (healthier); (2) I used 1 cup Splenda (fewer calories) and 1/2 cup brown sugar; (3) I used the full 1/2 cup of butter but I also added 1/4 cup unsweetened (homemade) applesauce for additional moisture. The results? My 2 adult sons finished (a better word might be "devoured") one of the loaves before I had a chance to wrap the second loaf and even before the third loaf had finished baking (LOL). They topped it with Cream Cheese and "washed it down" with milk. I will be making this again.

userID:
2415022
Display Name:
Layla Rodgerson
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5302938.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I inherited a wonderful banana bread recipe from my grandmother when she passed away. I was practically brought up on that stuff. The smell of banana bread in the air always makes me feel warm and fuzzy inside. So, I was surfing around on here looking for different recipes for dinner and such. I came across this sour cream version, and I thought I would give it a shot.  First off, this recipe is phenomenal! It has a great texture, it’s very moist, and also has a wonderful taste. It was very easy to make. Since there are only two people to my household, I divided the recipe by a fourth to accommodate only 8 servings (which equals one loaf). I also took into an account that the written instructions of the recipe are for the 32 servings (four loaves). So, I made the necessary changes to the written recipe format (1 tablespoon of sugar & ¼ ground tsp of cinnamon for dusting the pan. Also, ¾ cups of white sugar go into the mixture).  As for dusting the pan, I didn’t use the full amount that was called for. I took a little bit in the palm of my hand, and just lightly sprinkled it on the greased pan.  I placed the finished mixture in a Stoneware Loaf Pan and cooked it at 300 degrees for about an hour. It was delicious!

text:
This is absolutely the best banana bread recipe I have every made.  My kids never really liked my banana bread because it was too dry.  This is so moist I can't keep it longer than one day.  If I want to save it, I have to freeze it (out of sight out of mind).  One of the reviews said not to use fat-free sour cream.  I use it always and it turns out fine so maybe she had something else going on that day with it.  Not really knowing what six bananas would be (as they are all different in size), I started off using 2 cups and then 3 cups and then 4 cups and found that 4 cups makes more of a "loaf" of banana bread.  At 3 cups it was flat.  Thanks so much for the delicious recipe.  I threw out all my other banana bread recipes as I will never make any other kind of banana bread.

text:
The bread was so delicious!  I did make few modifications- I cut the recipe in half and baked in a 8x8 square pan.  I used 2 eggs, 3/4 cup sour cream (all I had on hand), a pinch of nutmeg, 1/2 cup chocolate chips (& walnuts), 2 cups whole wheat flour, left everything else the same, and baked at 300 for an hour.  After an hour, it was obvious that the temp needed to be higher, so I raised it to 350 and baked about 30 more mins.

It was so moist and the crust was just a tiny bit crunchy.  My boyfriend and I couldn't stop eating it!  Even with the 100% whole wheat flour, the texture was great, almost like it was made with white flour!  I will definitely make again!

As other reviewers have said, the baking times are a bit off.  Also, I substitute some brown sugar for the white, which may be the reason for that(?).  The batter makes much more than I thought, and the cooking time takes longer than stated-maybe 1 1/2 hrs, but TOTALLY WORTH IT!!

I sell my baked goodies at work and this, along with "moms zucchini bread", have given me a new regular!  She wants 2 loaves of each every week! text:
I've not actually made this yet, but my mom has and I wanted to add her comments, so I don't forget(she LOVES this recipe):

Pan size is not regular loaf pan size but smaller. If you make full recipe this will make 3 loaves. If you half this recipe use 2 eggs. I've made with or without nuts and used pecans rather than walnuts. With this list of ingredients how couldn't it be great! (Mom)

text:
My husband and I LOVE this recipe, its delicious. And so easy to make too. The first time I made it I discovered I didn't have quite enough sour cream so I substituted it with the same amount of cream cheese instead and it worked perfectly. I warm the cream cheese in the microwave on a low setting before mixing it in to the butter, sugar etc. I've made this recipe about 4 times already and have used sour cream half the time and cream cheese the other and haven't been able to tell a difference in the wonderful flavour and soft texture. Thanks for a great recipe! :-)

text:
I adjusted this recipe to make 1 loaf in a 9x5 loaf pan = Yield 8 servings. On the conversion for me it says 3 cups of sugar. I halfed this to 1 1/2 cup sugar. This was the only change I made. It turned out absolutely perfect! Any more sugar and it would have been far too much for me. To compensate I dusted the loaf pan a little bit heavier than what the recipe called for. I used 1/2 cup chopped walnuts. FH loved it! It was my first try at baking from scratch in 10 years, so I am very impressed with how easy and yummy it turned out. I will be making this again for sure! Thanks for the recipe!

I made this for Sunday morning breakfast for my husband and myself and I am embarrassed to say that an entire loaf was finished by Monday morning!  It is the best banana bread recipe that I have ever made.  The sour cream made it super moist.  I DID make a few changes, though--no nuts, used two 9x4 loaf pans instead of four 7x3 (made two large loaves) and I omitted the cinnamon in the batter (I am a banana purist, what can I say).  Next time I will probably try the cinnamon in the batter, as per my husband's request!  I also baked them at 350, as other bakers have mentioned here.  The loaves turned out great--this one is definitely a keeper!

text:
This is a nice twist of an old favorite.  I added a bag of chocolate chips at the end of the recipe.  I made 3 loaves and a dozen muffins.  The muffins cooked in about 45 minutes, and two of the loaves were ready when my hour timer went off.  One of the loaves, filled a little more than the others had to cook a little longer.  

If you make this, make sure you are not opening your oven to check on the breads.  This may affect the cooking temp.  I like the cinnamon flavor that comes thru, especially on the bottom of the bread/muffins.  I will make this again!

text:
Just wonderful!  I made a half recipe and baked it in 8 mini loaf pans for friends and a 2x6 loaf pan for my boyfriend's grandparents.  I scarfed down a mini loaf in 2 seconds flat, so I'm making a full-size recipe today.  I only had one problem - some of the sides of the mini loaves stuck to the pans because the cinnamon-sugar coating melted into a sticky syrup that defeated the purpose of the greased pan.  So, this time I'm only going to but the cinnamon-sugar coating on the top of the loaves.  In conclusion, this banana bread is the tastiest, most moist stuff I've ever tried!  :)

text:
A few months ago I had a piece of banana bread at a small coffe shop that was wonderful.  For months I have been trying to duplicate the moistness and density of that bread.  I have found it and much more with this recipe! I made it exactly as It calls for. Perfect.  I am so pleased at how moist the bread is.  The cinn./sugar caoting is a sweet and playful touch, much needed for someone who doesn't care much for the "end" slices. Please keep in mind that the kind of pans you use, the temp. of the ingredients, quality of ingredients and accuracy of oven temp. (as well as other things)all play a role in how well this recipe bakes up.  If a dense and moist banana bread is for you do not give up on this recipe if it doesn't come out right; take a look at some of the things mentioned.  This banana bread is fabulous. Myself, and my husband (who is very picky and critical about his food,have plowed through all four loaves in the past four days! The only thing I would suggest is to maybe add banana extract to batter if you like an intense banana flavor( as another review mentioned).  But keep in mind this is a sour cream banana bread, the "sour cream" coming first. Thank you Esther!!!!

text:
I absolutely LOVE this recipe!!!  I halved the recipe and baked ALL the batter in a 9x5 loaf pan.  I baked it at 350 degrees for 1 hour.  I took the advice of a previous review and loosely  covered the loaf with foil during the last 25 minutes of baking to prevent the top from becoming too brown.  No gooey center as most of my other attempts in years past!!!!!  Definitely a keeper!!!!  The sour cream seems to be the secret ingredient in this banana bread in the same way that mayonnaise is the secret ingredient in my cake recipes!!!!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2990055.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazingly good recipe! The trick to this one is to beat the butter, eggs, sour cream & sugar on high with a hand mixer before adding everything else. The loaves fluff up perfectly like a cake and then settle down after cooling off just like a good nut bread should. The ONLY two things I did different, was use HALF the sugar because good, ripe bananas add sweetness, too. Everyone far & wide that got to have some LOVED the bread and were none the wiser that I used less sugar!! And secondly, I cooked at 325* for 45 minutes before turning oven up to 350* to finish them off for the final 30 minutes of baking (1hour & 15 min total). The toothpick test came out clean then. If the loaves start to brown too much on top, cover with a piece of foil and they'll be fine.

Totally amazing! So moist and delicious. I only have one bread pan so I quartered the recipe, which led to me having to use like one whole egg rather than 3/4 egg. Not a problem to round up. I also baked at 325 for an hour and covered the pan with foil during the last 20 mins of baking. The loaf came out completely uniform in color except swirls of spice and banana wonderful-ness. I also left out the nuts because I don't like them. The cinnamon sugar on the outside was such a hit. Best banana bread, hands down.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I get great feedback whenever I make this, but I make a few changes.  1). I do not sprinkle the cinnamon and sugar into the baking pan(s) because I find the taste to be overpowering.  The cinnamon in the bread is a nice subtle flavour which always surprises people who try it and think it's great.  Covering the bread in it is simply overpowering.  2). I halve the recipe and that will make a single loaf in a standard size loaf pan.  When halving I recommend using 2 medium bananas and 1 egg (forget about the half). Bake at 350 for around 45 minutes and it comes out perfect.  3).  I like to sprinkle some quick oats and brown sugar on the top before baking.  Gives it a nice rustic look.

text:
This is the recipe you are looking for. It's hands down the best banana bread you'll ever make. Everyone loves banana bread, but if you want one that stands out as the best everyone's had, this is it. I have a million other things to be doing right now, but just made a loaf for the hundredth time and decided to review it because it's that great. I don't always have sour cream, so that's the one thing that is tricky, and I also don't always have 6 ripe bananas, either! I have found that halving the recipe is fine (sometimes using 2 of the 3 orig. eggs). As for the raw center others speak of, use your judgment. If it looks raw, let it go a couple more minutes. This one doesn't dry out quickly like others-- it's really moist, rich and just the right amount of sweet. Sometimes I add whatever chopped nuts I have on hand to the top, and I always finish the top with a sprinkle of cinn/sugar. I have frozen the loaves as the recipe description suggests and they come out literally as good as a fresh loaf. But the only way that extra loaf will make it to the freezer is if no one else is around :) Seriously, this is a keeper.

country:
None
text:
The texture of the bread was light and springy and coating the pans with the cinnamon/sugar mixture gave the outside a wonderful brown sugary taste.  Half the recipe calls for 1.5 eggs so I used 1 egg and then a flax/egg substitute (1T ground flax + 3T water) for the 0.5 egg as it is much easier for me to use half of the flax than trying to use half of an egg.  The flax also adds a slight nuttiness to the bread which was nice because I was out of walnuts!  My two 9x5 loaves were done in exactly 1hr at 300 degrees so no trouble there, but I am only giving this 3 stars because the banana overpowered by the cinnamon.  I will use this recipe as a base and add more banana because everything else about the recipe is spot-on.

Good stuff! I only had 1 cup of sour cream (instead of 2) - so I added yoghurt (actually... Yop!) and it still came out nice and moist. text:
I have made this recipe in a loaf pan, muffin pans and mini muffin pans. We adored the muffins. 
One dozen muffins is the same volume as one loaf pan and they cook in only 30 minutes. The minis cook in 20 minutes. 
No matter which way you prepare this recipe it will turn out great. 
I don't think a few chocolate chips would hurt either!

text:
This is my go-to banana bread recipe!  I use brown sugar in the batter instead of white sugar and cut it down to 2 cups.  In addition to dusting the bread pans with the cinnamon-white sugar mixture, I also sprinkle some on top of the batter before baking.  This gives it a light crispness on top and is my fiance's favorite feature of this banana bread!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made this today with my extremely overripe bananas.  I halved the recipe, and made the following changes- used 1/2 ripe avocado instead of butter, 1 C sugar, 2 eggs, separated and beaten before adding, 3/4 c greek plain yogurt, half wheat/half white flour, added extra cinnamon and I had to put in chocolate chips for my daughter.  I also did sugar and cinnamon the outside....I brought a loaf to my husband at work...he texted me- Nothing but....Y U M M Y....and he usually DOES NOT enjoy most of my somewhat healthier version of baked goods....he has no idea I used avocado either...nor do the kids!!  GREAT RECIPE

text:
This a such a great recipe!  Big hit every time I bake it.  It is a go to recipe for pot lucks and parties.  I know some of you have had trouble with baking time/temp.  My current oven takes about 20 min longer than it calls for at 300.  What I do is keep a close eye on it after an hour checking in the middle until my toothpick comes out clean.  DONT change the temperature. Keep it at 300.  Tried to up it to 350 and came out dry!

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
3
userID:
2473431
Display Name:
Candice
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
81
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/140759.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't know who needs 4 loaves so I halved the recipe and used a 9x5 loaf pan (a shallower pan would've been better). I left out sugar recipe for bottom of pan. I don't think its necessary

2 eggs
3 bananas (thats all i had)
3/4 cup of sugar (cut back on the sugar because of other reviewers, but it needs more!!! I'd say 1 cup to 1-1/4) 
8oz of sour cream
1tsp of vanilla
1tsp ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon of salt
1-3/4 baking soda
2-1/2 cups of flour
1/3 cup 1tbsp and tsp butter (awkward i know)
no walnuts, so i used 3/4 cup of raw halved pecans

300 degrees 1 hour (because of the pan I used I think I ended up baking for about an hour and a half. I would recommend upping the heat to 325-350, especially for a deeper loaf pan.)

Average banana bread to me.  The baking instructions cannot be correct. text:
I just made this banana bread about a week ago and it turned out amazing! It's the first time I've ever attempted making it and my husband said it was the best banana bread he's had. I did almost everything exactly as instructed but took a few other reviewers tips and made 3 9x5 loaves baked at 325 degrees for an hour and 10 minutes. I also used 5 large bananas since I didn't have 6 and it still tasted great. Take it from a first timer, this banana bread is awesome!! I was super apprehensive to try making it because we love banana bread at our house and I didn't want to make something only to have it turn out yucky. It was very easy and better than the banana bread that people have made for us. Thank you for a recipe that I will be using for years to come!

text:
This is a wonderful recipe. Instead of the bread version, I made large muffins. They freeze well. 2 minutes in the microwave, instant breakfast. I have posted a picture of my finished product. I made some minor changes to the recipe. I didn't have white sugar available. So I used 1 cup of brown sugar for the muffins. 3/4 cup of applesauce instead of butter. 2 cups of wheat flour, 2 1/2 of all purpose. A couple of dashes of nutmeg. I had a cup of blueberries that needed to be used up. I threw that in there as well (otherwise they would have walked out of the fridge.) I used 1/4 cup of brown sugar and cinnamon as a topping instead of using it on the bottom. This recipe is in my recipe box. Thank for sharing!

this is REALLY GOOD, similiar to the choc chip banana muffins on this site which i make with walnuts. i halved the recipe, and i used about 2 tbs butter...didnt have a hand mixer so i just whisked it with 1 cup sugar..i used only 1 egg, i forgot the cinamon and half cup walnuts and used only 2 cups flour baked in 2 loaf pans at 325 for 1 hour and 10 minutes perfectly cooked!!!... i also felt like it was a little sweeter than id like so next time im goign do to 3/4 cup of sugar

**UPDATE IVE MADE THIS AGAIN TODAY AFTER A WHILE**
For half the recipe...
I used 2 tbsp melted Smart balance butter, and 3/4 cup of sugar. I kept everything else the same, but used FAGE NONFAT YOGURT instead of sour cream...and 4 ripe bananas, and 2 cups flour. Awesome for breakfast!!

FABULOUS!!!!!! Perfection!  I didn't have the same size pans as called for. baked 2 in 9" loaf pans & had enough batter left for 6 muffins. text:
This is actually my second review... couldn't figure out how to add to that one so starting anew.. :o)  

this bread is AWESOME! The first time I made it with only 5 very overripe bananas, and it turned out delish.  The second time I made it with 6 bananas that only had 1 or 2 brown spots on them (thought for sure the bread wouldn't turn out) and it turned out wonderfully, maybe even better than the first time!  Whoever said that they had to be rotten is WRONG!  And both times I've made this recipe I've used Splenda, and it's amazing how fast this bread has disappeared.  
Also, be sure to make a topping for it.  I use a few shakes of cinnamon (I eyeball it... approx 2 teaspoons), half-stick butter - softened, 1/2 cup brown sugar and a 1/2 cup flour.  

The next time I make it I may try using that topping in the bottom of the pan, too.  Mmmm...

I was not a big fan of banana bread but I had a couple of black bananas and some sour cream close to expiring. I cut the recipe by two thirds since I only had 2 bananas and used a mini loaf pan. My husband and I each tried one and they are great!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Definately the best banana bread recipe I've tried yet!  I made this for Christmas goodie bags and I'm very proud to have included a loaf of this moist, flavorful bread in each one.  I took other reviewers' advice and baked the loaves at 325.  I used two 8" pans and one 9" pan.  I cooked the 8" loaves for 1 hour 5 mins. and the 9" loaf for 1 hour 10 mins.  I don't understand why some people had so much trouble with the timing.  I use glass loaf pans - perhaps metal pans cook differently?  I followed the recipe exactly and will do the same next time - I wouldn't change a thing.  It's perfect :)

text:
I downsized the servings size since I didn't have enough sour cream, and made a few changes. First off, I changed the temp to 375, as other reviewers stated 300 was way too low. 2) I added an extra egg, because 24 servings says 2 1/4 egg, well ok. 3) I added 1/4 tsp of nutmeg again as other reviewers suggested. 4. I added Terry's chocolate orange chocolate to the top of a few muffins (works very well if I do say so myself!)  I would suggest pureeing the bananas, as the muffins came out with chunks of mushy banana, could be caused by a lack of mashing on my part but I also used a hand-mixer. In the end, this is a really good recipe. I will continue to search for a better one, but will definitly use this one again. Thank you

text:
I have made many different recipes of banana bread and never had one stand out like this.  I usually don't make banana bread my first choice in using up ripe bananas.  However, this recipe was excellent.  Other than leaving out the nuts, I followed the recipe exactly.  It was phenomenally good!  Way better than any other banana breads that I have made. Will definitely make again and have already shared the recipe :)  NOTE: I did bake these in my convection oven and it was very most and delicious!  Took only 45 minutes to bake (not the 1 hr. stated in the recipe).  I do have a double oven so I put 2 loaves in each for baking.  Not sure how they would have done with 4 loaves in one oven.  As another note to another review that stated they baked it at 300 and it was raw in the center - either follow the advice of others to up the temp or get an oven thermometer and make sure your oven is calibrated correctly. I don't know if the original poster used convection and that is why it worked for them and me at 300.  I will try this again on my regular bake setting and let you know the results.

The bread turned out moist and not overly sweet or heavy.  I was able to make three 12 loaves and made up for it by baking at 325 and covering the tops with aluminum foil 20 minutes before done. I also sprinkled cinnamon and sugar mixture for the top of the bread.  Delicious!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good!! My husband gave it 5 stars! Not too sweet for him. Perfect texture. I cut the recipe in 1/2 since I only had 3 bananas, and baked at 325 in 1 deep 9x5 loaf pan for about 1 1/2 hours.  The only changes I made were that I used 2 eggs for 1/2 the recipe, and 1/3 C butter, 1 C white sugar and 1/2 C brown sugar, and a dash of nutmeg.  One complaint: when I took it out of the pan the outside was a bit soggy--I think because of the sugar/cinnamon coating on the pan? Or maybe I left it in the pan too long when it was cooling? Anyways, I just threw it back in the oven for 10 minutes (at 350) to dry out the outside of the loaf & that worked great. The sugar/cinnamon and nuts on top were a great, easy addition. Will do that again.  This will be my new "always use" banana bread recipe!!

userID:
558873
Display Name:
Julie62
isPro:
False
followersCount:
25
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
197
favoritesCount:
3129
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/154.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very moist banana bread. I was taking this to a Christmas brunch and wanted something festive, so I made the following modifications. I added a jar of marachino cherries that I halved, and a can of pineapple tidbits that I squeezed most of the juice out of.  I also added roasted pistachios, but I won't do that again; they turned soft. I also used fat-free sour cream and it worked just fine. This took a long time to bake -- about 1-1/2 hours, and it didn't rise much (i.e., it didn't have a domed top). To serve, I sliced the loaf down the center length-wise, then turned to slice cross-wise. This made nice individual pieces that I put on a Christmas tree-shaped tray.  I decorated with maraschino cherries to look like ornaments and put a star-shaped cookie on top. It was colorful and very tasty. My family can't wait for me to make this again.  Thanks Esther!

text:
I made the best Banana Bread/Cake ever utilizing this recipe. Usually the loaves turn out too dense and heavy so I substituted CAKE FLOUR for all of the all purpose flour. (I guess you could do half and half too) I also used FAT FREE SOUR CREAM. It was super light and tasty.     I halved the recipe, used one 9 inch square cake pan, and baked it for 40 minutes on 300° and the remaining 20 minutes, covered with foil, at 350°.     It came out perfectly baked. Finally!!! After sooo many banana bread recipes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummmmm! The only thing I can add to this is that a friend of mine clued me in to using Coconut Oil in baking awhile back and I ALWAYS use some in place of some butter in quick breads and cookies. It's a soft solid a room temp (except summer :D ) and a liquid oil above about 75 degrees. It adds just a hint of flavor that everyone that tastes my baking loves, but can't quite put their finger on...the perfect secret ingredient! Try substituting 1/2 the oil/butter in a recipe. My favorites for using it are...Banana Bread, duh, and chocolate chip walnut cookies (or white chocolate macadamia nut!). You can spend $$$$ at a health food store for Coconut oil, but I find it in the vitamin section of my local Walmart for $10 (sounds like a lot for a little jar, but you don't need much and it's soooo good and good for you!...that's my justification for eating the Banana Bread and cookies, hahaha, Girl Math!

Wow! This was great banana bread. It was a painful hour of waiting for the loaves to bake--the smell was making my mouth water! The sour cream makes it very moist without a sour cream taste. I followed the recipe and directions exactly except I covered the loaves with tin foil 20 minutes before they were done baking to prevent the tops from being to well done, and I used only five bananas because one of them had gone bad and I only had six. I also whipped the bananas with a hand mixer, and sprinkled the extra cinnamon-sugar mixture I had left on top of the loaves before putting in the oven. Thanks for the wonderful recipe!

This recipe was simple and great! I cut it in half because the whole recipe would have been too much. I made 16 muffins and one loaf of bread. I added a tablespoon of vanilla and cinamon instead of a teaspon. Cooked at 325. The muffins for about 30-35 minutes and the bread for 55 minutes. The last 20 minutes I covered with tin foil. Easy, fast and the whole family loved!

userID:

Display Name:
ellenphant

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This definitely was really good. I would make it again! :) I followed the suggestions of the reviewers - I halved the recipe, first as I had no need for 4 loafs of bread. I like my breads spicy so I actually put double the cinnamon, and put a dash of nutmeg and a dash of cloves as well. I used light sour cream and it was fine. I did cut the sugar as I wanted this to be more for breakfast than a dessert to 3/4 of a cup of white sugar. Next time I think I will try brown sugar instead.  The only thing about this bread that does not give it the 5 stars is that I like my breads a tad big denser. This was a tad more "cake-like" but nevertheless, delicious! :) I also did the streussel topping with the 1/2 cup flour and brown sugar, 1 tsp cinnamon, and 2 tablespoons butter before I put it in the oven. Because of this, I thought cutting the sugar was a must, otherwise it would definitely be too sweet. Had no problems with the bread rising. I baked at 325 for 55 minutes with 2 8x3 pans (the aluminum disposable bread pans at the grocery store) and it came out clean with a toothpick. My boyfriend thought the bread was DELICIOUS and especially liked it with the topping. I am an avid baker so he is used to things making the kitchen smell nice but when he smelt this he said his mouth completely started watering!! The aroma this bread let out when it was baking was one I've never smelt before ... it was fabulous. :)

text:
I have tried many banana bread recipes, and it amazes me when I come across one that is even better then my favorite recipe at the time.  When I saw the ratings for this recipe when I was searching for Christmas recipes, I had to give it a try. I am glad that I did. It is a big hit in my family! The sour cream is a nice addition that helps make the bread be so moist.  I love the idea of coating the pans with the cinnamon sugar (I added some on top as well). I halved the recipe since I only had 3 bananas (I used 2 large eggs) and I still had enough batter to make 4 mini loafs. My baking time was decreased to 40 minutes using the smaller pans. Use soft or melted butter to ease in mixing. Added a layer of cinnamon sugar to the middle of loafs. Put l/2 of batter in pan sprinkle with cinnamon sugar and then add the second half of batter. Topped with sugar crystals. Beautiful loafs of bread!  Great gift idea!

text:
It's really a yummy recipe!  I modified by: substituting butter with 1 cup oil; reduced vanilla extract to 1 teaspoon & added 1 teaspoon banana extract; reduced baking soda to 2 teaspoons & added 1 teaspoon baking powder; reduced flour to 3 1/2 cups.  Bake at 325 degrees for 1-1 1/2 hours (or until toothpick comes away clean from center).  Immediately cover with foil while cooling & it will be really moist.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is excellent.  The cinnamon sugar "crust" is great.  The recipe really does make a huge amount of batter... almost too much for a kitchenAid mixer bowl!  The only issue I have is that the size loaf pans called for are very scarce.  So you are kind of on your own as to the size of pan and baking time.  I made 1 9x5, 1 8x4, and a pan of mini loaves.  The large one cooked (at 325) for almost an hour and a half, the smaller one for about an hour and twenty minutes, and the mini loaf pan cooked about an hour.  I filled all of them to about an inch below the top of the pan.  Other than that confusion... this was an excellent, moist, flavorful recipe.  You can add extras like raisins, craisins, different nuts- whatever you like.  Don't skip dusting the cinnamon sugar on the pans.  Not only does it taste good, but it also helps the baked loaves come right out easily.  Try this!

Oh My Goodness... this is even better the next day!  Try it with cream cheese.

text:
this is my favorite banana bread recipe.  I make it all the time, my favorite part about it is that it makes 4 loaves, my boys love banana bread and usually polish off a loaf as soon as I cut it up.  I love the cinnamon-sugar idea, I've made them with the c-s mixture on the bottom and on the top of the loaves and it's good both ways, I've also forgotten to put it on entirely and that works too.  It does freeze well, one day I had a ton of bananas and no one was eating them, ended up making a dozen loaves - had to freeze some, and give some away.

text:
Oh, my goodness, I am throwing away all my other banana bread recipies, and using only this one from now on. So moist, so full of flavor, oh my so good. I halved the recipie, and used 2 eggs (when you half it it calls for 1 1/2 eggs). I also threw in a dash of nutmeg, and put a crumb topping of cinnamin, butter, brown sugar, flour and walnuts on top before baking. i am going back for my second piece now..excuse me
