text:
This is by far the best Banana Bread recipe I have ever tried - and I love Banana Bread, so I have made it alot.  I've made it several times now, and have used different nuts (macadamia nuts were awesome) and always taste the bananas I use prior to adding the sugar.  The last time I made it my bananas, while over-ripe, just weren't very sweet.  So I did use the full amount of sugar in the recipe, and it turned out absolutely delicious!  So it definately rates 5 stars; great just as the recipe reads, and also lends itself beautifully to changes.  I have added different spices, also ... it never fails to be a huge hit.  I freeze extra loaves, and now have to actually hide them in the freezer to prevent family (and friends!) from digging it out and eating it!  Thanks for a PERFECT recipe!

text:
This bread was very yummy!  Very moist and tender, and stayed that way after a few days too.  My girls devoured it!  The one thing I would change is that I didn't care for the cinnamon/sugar coating on the sides from the pan dusting - it made for a crunchy-type crust because it seemed to carmelize a bit for me.  I prefer my bread to be soft all over, so this was not an appropriate addition for me.  Perfect for someone who likes a bit of crunch in their bread though!

text:
Holy Moly!  I will never make another banana bread recipe again!  This is so good that I seriouslu could eat the whole loaf right now.  Wow.  The cinnamon and sugar coating on the pan makes a delicious crispy glaze all over the bread - so add some to the top before baking too.  Mmmmmm.  
I only have 1 9 x 3 1/2 bread pan and a pan that makes 8 mini loaves, so I cut the recipe in half, which made 1 big loaf plus 4 mini loaves.  Since my pan was bigger than the one called for in the recipe I baked it for an hour and ten minutes, and the mini loaves for 25 minutes.  They came out perfect!  Thanks for my new banana bread recipe!

region:

country:

text:
There are lots of banana bread recipes, but the best ones make sure the bread is moist.  This was FINALLY my first successful attempt at a moist and delicious banana bread.  I halved the recipe and used one of the pans that make 4 mini-loaves.  I started watching the bread after 40 minutes, and pulled it out around 45-50 minutes (toothpick came out clean).  I used Tillamook fat-free sour cream, and dusted the tops with confectioners' sugar.  Even though I used fat-free sour cream, the loaves came out really moist.  I brought a loaf to work, and it was gone in 1/2 hour.  Great recipe!!

userID:
278426
Display Name:
MARY DOMAZ
isPro:
False
followersCount:
38
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
233
favoritesCount:
2018
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I hate to be the bad guy, but I was not impressed with this recipe. It has its pluses, which is why it got a three. It is a relatively light banana bread. Most banana bread recipes are very heavy and dense. This one cooks up light, which is nice. What I didn't like, was the cinnamon in the batter. I love cinnamon, but it overpowered the banana taste. If I decide to try this recipe again, I will not put any cinnamon in the batter. I will, however, put the cinnamon/sugar mixture on the bottom of the pan and on the top of the batter. That would be all the cinnamon I would want. I guess I am used to banana bread tasting like banana, and I didn't find that the case in this bread.

I had to leave a review b/c it made the VERY BEST banana bread!!  I did make some changes, took others advice and cut sugar to 2 1/2 c sugar, used white/whole wheat blend flour,wheat bran and wheat germ to make the 4 1/2 c flour then added 1 tsp baking powder since some had said it was alittle too dense/didn't seem to cook all the way through.  It came out perfect and sooo delicious.  The recipe made 5 smaller loaves and 12 muffins.

This bread is fabulous! I substituted 1 cup brown sugar for one of the white, omitted the nuts and added some flour dusted mini chocolate chips, and used Mexican vanilla (a wonderfully spicy vanilla). Cooking time for me was a little over an hour in a Pampered Chef bread pan. The bread was wonderful right out of the oven but even better the next day. I usually make the Banana Banana bread on this site but I may replace it with this recipe. I found this one to be just as wonderful in flavor and moistness but not quite as sweet. Can't wait to eat the loaf I stuck in the freezer!

country:
None
text:
Alright...I'm now part of the thousands of reviewers who thought this was the best bread out there! If you're reading this, you probably know that some changes made this bread outstanding. I halved the recipe and baked in 7 1/2 x 9 inch loaf pans at 325 degrees for 1 hour and 10 minutes. I also added a pinch of nutmeg and cinnamon to the filling. But the best change of all was following another reviewer's advice by adding a crumb topping: ½ cup packed brown sugar, ½ cup all-purpose flour, 2 or 3 tablespoons butter, melted, 1 teaspoon cinnamon, 1/3 cup chopped pecans. Best banana bread I ever made...ask my family who has had to endure very mediocre or underdone banana bread for years!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-12-21T15:10:59.64

userID:
4080268
Display Name:
SHANEY
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
69
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5480741.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe  for the past 6 years and I can not give it more than 5 stars or I would!! I have never met anyone  who  didn't think this is the best version they have ever eaten  even  if  they don't like sour cream  just don't tell them before lol and trust me they would never know. The sour cream  is not strong or over powering  at all. I love banana bread but hate the usual bitterness most of them have to them. The addition of sour cream takes that away and you are left with a amazing  flavor of banana. Also the sour cream  adds that extra moisture  most breads lack this bread always makes 5-6 loafs  for me which is perfect for giving at Christmas time an when I have extra they keep for almost 2 weeks wrapped in foil. I hate having to eat everything  so fast then you get burned out on it. The only thing I do differently is I add the vanilla and cinnamon last  I go by smell because  I want the batter to still have  the  banana  smell as well as the vanilla  and  cinnamon, so as I add a little bit of each, I smell above the mixer as its going so I get the aroma from the mixing process to know when I have added  the  right amount for my family. My daughter who cannot make anything poor kid I taught her this method and she was amazed because she never knew that was what I was doing. My kids love the batter left in the bowl just as much as the bread. OK now that I have rambled enough about this bread im off to start making my Christmas batches.

5
dateLastModified:

userID:
17853879
Display Name:
Gramma T.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this banana bread many,  many times for my #1 fan, the hubby, who regularly says it is the best he has ever had!! That after almost 70 years of trying different recipes!!!
I now make 4 loaves at a time and freeze some, wrapped in freezer paper (so top does not peel off upon opening it) and plastic. Loaves given out to friends yields frozen banana donations to encourage this baker to keep-it-coming!!! 
Changes: 350 degree oven for 50-60 minutes
                     4 tsp baking soda
                      1 tsp nutmeg added
                       1 TBSP vanilla
                        2 cups walnuts ( pecans weren't 'right' per hubby)
I cream the sugar and butter till very well blended and fluffy then cream in the eggs; with mixer on low speed I add banana- vanilla mixture then sour cream and while still running slow mixer I spoon the flour /baking soda/ salt mixture in. Stir in walnuts before distributing to well sugared ( w/cinnamon mixture) loaf pans. 
Anyone have some frozen bananas for me? 
Perfect!!! Four more loaves in the oven now.

country:

text:
Great, moist recipe--needed to bake for 1 hr to 1 hr & 20 min at 325 deg-F.  Since I used different sized pans, and since I put all 4 pans in at the same time, my breads came out at varying times.  Used frozen bananas (weight of 2 frozen bananas is 7.25 oz with the banana "juice", so multiply by 3 to scale this up to 6 banana recipe) and macadamia nuts since that was all I had.  Also added a dash of cloves and nutmeg to the batter and to the cinnamon/sugar lining.  I tasted the batter before baking and I was really afraid that the bread was going to be too sweet.  But it turned out perfectly in every regard.  Immediately after I barely mixed in the dry ingredients, I popped the pans into the oven.  The bread rose enough such that the batter overflowed, so be careful not to fill the batter to the brim.

text:
This is a great tasting banana bread recipe and so moist!  I had used the same banana bread recipe for years that was handed down to me by my husband's grandmother until now.  I was searching for a recipe to use up a large quantity of sour cream and as a bonus found a recipe that would also use up overripe bananas.  I made the following changes:  1.  I don't care for cinnamon so I don't put it in the bread nor dust the pans with cinnamon and sugar.  2.  I substitute plain yogurt for the sour cream if that is what I have on hand.  3.  I use 3 pans instead of 4 pans.  4.  I upped the temperature to 325 degrees and baked it for another 15 minutes.  Turns out perfect every time!

text:
This recipe was absolutely fantastic save for the cooking time. I found 1 hour at 300 degrees to be insufficient, so after the first hour I covered with foil and increased the temperature to 325 for an additional 20 minutes which resulted in a perfectly done loaf. This could have been the result of me baking in a cast iron loaf pan, but regardless it was a trivial issue that was easily gotten around. 

Additionally I added dried blueberries to the dough/batter which made it even more moist and awesome. I will definitely be making this again and it is my new go to banana bread recipe. :)

I made this recipe yesterday and the bread is wonderfully moist, plus the cinnamon sugar makes a tasty crust. The next time, I might even sprinkle cinnamon sugar on top.
Since I only had 4 bananas I switched to 22 servings (love that feature of allRecipes!) for the best balance of ingredients. In about 15 minutes it was perfect - not burned and well baked inside.
The next time I might try 325 for the baking time. Either way, I will repeat this recipe and gave it only 4 stars due to the baking temp/time issue.

I hardly ever write reviews, usually because I just exit out and forget about doing it...BUT, this one was worth it! I made one batch and turned it into so many different flavors. Chocolate Chip Banana Bread, Chocolate Chip Walnut Banana Bread, Banana Walnut Bread, and just plain old FABULOUS Banana Bread! It makes so much and its fluffy and tasty, and everything you could ever imagine banana bread needs to be. I left the Cinnamon out of the actual recipe, but still used it for the lining and I think it was still great! I'm just not a huge cinnamon person. This is one recipe I'll pass on to friends and family!

text:
This is a huge recipe! I had a bunch of ripe bananas on hand so just made the whole recipe. I only have one loaf pan. So I yielded one giant loaf of bread and 24 muffins. Don't be too shy when filling the pans because this recipe lifts really nicely. My husband loved it! Neither of us thought it was too sweet and he's sensitive to things being really sweet. The recipe is denser than a cake but lighter than most breads. The only change I made was add 1/2 tsp rack of nutmeg and cloves. Gave a spicy essence. Oh I also use the crumb topping from the zucchini bread on this site. Very good! The recipe is a keeper!

text:
Just had my first slice from the batch I just made.  FANTASTIC!  Using hints from others I used 2 cups of mashed bananas but made no other ingredient changes.  I made 8 mini loaves, (the smaller foil pans you get at the market - about 3x5.5.)  Using a digital kitchen scale, I put about 11 oz. into each pan. (pan weighs .4 oz. so you get about 11.4 oz. total per pan.) Baked at 325 for about 55 min.  BE WARE - this recipe makes a LOT of batter.  Make sure you have a large bowl. (I wound up using a stock pot.)  :)

Display Name:
Tracy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best banana bread recipe ever! Everyone raves about it and asks for some. I have been making this recipe for about 9 months now. I have only ever had one loaf fail. I use 3 8X4 inch bread pans and it fills them perfectly. I also measure out exactly 2 cups of bananas for the recipe and I cook the bread at 325 for about an hour and 15 minutes and it is perfect every time. I also add 1/4 teaspoon of all spice and 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg to the recipe. I too find that I have to cover it for the last 15 min to avoid over browning the top. My only failure was the very first batch I made.I used larger loaf pans and tried cooking at 300 degrees per the recipe. I opened the oven at about 50 min to check on it and see it's progress and the loaves caved in. I learned from that mistake! Higher temp, smaller pans, consistency on amount bananas. Too little or too much banana can make a difference and 6 large bananas is pretty vague. 2 cups was the magic number! Sometimes it takes 6 bananas and sometimes 8 bananas to make 2 cups...

text:
I loved this recipe.  For those who had trouble with cooking time you may want to check the temperature on your oven.  Ours is accurate and one hour was perfect.  

I'm rating this recipe on it's "as written" product.  I used my kitchen aid mixer on a low speed for the entire process.  What I got was a nice consistency delicious bread.  Even my husband loved it..enough that he's taking a loaf to work tonight to share!!!

I have to say that it drives me nuts when people rate a recipe and then list how they changed the entire thing.  But that's just me!  

If you are looking for a nice simple banana bread this is the one you want!!!

text:
Great recipe. I didn't have quite enough sour cream, so I used about 1 cup of sour cream and 1 cup of creamy peanut butter. The result was delicious! I also made them into muffins instead of loaves. The recipe made 36 regular size muffins and 6 jumbo muffins. I also stirred some semi-sweet chocolate chips into the last half of the batter. I did not use the cinnamon and sugar mixture to coat the pans with, but I did sprinkle some coarse sugar on top of the muffins prior to baking.

AMAZING!!! The sour cream is the secret ingredient. I bought the wrong size pans so I made 3 from the recipe. I've never baked anything, so I didn't realize how much it would rise. The result was a "muffin-top" loaf but the taste was amazing. I cooked it longer - until the toothpick (in this case a skewer) came out clean. Oh my, it was fabulous. I did add a topping recommended by one of the top reviewers - delicious. I didn't have quite enough walnuts - next time I'll add more. Overall, it was easy, inexpensive, and most of all - DELICIOUS!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
5+++++++!! My mom used to make banana bread for us as kids on a regular basis so I'm always reluctant to try other recipes since hers has always been my favourite - none of them can even compare with my mom's. I'd have to say that this recipe is better (sorry mom lol). This is going to be my new banana bread recipe!! I made then into square cupcakes for easy individual servings (made 1/2 the recipe & got about 18 "cupcakes"). I even added some chocolate chips to some. I made these last night and there are only 5 left this morning!!! ***DO NOT FORGET the dusting of cinnamon & sugar on the pan this adds such wonderful flavours!!!!! Although my husband and I are on an eating healthy mission so next time I'm going to try some of the other reviewers suggestions to make this lower fat.  UPDATE: I made this with low fat sour cream and I noticed quite a difference. Will use regular next time. I also tried a "crumble" topping on one of the loaves (1/4 cup packed brown sugar, 1/4 cup flour, 2 Tbsp softened butter, 1/4 tsp salt. Mix all together until it's crumbly). This was good but I'm a huge lover of the sticky top of banana bread (sometimes I just eat the top and give my husband the rest) so for me I prefer this without - personal preference. Others said they prefer the crumble. This is the first time I made these in "regular size" loaves (not sure if that was the diff) and I noticed that the colour toward the top of the loaf was different than the bottom. Although still delicious.

text:
Pay attention to the loaf sizes. When it says 7"x3" loaves, they're not kidding, although it made six loaves, not four. One hour at 300 degrees was perfect for the size specified. The insides were cooked perfectly and there was no thick, dry crust on the outside like I typically get with quick breads. VERY moist. I made the bread exactly as stated. I skipped the cinnamon-sugar topping and instead made a glaze of confectioner's sugar, a little orange juice and zest to pour over the bread and it was fantastic. I will keep this recipe on heavy rotation. UPDATE: Makes terrific muffins too! 15-18 minutes at 300 degrees!

text:
Excellent! I made half the recipe - it made 1 full loaf and 1/2 loaf in full size plans (the 1/2 loaf was just skinny). Used 2 T. butter and 1/4 cup cinnamon applesauce and low fat sour cream and less cinnamon.  I beat the eggs and other liquids alot, then mixed the dry ingredients in gently. I think this made the bread light and delicious. Next time I will add less sugar for health reasons, but thought the full amt. did not make it too sweet. Adding nuts would have put this over the top, but I didn't have any on hand. This recipe was just as good as the buttermilk version which I usually make. I always sub cinnamon applesauce for the oil and it's great! Also, baked the big loaf at 325 for about 50 minutes.

text:
I would give this 5 but that's so deceitful when the recipe has the incorrect temperature. That's a pretty big deal. With a 325 oven it's a 5 star but if you cook it too low it's a 1 :) I omit the walnuts because the kids don't like them and swap in some mini-chocoalte chips sprinkled in and on top of the loaf. Yum! Also, it taste just about the same with half the sugar when you add the chocolate chips. 
Other changes: I use coconut oil since I like the flavor it gives. I use plain full-fat yogurt instead of sour cream.

This was good! I cut the recipe in half and used it to make a single loaf, cooked in a 350 degree oven for about 60 minutes, until the outside was deep golden and a knife inserted in center came out clean.  I left out the sugar/cinnamon mixture because the recipe seemed sweet enough without it.  I used reduced fat sour cream and Irish butter.  A keeper!

None
text:
I've made many different versions of banana bread, and this one was so fabulous that I am doing my first ever review on a recipe.  I did modify it somewhat as I don't care for overly sweet desserts, so change the amount of sugar to 1 1/4 cups, I think I would even reduce that more as the cinnamon sugar that you dust the pan with first already gives it sweetness.  I also put in crushed almonds rather than walnuts, but otherwise kept the ingriedients as indicated.  I baked it at 350 degrees for an hour and it was perfect!  Nicely browned and moist, and the crunch from that cinnamon sugar dusting gives the surrounding crust a nice texture.

text:
Absolutely lovely! Made it exactly as written with the exception of oven temp. Like others, I baked at 325. I made 12 muffins for my husbands work, they took 30 minutes. I also got a large 9 X5 loaf out of it. Baked it for just over an hour, also at 325 and covered with foil the last 25 minutes to prevent over browning the top. I also did not use an electric mixer, all by hand. I wanted the density another reviewer mentioned. After all, if you're going to add sour cream for the richness it provides, might as well go all the way. This is simply decadent! Thank you, Esther!

text:
Beware cooking temps & times! I didn't read reviews and almost ended up with gooey bread. I had baked two loaves at 300F for an hour. Reading the reviews after the hour was up because the bread was still wet in the middle, I increased the temperature to 350F for 15 minutes and covered the tops of the bread with aluminum foil to prevent burning. It turned out delicious. Good luck!

Kanri

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
That's some pretty tasty bread there! I followed the original recipe exactly except I made one 9x13 loaf that I baked at 325 degrees for 1 hour 20 mins. It came out perfect! 

I've never tried to cream such an uneven sugar to butter ratio before, and "cream" doesn't really describe the end product of this stage. What I did is softened the butter (sticks) in my had until they were super malleable, cut it into 1/8 cup chunks, and smeared it into the sugar with the back of a wide spoon before stirring. The end texture should resemble instant potato flakes (at least it did for me and turned out fine!). 

Next time I make this recipe, I'm going to experiment a bit - the taste is a little plain for three cups of white sugar! I'll probably do half white and half brown sugar next time and throw in some nutmeg and cloves for some extra zing. I would probably let the bananas ripen just a little more as well. 

Overall a very tasty recipe! The sour cream really gives it some moisture! And pretty simple to boot! I will definitely be making this recipe again!

text:
The best banana bread I've ever made! I baked at 300 degrees for one hour as the recipe calls for and the center was like jelly! (Although, I used 3 baking pans, not 4.) So after the initial hour, I baked for an additional 20 minutes at 450 degrees. It made the crust crispy without being hard as if it were stale and it left the center moist and yummy. A perfect loaf!

text:
Just for the record, don't try and sub cream cheese for sour cream. I didn't check my new container of sour cream before I started and got half way through and realized my roommate had swiped half the container. So in desperation, I tried subbing half the sour cream with cream cheese ( 6oz sour cream, 6oz cream cheese). The loaves still didn't turn out horrible but certainly won't be using cream cheese again. With all the great reviews though, I can't wait to try this recipe again with all the correct ingredients.

text:
Awesome! So delicious! Normally I am not a big fan of very banana tasting goodies, but this recipe is SOOO good!! It made more batter than I expected as I was able to make 4 loaves in the slightly larger sized loaf pans. Also, I forgot to sprinkle the cinn/sugar on the  greased loaves, so I opted to sprinkle it a-top the batter just before I put them in the oven, and added a little more cinnamon to the mixture because I love it. Once sprinkled on top I swirled it with a knife. This makes the very top of the bread slightly moist as it bakes, so if you do this expect it to leave some moist crumbs when you do your toothpick check. This is really terrific, you should go for it! :-D

text:
Fantastic, moist, dense and flavorful. Made 3 loaves in two days and handed out a couple recipes as a result! I cut the recipe in half the first time and the second loaf had crumbs left by that evening! Texture is not cake-like...more like a gourmet cafe slice and the topping really finishes it off. I lined my baking pans with parchment paper to help with a tendency to over bake as well as to get a clean loaf and nice presentation. The overhanging paper also 'secured' any loose topping but with pressing it into the batter just a bit, that wasn't a big problem. Even used frozen ripe bananas and it worked great.

country:
None
text:
Excellent!  I like it sweet (as written) but do add extra vanilla and cinnamon.  Bread is better day two or three after it's been baked, cooled and wrapped up - flavors definitely blend together better.  My cook time changes every time I make - probably the level of moisture and how much I hold true to the recipe;  it's very tolerant.  Extra chopped nuts on top give it a nice nutty touch.   Try toasting it until the outside is a bit crunchy and then put butter on it.  Just keep telling yourself that the potassium is good for you and not to worry about the butter! It's a bit crumbly but I always go for taste. This is my hubby's favorite banana bread; also like the Downeast Maine one from this site.

text:
Excellent! 1 hour at 300 for 4 loaves just does not cut it. I used original recipe, added nutmeg to dry ingredient and to topping I made (1c brown sugar, 1c flour, 6 tbs melted butter, 2 tsp cinnamon & 1/2c chopped walnuts - sprinkled evenly over top of loaves) and bakes for 1hr 20 mins at 325. Came out amazing! People at my work and my wife said it was the best bread of any kind they have ever had. Topping also help keep the tops of bread from burning or getting too dark. Enjoy!

Soooo disappointed.  I really wish I would've read the bad reviews first...lesson learned.

The bake time wasn't accurate at all!  After an hour, I still had four loaves of batter in my oven.  Had to crank the temp up slowly, first to 320 for 20 minutes, then to 350 for another 20.  

Result: My loaves didn't rise, and now I have these solid bricks that remind me of banana flavored play-dough.  

Such a waste of time, money, and the beautiful organic ingredients I splurged for.

 Why the heck do people like this recipe so much?  What am I missing?

text:
I have made this twice and I took the four big loaves to separate functions.  It is amazing what a difference the sour cream makes. I have to admit that I will not make my mother's traditional banana bread anymore, except for my brothers. Everyone else likes this better, and so do I. 

Jan. 2020 
Update: Still making this recipe and giving it out to everyone who asks. Today I only had 1/2 container of sour cream so I used greek yogurt for the other half. You would never know.  I like to put a line of pecan halves down the top. I always use 2 C white sugar and 1/2 C brown sugar.  I bake at 325 instead of 300. It still takes a whole hour and sometimes more, but I have always made two big loaves instead of the four smaller ones.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this recipe for a second time, and I tweaked a few things which led to the BEST Banana Bread that I have ever made (seriously).  

I always use half whole wheat and half white flour when I make banana bread, but the real key to my success this time was not following the recipe (the batter was a little too loose the first time).  I just added a little flour at a time until the batter looked like the banana bread dough of my childhood.

Secondly, I froze all of my bananas completely and then I let them thaw.  It created ooey gooey perfect bananas for the dough.  No mashing required.

text:
By far the BEST banana bread recipe I've ever made.  I'm not a big fan of cinnamon so I omitted dusting the pan w/ cinnamon and adding cinnamon into the batter.  I instead dusted the pan with raw sugar before adding batter for an awesome crunch crust.  Mixed in about 1 cup each of bittersweet chocolate chips, semisweet chocolate chips and chopped walnuts to my batter.  I always get request for this delicious bread!!

userID:
6657980
Display Name:
Melanie Mae Byron
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Phenomenal!  I love that it is a large recipe.  If you're going to make something great, do a bunch of it so you don't run out too fast.  I made it more versatile by making 1 large loaf, 8 large muffin sizes, and 12 cupcake-sized (in muffin tins with paper cups and I added a little cinnamon/sugar to the bottom of each muffin cup).  Careful on the timing for the muffins, as the little ones were ready in just under 30 minutes and the bigger ones a bit later.  Per other recommendations, I cooked them at 325.  I pulled the muffins out when they were golden and left the loaf in for 55 minutes and then covered with foil and added another 15 (for 1 hour 10 minutes total) since other reviews said that it could be uncooked in the middle.   PERFECT!!!  If I had not covered with foil, it surely would have been overdone on top.
I filled a gallon freezer bag with half of this amazing bread and we pull a couple out at a time to defrost for a fresh snack.  
I LOVE banana bread, and will not ever make any other recipe!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread is an easy and tasty treat. I halved the recipe and used canola oil in place of butter. When baking I think it helps to use a higher temp but if you use common sense with your temp and time, and check it 3/4 of the way through it should be easy to end up with properly baked loafs. All in all, this may be one of my favorite banana bread recipes.

THE BEST banana bread ever!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe after adjusting, not the way it is written.  3c. of sugar is too much, I used 2c.  I added one more egg, in leu of the 1c. sugar.  I used 2 1/4c. all-purpose flour and 2 1/4c. whole wheat flour.  This recipes made 4 9x5 loaf pans when baked at 350 degrees for 45 minutes.  Cover the loaves with tin foil for last 15 min. to avoid over browning.  Be sure to grease the pan.  Turns out very moist!

text:
This is the banana bread recipe I have been searching for! I love the banana bread from Starbucks, and can never get mine taste as good. This totally does it! It is sweet, rich and moist. The only changes I made were adding some cake spice from Penzey's and using two 5 x 9 in loaf pans instead of the smaller pans. I baked it at 300 for 1 1/2 hours and covered the loaves halfway through the baking time with foil so they wouldn't get too brown. Amazing stuff!!!

userID:
4885842
Display Name:
MKA
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best banana bread recipe I've tried (and I've tried a lot).  Changes I made: I halved the recipe; used one whole egg plus one egg white to equal 1 1/2 eggs; used 1 cup of sugar; baked for 1 hr 15 min.  PROS: 1.  The sour cream does give it a more dense texture but it also imparts more moisture.   2.  The flavor is light but complex with the cinnamon, sour cream and vanilla. 3.  It browns beautifully with a nice, crisp top.  I realize this is a personal preference. 4.  Not too sweet  but I did use one cup of sugar instead of the 1 1/2 that it asked for  CONS: 1.  I halved the recipe thinking I only wanted 2 loaves but after loading the first pan I realized that the two loaves would be very short, so I put all the batter into one 7X4 pan.  It rose impressively and looked appetizing! I don't think the recipe should suggest 4 loaves, but when made as written should be 2 loaves.  However, my one loaf did take 1 hr and 15 minutes to bake. 2.  The cinnamon sugar dusting made the edges overly sweet for me, but my 3 teenagers loved the 'chewy' sides.  I will try the recipe without the sugar dusting. 3.  I would NOT add the dry ingredients individually to the wet.  FIrst, mix the dry ingredients in a bowl and add in bulk to the wet, then MIX ONLY TO COMBINE.  There will be some specks of white flour but no clumps of white flour.  Do not mix til smooth;  DO NOT overmix or the bread will be tough.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This banana bread recipe IS better than others. I'm usually not a big fan of banana bread or muffins. I made this for my children. I have to say it was GREAT! The sour cream cuts that "sweet" taste that most banana breads have. This is not overly sweet. I halved the recipe, used two eggs, baked these at 325 for about 40-45 mins and followed the rest of the recipe (of course where the recipe says 3 cups of sugar you have to change that when you halve the recipe). I made muffins and a small bread with the left over batter. (I over filled the tins a little because someone else said theirs didn't rise much. Mine rose fine. Maybe I used a 'little' extra soda.) I did separate wet from dry ingredients and just folded them together as to not over-stir them. The result was some very moist, wonderful muffins and bread. These had great texture as well. I had no need for any kind of topping. I did cinnamon and sugar the tins and probably added a little extra cinnamon to my batter- I eyeballed it. Wonderful~ the sour cream just does it! Great recipe!

text:
I've made this recipe many many times and it never fails to amaze me. I made it again just yesterday and here are the modifications I made.  - Used 6oz greek yogurt and 10oz activia yogurt instead of sour cream as I had none at home - Used 5 long bananas - Measured out all the dry ingredients into one bowl so I wouldn't forget any of them, before proceeding to mix the sugar and butter - Used Smart Balance instead of butter - Used 1.5 cups natural cane sugar and 1 cup brown sugar so it wasn't too sweet - Spooned half the mixture into a mini loaf pan and a 9-inch loaf pan, and added 1/2 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips and 1/2 cup cranberries to the remaining half of the mixture before spooning into another mini loaf pan and a 9-inch loaf pan - Recipe yielded 2 9-inch loaves and 2 mini-loaves - Baked at 325F for 1hr 10mins  It was absolutely delicious! Thank you for the recipe.

IT MAKES 4 LOAVES!!  Just had to say that since I didn't read that part in advance.  haha  I only have 2 loaf pans so now I cut the recipe in half (I tried buying four 7x3 but haven't found them yet) *** Anyway this is delicious!! I also adjust the baking time due to my pan size and go with the tried and true toothpick test but it's usually 1 hour to 1 hr 15min depending.

text:
OMG!  This recipe is SOOO good!  I made a couple of minor changes:  I substituted 1/4 cup of the butter with virgin coconut oil (solid and white, like shortening); I added 2 TBS of banana liqueur, and 4 TBS of dark rum.  This made the mixture a little looser, so I added another 1/4 cup of flour.  I also decreased the sugar by 1/2 cup.  Baking time increased a little, so I kept checking every 10 minutes after 1 hour, and it took another 30 minutes.  The bread came out super moist and delicious!  I recommend this recipe to anyone, with or without my changes.  SO GOOD!

text:
Good, not great. The ratio of bananas and butter to flour and sugar is lean and I didn't think the results were outstanding.  I've another recipe that has more intense and moist banana and butter volume (and hence, flavors) with brown sugar lending caramel undertones.  BTW, for any banana bread recipe, try using your electric mixer to whip the bananas for a more even, moist texture (they really liquefy)

text:
Delicious and Sooo moist, but not to moist. i used a topping from a different recipe and it was perfect, here is the recipe:  1/2 cup cold butter, cut into small pieces 1 cup all-purpose flour 1/2 cup packed brown sugar 2 teaspoons ground cinnamon 1 cup quick cooking oats 1 cup chopped pecans   Mix all ingredients in a bowl until it crumbles. set aside until bread is ready to bake.  sprinkle the top of each loaf with one forth of the topping.  Use the pecans (or walnuts) instead of the walnuts in the banana bread recipe

This is a wonderful banana bread! I made 8 mini-loaves in 325 degree oven for 45 minutes. They turned out beautiful with the cinnamon crumbs that I made: 1/3 C brown sugar, 3 Tbs all-purpose flour; 1 tsp ground cinnamon; 1/2 C walnuts; and 1 1/2 Tbs butter. I will definitely make this again!

This was really good but mine fell in the middle after an hour even though a toothpick came out clean. After fully cooling I see it fell because it looks not done... this was my fault and next time I will cook it longer. I cut the recipe in half because I didn't need 4 loaves and I didn't have enough bananas for it. I also didn't have the small bread pans (7x4) mine are all 8.5x4 (standard size). I always have left over sour cream so this was a great way to use it up plus my husband loves banana bread. As usual I added extra walnuts - 1 cup is never enough for him! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This bread really WOW all of us! I halved the recipe to make 2 loaves and generally followed directions as stated, except reduced sugar to ¾ cup, used spatula to mix in flour instead of using an electric mixer to produce a more "bready" texture as per someone's suggestion and increased oven temperature to bake 325 degrees. My bread turned out to be super-moist and delicious; all thanks to the sour cream called for in the recipe. All of us really enjoyed this wonder breakfast bread and we especially love the crunchy crust!

Turned out FANTASTIC!

text:
I had 6 overripe bananas in the refrigerator yelling at me to do something with them and when I stumbled across this recipe I was finally able to silence them. The flavor is this bread was amazing! It was fluffy, had a crusty top, the perfect amount of cinnamon and vanilla, and almost creamy with the sour cream...almost. My only complaint was that it was a bit too sweet. So now I usually omit the 1/4 cup of sugar and just take that much away from the 3 cups of sugar and use that along with the additional cinnamon to dust the pans. Very good recipe; one of the best banana breads I’ve ever had! I'd give this 4 and 1/2 stars if I could, but I'll be nice and give 5 instead.

WOW! My husband was sent home with a banana nut loaf earlier this month by a relative. We ate it but both agreed that this was NOT the best we'd had. So since I ALWAYS have bananas that sit and sit until they land in the garbage, I decided to try a loaf myself. Well THANK YOU! this made a wonderful snack. First of all, I am high altitude and I made no changes for that with no problems at all. I made 1 5X9 loaf, baking at 325 for 1hr 15min,  I used fat free sour cream, and Also I used 3 and 1/2 bananas( a little more than a 5X9 called for).  Otherwise I followed this recipe to the T and it turned out great.

This was a fantastic recipe. I followed the directions to the "T" and all four turned out wonderful. I brought a loaf to my good friends house to share and they both LOVED it. Asked for the recipe right away. The only thing that I would do to put a lil pop in there is add chocolate chips! This is something my mother did growing up, love it! FYI fluff chocolate chips in the flour before you add it to the rest of the mixture..this prevents then from sinking to the bottom of the pan:) happy baking:)

AWESOME! I only make for holidays because it is like eating cake. I followed ther recipe exactly and then did a topping of 1 cp. brown sugar, 6 tbsp. softened butter, 2/3 cp. walnuts, 1 cp. flour and 2 tsp. sugar. I had to bake mine for 1 hour and 45 minutes at 300. I usually wrap 2 loaves in foil and then put in freezer bags and freeze for special occasions. It tastes just as good after freezing and this recipe makes such a large amount, it's nice to have leftovers.

Wow! This is the most perfect banana bread ever!   This is my first time making it so I used the full amount of sugar and did not substitute with apple sauce so that I have a basis.  I did make the crumbly topping which I use for the zucchini bead.   I cooked at 325 for 1 hr 10 minutes.  I added a dash of nutmeg.  I did not need a blender at any point as others have mentioned they did. I just made sure the butter was soft and used a spatula to "cream" together with the sugar.  Fabulous! Will make again and again!

text:
I love this recipe!!! My husband says it's the best banana bread he's ever had!!! I made just a few changes, although I am sure it would have been perfect the other way as well! I used 8 oz. fat free sour cream and 8 oz. light sour cream. I also used 1 cup  white sugar, 1 cup brown sugar, and 1 cup Splenda. I added a dash of nutmeg as suggested by another reviewer. I split between 3 pans- since that is what I had. Baked at 320 degrees, and checked after 45 min. One of them was already done, so keep an eye on it!! I also covered with tin foil, as another reviewer suggested, towards the end of the time, so it was not to dark. I love this bread! It is wonderful!! Thank you!!!

text:
According to one of the helpful reviews, I halved recipe and made two 7 1/2" x 9" loaves and baked at 325 degrees for 1 hr 10 mins. I agree that you can't really make the butter and sugar in the beginning "cream." I think this has something to do with the problem of this recipe. I even hand-mixed the flour in to create a denser, bread-like consistency. I didn't achieve anything close to "bread." Like some other reviewers, the consistency I got was more of a cake. After letting them cool, I could barely get them out of the pan and ended up with something like crumbly cake. Barring all that, I still gave it 2 stars because for all its problems, somehow it still tasted pretty good - for cake.

text:
if there was a 10-star rating here, i'd select that. this was so  good that i made it to give away to family and friends for Christmas. I love to cook but baking is my Waterloo. But follow this recipe to a T and it is fool-proof. Actually, even if the bananas are not super ripe, still came out fantastic! Starbucks has their version of this called Banana Walnut Loaf...uggh, nothing compared to this---at all. Thanks for recipe! It's almost unfair for me to take the credit when i hear the ooohs and aaahs. Oh, i know it sounds weird, but i love mixing sweet and salty, so i always pair this with Doritos chips Verde Salsa flavor...just for me :-) --- to DLPALMA: not sure why yours did not turn out right. I've made this twice already, the 2nd time, i did 2 batches, baked them all together, added like 15 mins for each batch and it came out perfect. Could it be the settings of your oven? Or if you used electric or gas oven. I have gas which i think is even more tricky. Also, hopefully you did not use a bigger loaf pan that what was required. I'm thinking the density of the loaf is also important. Baking is precise which is why i'm not too fond of it because i'm an eye-baller. So this one, i followed exactly. It was fantastic!

text:
I made this recipe the other day and it was SO GOOD! I added a couple shakes of nutmeg, 1/4 tsp of ground cloves, about a tsp. of lemon juice and 1/2 tsp of ground cinnamon. I didn't melt the butter because I have never heard of baking banana bread without creaming the butter and sugar. I also did not leave my bananas sliced, I mashed them because banana chunks just don't do well when baked in a bread. This is now my favorite banana bread recipe, I can't wait for my bananas to get nice and ripe so I can make more!

I make this again and again and again. The only change is that I add a couple handfuls of fresh or frozen blueberries (whatever is available). People ask for this bread, my girlfriends and I usually keep some on hand for coffee talk.

text:
Not too long ago, my boyfriend mentioned something about liking Banana Nut Bread.  Seeing as food is the key to someone’s heart, I decided to go one an extensive search.  I barreled though baking books, performed scientific experiments, graphed my findings from taste tests with chimpanzees, and even hunted down relatives of the late Betty Crocker.  – Well, close.. I Googled “Banana Nut Bread“ and came across this very recipe.  Shh.  No one has to know. :o)

My friend and her husband were having a large group of people over helping her move and unpack into their new home, so I decided that this was my chance to get my bake on and test my skills.

I made a few changes.  1) I added a dash or two of both ginger and nutmeg. 2) I used 7 bananas because the first three weren’t from the same bunch and appeared a little smaller. 3) I used the crumb topping suggested by other reviewer. 4) I used both walnuts and pecans. 5) I first toasted the nuts on a baking sheet in the oven at 350 degrees for ten minutes, and then chopped them after they cooled. 6) I used more nuts than the recipe called for. 7) Since the recipe didn’t specify salted or unsalted butter, I went ahead and used salted, but only used ¼ teaspoon when adding my dry ingredients. 8) I used a standing mixer for this recipe, which resulted in a more cake-like consistency, which isn’t a bad thing. 9) I used two 11¾ x 5½ x 3¼ Hefty EZ Foil Loaf Pans, sprayed them with butter-flavored Pam and coated with the cinnamon-sugar mixtu

text:
Like many other reviewers, I was convinced my mom's banana bread recipe was the best.  But, I had to try this one because of the sour cream--and, this one wins hands down.  The cinnamon-sugar crust is such a great idea, and the texture is perfect.  For those wondering how to make this with normal loaf pans (mine are 8 x 4), the full recipe fits in 2 of these, but I put some cookie sheets underneath because I was afraid the dough would spill over.  It got close, but never ran over.  The loaves were very pretty.

text:
This bread is awesome!!  I will make this again and again! 
I always use mostly whole wheat flour as I did this time.  I would cut the sugar next time, though, but that's just me - don't like it too sweet.

I also followed some recommendations from SaraLady19.  For instance, I halved the recipe.  Baked the 2 loaves at 325 for 1 hr. 10 mins.  Made her crumb topping for one of the loaves. (I halved: 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup flour, 2 TBS butter, 1 tsp. cinnamon, and chopped walnuts).

text:
Great recipe! I cut the sugar to 2 cups because of using large, very ripe bananas. I also used the mini pans (approx. 6 x 3.5) and baked them for 65 minutes. I was able to make 9 mini loaves, (& baked them all at once!) putting 1 cup of batter in each. After easily removing them from the pans, I placed them on their sides on a wire rack to cool. They'll make great gifts!

I used 2% plain yogourt instead of sour cream, since I made it for myself to have as an everyday snack.  I halved the recipe and only used 1 cup of sugar.  I don't like an extra-sweet bread.  I made two small loaves.  I did not add cinnamon, but only nutmeg and extra vanilla, which I believe gives it a much smoother taste.

text:
This one replaces mom's recipe. Sorry Mom! I didn't add nuts and I replaced the cinnamon with pumpkin pie spice. Also..I used 10 or 11 very ripe bananas ( I bought a bag of them at the grocery store for 50 cents!)and reduced the sugar by 1/2 cup to counter the sweetness of the bananas. Other reviewers are not kidding! This makes A LOT of batter. I ended up mixing it in a giant stock pot because it was overflowing my mixer bowl before I added the flour and bananas! Very good crust and appearance. I'm wrapping it in green saran wrap and giving it away as Christmas presents. Thank you!

text:
I was really skeptical about trying another banana bread recipe since I thought I had found the one, but after trying this one, I'll never use another recipe unless I have to (I don't always have sour cream). This bread was so moist and creamy. I halved the recipe, but used 2 eggs (didn't want to throw away half an egg!), I also used 2 tsp of baking soda instead of one to compensate for the extra egg. Also, I like brown sugar so I used 1/4 c. of it. Loved, loved, loved this banana bread!

text:
The banana bread was moist and tasty.  However as another reviewer warned, it was ALOT of batter.  Also, the finished bread was not all that attractive. My husband was hesitant to try it because it didn't look appealing but he agreed that it had a good taste.  I expected that cinnamon sugar coating to give it a crust but it actually made the bread kinda wet.  I gave this recipe 4 stars because I prefer the recipe I use from Betty Crocker using buttermilk, which has a better taste, less work and less batter.  I'll try the Creamy Banana Bread recipe with cream cheese next just to compare.

city:

country:
None
text:
Great recipe, both the family and friends truly enjoyed this banana bread.  Update:  I halved the recipe and made about 11 jumbo muffins.  It took about 25-30 minutes to cook.  Update 2: If halving the recipe use 2 eggs and 4 bananas.  At half the recipe it will make 12 regular size muffins and 6 jumbo muffins.  The regular muffins cooked in 28 minutes and the jumbo muffins cooked in 30 minutes.  I would start checking the muffins about 3 minutes before the time I have listed here.  Update 3: I halved the recipe, it made 3 regular size muffins and one 9x5 loaf.  The muffins cooked in 20 minutes and the loaf cooked in about 1hour and 10-15 minutes.  Also, I didn't throughly read the recipe and I did not cream the sugar with the butter.  Instead I mixed the butter in with the bananas and the other liquid ingredients.

text:
I have been searching for the ultimate banana bread...and I think I've found it!  I made some changes to the recipe to suit my family's tastes, but overall, I think the changes are minimal.  We don't care for cinnamon or nuts in our banana bread, so I left that part out and included instead, 2 cups chocolate chipits.  I also only used 2 cups sugar, which was plenty sweet and swopped out one cup of flour for 1 cup of oats, trying to make them a little healthier after adding 2 cups chocolate!  Also, instead of making loaves, I made muffins, (got 30 good sized ones) baked at 300 for about 30-35 min.  This recipe is the bomb, thanks for sharing!

text:
I made this tonight. I had 5 medium ripe bananas and 1 large regular banana on hand.
This came out wonderful! I was able to get 3 lg loaves and 4 mini loaves. I just bought the disposable foil loaf pans from Walmart and set them on a cookie sheet since they are kind of flimsy. I did lightly spray PAM into the pans before I did the cinnamon sugar coating. This is better than my mother in laws recipe.And I will bake this from now on. I was concerned with what another reviewer said about "to much sour cream" but honestly It diddnt taste at all tangy to me. Just delish! I do like more of a banana flavor, but that could be because my 1 banana wasnt fully ripe. I guess you could always throw in some banana extract or an extra small ripe banana. I plan on giving my mini loaves out to the neighbors. Thanks for a great recipe.

I have found a new banana bread recipe!  It was so flavorful and moist.  Other recipes use oil to provide the moist texture and sometimes have an oily taste. text:
I've tried many different recipes for banana bread and think this one is something special.  The sour cream makes it very moist and it has lots of banana flavor.  Sprinkling the pans with cinnamon sugare was something new and I think it added a little something.  I didn't have any butter so I used 1/2 cup applesauce and 2 T of oil.  I scaled the recipe to 22 servings to get it to 4 bananas (what I had on hand) and 2 eggs.  Bake time was perfect.  The only suggestion I have is to cut back a little on sugar.  It is plenty sweet and I don't think it would hurt it to scale back a little.

I have tried several recipes and this one was the best. Even my "my moms is the best" husband loved it! I altered it a little, I cut the recipe in half, used 1/2 cup of butter instead of what would have been half, used 2 eggs, and 4 bananas because mine were only a little brown. I made 2 loaves, one was 8", the other was 8 1/2" the larger loaf took 15 min. longer and I added nuts and chocolate chips to that one. My family loved the cinnamon on the top and sides. I will use this recipe for holiday gifts and for our family recipe.

Great recipe! I made it yesterday with bananas and sour cream. Today I made it with 3 cups of pureed sweet potatoes in place of the bananas, buttermilk in place of the sour cream, and 1/2 tsp. ginger, 1/4 tsp. cloves and 1/8 tsp. nutmeg in addition to the cinnamon. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very flavorful recipe.  I agreed with other reviewers, 3 cups is a lot of sugar.  I reduced it to 1 3/4 and it was just right.  I substituted unflavored homemade yogurt that I always have handy for the sour cream.  I also used frozen bananas which I also keep in supply.  The yogurt and thawed bananas made for a very runny batter.  I got 6-6" x 3" mini loaves and some pans overflowed.  Next time, I will reduce the yogurt to  1.5 cups from 2.  I reduced fat by using parchment paper to line the pans instead of greasing with butter.  Then, I used the cinnamon sugar for topping instead of lining the pan.  It made the top look pretty, shiny and crackly  when done.  The loaves looked underdone after 1 hour so I baked an extra 10 minutes.  Next time, I might try to bake at 325 F.  As promised, the bread is melt-in-mouth moist. I like the mini loaves because I can freeze what I don't use right away to keep it fresh.  I will definitely be making this again.

text:
I made this just today and it came out perfect! I think I've baked about 3 things in my lifetime (just never got into baking) but this recipe was super easy and I read the reviews and changed it up a little. I made the whole recipe but used 5 very ripe bananas instead of 6. I also used only 2 cups of white sugar and replaced the 3rd cup with 1 cup of brown sugar. I noticed that almost everyone baked at 325 degrees so I did that for an hour, then covered my loaf with aluminum foil and baked it for an additional 15 minutes. It came out perfect! I had enough for 2 loaves in a 9x5 inch loaf pan. The remaining batter I used a muffin tin and made banana muffins. I baked at 400 degrees for 18 mins and they turned out perfect! Super yummy and moist and I'll definitely  be making this again!

country:

text:
Best banana bread recipe I have tried. Everyone loved it. It's moist, has a wonderful texture and flavor, not overly sweet. I think the secret is the sour cream. Yummy! I sprinkled the top of each loaf with a combo of finely chopped nuts, coarse sugar and cinnamon before baking.  I substituted pecans for the walnuts.   I had to bake at about 335  degrees and for about an hour and a half in my oven which always seems to need more time than recipes usually state. But I think 300 degrees is unrealistic for this recipe.
This recipe makes four 3x7 loaves. I wrapped the extra loaves in foil and put them in the refrigerator for a couple days. What do you know? Three more banana bread occasions came up and I was prepared!  The refrigerated loaves were fresh and perfect even after 3 days in the fridge. So now as I type, I'm baking another batch for a community potluck and for work. 
I'm a beginning baker who loves to try easy recipes and bring my experiments to work. This recipe fit my repertoire.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was an excellent banana bread recipe.  I like that it recognized spices like cinnamon add to the taste.  I also added nutmeg, cloves and pumpkin pie spice to the flour mix.  I think I will lower the sour cream content next time though.

For those with temperature issues, I would suggest looking at your loaves about 5-10 minutes after they have been in the oven.  If the center is rising faster than the edges your temperature is TOO LOW.  If your edges are rising faster than your center, your temperature is TOO HIGH.  Adjust your temp accordingly and then look at it 5-10 minutes later to see if the top is now flat rather than uneven.  

With people altering sugar content,  sour cream and baking soda amount, number of bananas, etc, it's best to just monitor the bread for a bit in the beginning to get the temp right.  It just so happens 300 degrees for 1 hour 5 minutes was right for my two loaves (half recipe).  I use the skewer coming out clean method to determine doneness.

Those with gooey centers that were inedible but the sides were done, your heat was too high.  

That said, I think I will try Martha Stewart's recipe next.  She doesn't have cinnamon in it so I will add that but I do think her proportions of sour cream etc is more along what I like.  She cooks it at a higher temp and I like that too because I like the "done" taste.  Maybe it's the combo of a lot of sour cream and the low temp but this recipe's bread sat "heavy" in my tummy.  Still was tasty though!

Followed the recipe exactly and this came out perfectly.  The only thing I can add is a tip.  The bread will rise more than twice the depth of the raw batter as it sits in the pan so plan accordingly.  I like a lot of crust so the huge bloom over the top of the pan height wasn't a problem, at all.  Just be aware that it does rise a bit more than usual for banana bread recipes.

text:
Amazing and Easy!  I give this bread away regularly because I have a lot of bananas go bad.  Everyone at family holidays expects me to bring it.  I never really indulge that it has sour cream in it.  To me that's kind of a "Secret ingredient".  I have had great success making this recipe a Gluten Free dessert.  I just substituted all-purpose GF flour blend for the regular and added 3 tsp of xanthan gum to the full batch.  No one has ever known ths difference.  And I like to make this bread a tad healthier than the recipe.  Natural sugar is so much better for you than "white death", so I keep all the bananas, maybe sometimes add one or two and cut the "white" sugar down to 1 3/4 cups.  My husband loves sugar and quickly steals an entire loaf for himself when they are done, so my guess is that the white sugar is not missed.

text:
I will tell you that I always make the recipe as directed the first time. The second, I tweek, the third, I make final changes.
I have made this bread almost a hundred times over the past 2 years. I became motivated when I told someone I make raw desserts. He asked if I made banana bread; I did not. My challenge began. By the 7th or 8th batch, I began to make the bread Gluten-free and vegan. I subbed Bob's Mill all-purpose flour, tofutii sour cream, apple sauce (another recipe I got from here: Slow cooked spiced apple sauce), and 8 bananas instead of stated in recipe. One extra because, why not, and the 8th, I cut into diced pieces and throw in at end of mixing stage. I cut sour cream down because of extra bananas. The tub is 12 oz, I use about 6-7oz. I had started to sell my bread. I love it! It is amazing! Any questions, please let me know. (I'm not vegan, I just wanted to make it safe for everyone :-)

1/2 cup less sugar,

1/2 teaspoon of allspice,

text:
Loved it! Made recipe as written minus the nuts and only used 5 bananas since they were pretty large. My pans were larger than stated, I used 1 9x5 pan and 3 8x4 pans, and had plenty of batter to fill all four. I baked at 300 for 75 minutes. I checked at 60 but they were still wet in the middle. An extra 15 minutes and they came out great. The tops weren't burnt and the middles were cooked through. This was my first attempt at banana bread and this is the recipe I will be the one I will continue using.

text:
This was delicious! Followed the recipe EXACTLY (but cut the servings in half since I only had 3 ripe bananas)and it was so moist and light. The best banana bread Ive ever made. I strongly suggest that the walnuts be added if you like walnuts at all; they added a flavorful crunch. And dusting the pan with cinnamon sugar gave it a sweet thin crust. BUT one warning; unless Ive got the wimpiest, most contrary oven ever, when I set it at 300 degrees it just wasn't enough to cook it in one hour. After testing it at one hour I had to add another 25 minutes before it was done. But it was worth it....

text:
We have nut allergies in the family, so I make this sans nuts.  I also use the topping SaraLady19 recommended - I think this is the best banana bread we've had.  Easy to make with the KitchAid mixer - this recipe makes two large loaves and two small loaves.

Update:  Have made this three times more, again sans nuts but with SaraLady19's topping.  I took two loaves to the office - to a person, everyone said it was the best banana bread they had ever had.  I've only favorited some of the dozens of recipes I've tried on allrecipes.com and reviewed few - this one tops all.

text:
I gave this a 5 star but I am rating it according to my alterations. First of all, I used 2 1/2 cups white sugar & 1/2 cup brown sugar instead of 3 cups white sugar. I reduced the sour cream down to 8 ounces instead of 16 ounces. The bread remained moist but not wet or under baked in the centre & I did not have problems like a lot of others said they experienced. I added 1/2 cup raisins to my batter. Everything else I kept the same. The next time I think I will leave out the sugar / cinnamon dusting for the pans, for me it is just a little too sweet & I feel it distracts from the overall flavour of the bananas. All in all this is a really good recipe. A keeper. Happy baking!!!

text:
Made as written with 2 cups of walnuts and it was excellent!! This will be my go to for banana nut bread / muffins and I have tried many a recipe. I made muffins with a crumb topping for work, this recipe yields 36 muffins with the additional nuts bake at 325 for 25 mins. Perfection!!

Crumb mixture: 
1 1/2 c oats, 2/3 c brown sugar, 1/4 c melted butter, 1/4 c chopped walnuts. Mix until crumbled top muffins prior to baking.

text:
I made HALF a batch into 6 jumbo muffins and had enough leftover to fill a mini-loaf pan. Cooking time for these was 25 min. I used two eggs and also added 2 TBSLP of ground flaxseed. I cut back as I always do on the sugar by about 1/4 cup (used some brown sugar, too). I combined the dry ingredients (except cinnamon...recipe had it going in with the eggs...sure it would be fine to add with other dry ingred). A little low on sour cream so topped that off with plain Greek yogurt. I did not add nuts into the batter but did make a streusel topping to which I added them. I tried something different and added about six coarsely chopped, mini dark chocolate peanut butter cups from Trader Joe's. Oh my...just enough to put these over the top! I highly recommend this recipe! Thanks Esther!

text:
I made a third of this recipe and used my mini muffin tin. A third of this recipe fills one mini muffin tin with 24 spaces. Fill the spaces just about to the top. In addition to cinnamon, I added a healthy dose of ground cloves and ground nutmeg, both of which go nicely with banana. I also used two and a half bananas, or use two large bananas. I baked at 350 degrees for 18 minutes.

text:
FANTASTIC RECIPE. If you don't have allergies to any ingredients, this is the ONLY banana bread recipe. There is a reason it's rated so highly. It made me feel like a baking queen when I made it. I cut it in half and used one pan. I also had sprinkled cinnamon and sugar on the top to make a light crisp for the top, and I had to substitute baking powder for soda. Still phenomenal. I did two eggs instead of one and a half, and I guessed on the sour cream because I had already gotten into it. Also my cooking time because I used one large pan instead of the minis was 1hr 15min. Good luck. Enjoy.

text:
I've made this several times and always get told it's the best ever!  Once you make it this way, there's no going back. 

Because we have a convection oven, I bake it at 325° for 1-1.25 hrs. I think the bananas make the difference in cooking time, but I could be wrong. The recipe is great as is, but I add 1tsp of nutmeg and 1 1-2 tsp baking powder.  Truly, you'll make a banana bread better than your grandma, so be prepared to face the consequences!

text:
I made some changes based on what I had in the house. I was short 1/4 of butter, so I used mayo. I am sure I added in extra bananas, since I used whatever I had (probably 7 or 8), thew in vanilla and cinnamon without measuring. Sugar was half white, half turbinado (Sugar in the Raw). I ended up doing 2 brownie pans of bread, one tray of 24 cupcakes, and one tray of muffin tops. At 300, muffin tops were done in 30 min and muffins in about 40/45. Rest were good at about 70 minutes.  They tasted great. I love sour cream in anything, though! I added about a cup or so of chocolate chips, also. I am sure I will make it again for Thanksgiving and Christmas time and will change it up based on what I have in the house.

text:
I was a bit sceptical of this recipe as I have made banana bread before and they have always turned out terrible. But I had sour cream and bananas to use up so I thought i'd give it one last try. I'm so glad I did. This turned out wonderfully well. I followed the recipe exactly except I only used 5 bananas (I only had 5 on hand) and 1 teaspoon of ground cinnamon ( I don't like strong cinnamon tastes). I did do a double take when i saw the temperature setting, 300 seemed a bit low but I set it at that anyway, and yep they rose well. I had to leave them in there about 10 mimutes longer than stated though. They looked fantastic when I took them out of the oven and smelt great. I was getting ready for the dissapointing taste but no, it tasted great too. I still can't believe I have found a banana bread recipe I like and turned out so well. Thank you Esther for the fantastic recipe!

Display Name:
Miki Crespo
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1662201.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hard to rate when I changed the recipe so much but it came out great. I halved the recipe and wanted to make it a little more healthy. 
Two eggs, 3/4 cup of sugar and a dollop of molasses, 1 cup of white flour and 1/2  cup of whole wheat flour, 1/4 stick of butter only and 1/4 cup of applesauce. Added a handful each of ground flax and whole flax and chia seeds. Bumped the spices way up and added cloves, nutmeg and allspice. All other ingredients were just halved. Used reduced fat sour cream. Used almonds as it was the only nuts I had.  At 1 hour and 20 minutes, I turned off the oven and let it rest in there for another 10-15 minutes.  This banana bread came out so moist and slightly dense, it was more like a cake. Even better after a day in the fridge. I was afraid of how long it was taking to cook at that low heat but it came out perfect. I froze one and can't stop nibbling at the other one!

text:
I made this recipe  with the exact amount of everything specified,  except I put in 1 tsp cinnamon,  1/2 tsp ground cloves,  and 1/2 tsp of nutmeg instead of 2 tsp of cinnamon. I also think it could use 2 tsp of salt instead of 1. I made it in Reynolds 2 1/2 inch foil baking cups sitting on a cookie sheet at 325 for 30 minutes and they came out perfect. I also dusted the walnuts with a cinnamon sugar and butter and just put them on top before baking instead of in the batter.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Took the advice of others and cut the white sugar to 1-1/2 cups and added 1/2 cup brown sugar.  Where we live we have Apple Bananas growing everywhere, so that was the type of banana I used.  They are smaller than the regular bananas you get in the food store so I used all I had on hand which was 8.  I thought I had plenty of sour cream but was a bit short of the 16 ounces.  So to make up for the lesser amount of "wet" ingredients I added 1/3 cup of coconut cream that I had left over in the fridge.  Sprinkled the tops of the three loaves (which is all I got out of the recipe)with cinnamon sugar.  Oh boy, this was so good when it was warm and so good the next morning toasted and buttered.  Moist and fluffy and not too sweet.  Going to try again with the next batch of bananas but this time I am going to add lilikoi or guava to it since they are going off right now, too.

text:
I absolutely loved this recipe!  I have been looking for a great banana bread for a long time, and I had one recipe I used a long time.  That recipe pales in comparison.  I followed it exactly.  My husband is raving about it right now.  He ate a full mini-loaf.  I did use small loaf pans instead and made 5 small loaves with a 2/3 recipe.  I only had 4 bananas.  Yeah!  Great recipe.  I don't know why people think they need to change recipes and add this or that.  This one is perfect the way it is, and I agree that using fat-free or low-fat sour cream won't work the same way because the fat in the sour cream is to replace oil, which is in every banana bread recipe.  I would rather put in sour cream, real stuff with all of the fat, than add oil to a recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This banana bread is simply the best.  It is so moist and flavorful it reminded me of my grandma's.  As I am diabetic I substituted half of the sugar with Splenda® and half with dark brown sugar.  I think I will cut the total sugar amount down to 2 cups as it was plenty sweet.  I did increase the baking temperature to 325 as suggested by other reviewers, and it came out perfect though it did take a bit longer than stated.  I think this is a reflection of my oven's accuracy though as the bread did not get overly browned.  I will definitely make this again.  As this recipe makes a lot, it will be great for making multiple smaller loaves for gift giving, like at Christmas time.  My family is nutty but don't care to eat them, so I added raisins to part of the batter and made muffins out of it.  They grabbed them as they ran out the door.  A huge hit with the entire family.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3542952.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I got very frustrated making this bread, and I thought I'd never make it again. However, once it came out of the oven, the bread is so good--moist and just sweet enough. I'll have to make it again! However, my very large mixing bowl almost overflowed--I wondered if my bananas were too large. I had so much batter! I used four 6X2 loaf pans and then figured I would put the extra batter in 6 muffins. I ended up filling 18 muffins and not having room in my oven for all of them. I started cooking them at 300 degrees, but I began to question the temp and so checked the reviews and decided to turn it up to 325. The loaves took 1 hr, while the muffins took 30 min at 325. Next time, I will make 2 large loafs instead. :)

text:
Fantasic recipe!  This has replaced the banana bread recipe from my grandmother that I used my whole life!  I usually half the recipe to make 2 loaves. I use 2 eggs for 1/2 recipe and increase the flour by 1 cup. I have used both sour cream and fat free plain greek yogurt and the bread turns out great either way. I have used walnuts, pecans and even mini chocolate chips as add ins. It take about 1 hour 15 minutes to bake at 300 degrees in my oven.  It is so delicious!

text:
Made a few substitutions to reduce fat and calories:  Cut recipe in half then used the following: Replaced all sugar with Stevia, replaced 3/4 cup butter with 1 apple (sauced) + 1.5 T butter, 2 eggs, replaced sour cream with Nonfat Greek Yogurt and used 2.5 Cups Whole Wheat flour.  Replaced Walnuts with Pecans.  All other ingredients kept the same.  Baked at 325 for 70 min.  Dusted top with Cinnamon + stevia.  DELICIOUS!!!

text:
While I will try adding sour cream to my banana bread in the future, I won't be utilizing this recipe again. For me, there just was not enough banana flavor, instead there was a lot of sweetness from the amount of sugar. Additionally, the bread was more of a cake consistency rather than being dense like you would expect from a quick bread. I have my own recipe for banana that has never failed but decided to try this one to break out of my routine a little bit. Just wasn't for me...

76
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7589981.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This banana bread is fantastic! Not too sweet and very moist. My family loves it. I cut the recipe in half and made muffins; it was the perfect amount of batter for 12 muffins, filling the cups almost to the top. I baked them at 300 for 30 minutes but I think taking them out at 28 minutes would have been better as they were a little too brown. I changed it a bit since I don't always like to use butter in these kinds of breads. I replaced the butter with applesauce and Stonyfield's low fat french vanilla yogurt in place of the sour cream. Even though I used french vanilla yogurt I still added vanilla. I added about 1/2 tsp nutmeg too. I didn't dust the cups with sugar and cinnamon, I just didn't think it was necessary and I'm glad I didn't. I think it would have been too sweet. I used 3 bananas but I think adding another would be even better.

text:
*** Originally reviewed 2/17/14 ***
This has become my "go to" recipe for the perfect banana nut bread!  I have made it for holidays, to welcome new neighbors and for the kids to devour. It's easy and crazy, yummy.  I like to add frozen cranberries to it; because I love that bite of tang when I eat the finished bread. It's so delicious.

*** Updated 12/30/18 ***
Still wonderful.  Still delicious! My kids love it, their friends love it, their teachers love it, my colleagues love it. 

The only thing I've changed is, I use a whole, fresh bag of washed & dried cranberries (picking out mushy or white ones); I put in half of the cranberries whole & the other half chopped. Also add 1 1/2 cups of chopped walnuts. Sometimes I add a generous dash of nutmeg & same with cloves.

city:

country:
None
text:
I prepared this recipe only to have cream cheese for stead of sour cream. On top of that, about 3 5min into cooking phase, the butter got left in the microwave so, there was no butter or fat content in the mix as well, i added a 4th egg because mine were very small.

I could not stand the melted butter just to get put back into the fridge so, i rued a 1/4 cup of cocoa, about 5 oz of strawberry preserves and a half cup sugar for a topping. I included the rest of the cream cheese left over which was about 3 oz. I set in sauce pan on med heat long enough to DE-crystalise the sugar and melt down the cream cheese. I topped both now cakes once they were cooled enough and it was actually very good and no ingredients were wasted. i never made a banana bread without some fat content be it oil or butter and i have to tell you that the sponginess and moistness was quite impressive despite my mistake of not adding the butter. 

My apologies if in any way i took away from the original author's recipe by sharing my mistake. Cheers!

text:
This is a great recipe! I couldn't find Mom's original recipe. (and over ripe bananas were calling!) I wasn't sure very sure at first when I saw this recipe, (After reading the lower reviews) but you never know unless you try making it yourself! 

The banana bread needed a few more minutes more than an hour, but after it turned out wonderful! There weren't any purple banana globs and the whole bread was evenly cooked. I also made some cream cheese frosting to go with it. Together with frosting and more mild sweetness of the banana bread this recipe was wonderful! 

This was my first time making banana bread without Mom directly helping. If your new to making banana bread like me, this is a great recipe! I will without a doubt use this recipe again. Actually, I plan on making more banana bread very soon! (more bananas calling!)

I modified my flours by using 2 cups oat flour 2 cups regular flour and 1/2 cup ground flaxseed meal. I also found that when using  a regular size loaf pan , the middle was not done , but upon using the mini loaf pans temperature was ok , with an Electric oven , but I used the pampered chef mini loaf stoneware . If you only have the larger loaf pans I would start temp at 325 and check loaves after 45 min of bake time . This is a great recipe though !

This is a great banana bread recipe that lended itself easily  healthy substitutions. I halved the recipe and substituted:
1. 1/4 cup unsweetened applesauce and 2 tbsp butter instead of all butter
2. 8 ounces Chobani Greek yogurt instead of sour cream
And I opted not to sprinkle additional sugar... It has plenty already. I baked four 7x3" loaves on 300f for one hour.

text:
By far the best banana bread recipe I have ever made.  I made very little changes to the recipe.  I used baker's sugar (super fine sugar) instead of regular granulated.  I only had 5 bananas so I did add a tsp of banana flavoring just in case.  A dash of pumpkin pie spice as well.  I made one large loaf, 5 jumbo muffins and 4 mini loaves with the amount of batter.  Everyone loved the sugar and cinnamon crunch on the bottom.  Only thing to note is the bake time is definitely longer than an hour.  It took about 90 minutes for my large loaf and about 45 for my mini loaves and muffins.  But just keep testing and you won't be disappointed!

text:
I looked at the top of my microwave... 6 bananas then I looked in my fridge, 2 tubs of sour cream. I had to use this stuff up, pronto! So, with a bit of searching, I found this recipe. I'll admit, I was thinking "300? That's odd; I usually bake these at 350", but I went ahead. I followed the recipe exactly and popped it in the over for 300. The aroma filled my house quickly and it smelled SO good! After an hour, I opened my oven to find..... a big wet mess. I left it for an additional 15 minutes. Again, a big wet mess. So! I cranked the oven to 350 and covered the breads with aluminum foil to try to minimize burning the tops. Worked great! After 15-25 mins amazing, moist banana bread! But - the texture does remind me more of a cake than a bread and it is very sweet!

text:
I've made this recipe at least 50 times in the past few years.  Today I decided to make it as muffins rather than loaves.  I can't imagine a more tender muffin that these.  The only item I altered in the recipe was to use 1/2 brown sugar AND 1/2 white sugar rather than all white.  Perhaps this had the positive impact on the texture.  Would be great with old-fashioned cream cheese frosting (just a dollop on top)for a dessert too.  I used a large cookie scoop for the muffins and a standard cupcake pan; the recipe yielded 54 perfect muffins.  You won't be disappointed with this recipe.  Everyone I've ever made it for has absolutely adored it!

text:
The most moist banana bread ever! I made these in a pan that made 8 mini-loaves in each pan. I doubled the recipe and it made a lot...32 mini-loaves plus 2 loaf pans. I baked these at 325 and didn't have a problem with them being under-done. Just preference, I cut the sugar to 2 cups per batch and I added 1/2 tsp of nutmeg to the batter. I sprinkled vanilla bean sugar, that I got from a spice store, on the top of the loaves before baking along with some pecans. Delicious! Honestly, it was amazing and very pretty. Personally, I would add even less sugar next time. Could be because of the cinnamon sugar that I dusted the pans with and the vanilla bean sugar on top, but it was still too sweet for me. Overall, excellent recipe that's moist and full of flavor.
