I made this into mini muffins.  Cooked them at 300 for 28 min and they came out great.  I added nutmeg to them and I only had 4 bananas but those were the only changes I made.  I think unless you are feeding a small army, this is a huge recipe.  I will cut it in half next time.  I got 96 mini muffins from it.  The kids, my husband and the guys at his work all loved them.  I don't even care for banana bread that much myself and I liked them.

text:
My boss made this and it was the best ever.  I have been making banana bread for over 40 years and this is the best recipe I have ever tasted.  HOWEVER, when I tried to make it at home, I used very overripe (almost liquid) bananas and it did not work out at all.  The second time I used bananas with lots of brown spots and it was delish!!  If bananas start turning from brown to black, I would not recommend using them.

text:
This was a wonderful recipe and I love it and will continue to use this one! I made two large loaves rather than four small ones. This recipe for me was not done in an hour. After one hour...I put on my timer for 30 more minutes at 325 degrees and they were perfect! (I was sad to see where someone who rated this recipe a one star threw out all four of theirs because it wasn't done). The key is to know your oven and to adjust accordingly...DEfinitely use a toothpick and test after an hour...then add maybe 15 minutes at a time until the toothpick comes out clean! My house smells delicious as it is cooling!

text:
I made one loaf of this bread, so I cut the serving size from 32 to 8. It confused me at the beginning because the directions didn't change, only the ingredients, but after a minute I realized my stupidity. I threw in 2 banana's instead of 1.5 and used a whole egg instead of 3/4 of an egg (because how am I supposed to measure that, lol). It came out well, I had to bake it for an extra 10 minutes. The bread was extremely moist, but not undercooked. In the future I think I'll use the correct amount of bananas.

text:
There's something very odd about this recipe:  when I first tasted it straight out of the oven, I didn't really think it was any more fabulous than any other banana bread recipe I've tried in the past, but I had a tough time refraining from eating the entire loaf then and there!  I made exactly as written, except I don't have any 7x3 pans.  I made the bread in one 9x13 pan and one 9x5 pan, and filled them up even with each other.  The 9x5 cooked in about an hour, and the 9x13 cooked in about 1 hour 5 minutes.  I think that the bread really does need the crumb topping that so many other reviewers were suggesting; it was delicious and moist, but lacking that "wow" factor.

text:
Like everyone here; the best banana bread recipe ever. I normally hate making a new recipe because they always ask for some things I don't have handy. Just so happen I have all the ingredients it calls for. 
I am a rebel in my own right. I almost never follow a recipe. so, here are little things I did.
I only had three babanas at home. I made half the recipe and used a regular loaf pan instead of small loaf pans. Put sour cream more and cut the butter in half. Use half the sugar and substitute the other half with brown sweetener. Baked for 1 hour and 35 mins in the oven. 
The bread was so good. The kids ate almost entire loaf at one sitting. I will be making it again for sure.

text:
LOVED this recipe! I did change a couple of things to make it a bit healthier. I used 1 egg and 2 egg whites rather than 3 whole eggs. I used 2 cups of unsweetened apple sauce instead of the 3 c of sugar and I used fat free greek yogurt rather than sour cream as the local grocery store did not have fat free sour cream. I also did not use any butter. They taste amazing and moist! I did use the sugar and cinnamon to dust the pans and added 1/2 c of chocolate chips :) 
Will definitely make them again!
Mine yielded 3 large loaves and they took 1 hr and 20 mins to bake. 
Thank you for sharing this amazing recipe!

text:
Awesome! I discovered I only had 4 bananas mid mix, so quickly added some banana cream pudding. I made the whole recipe, 2 loafs & 11 large muffins. I used Walnuts & added the crumb topping another review suggested. ~ 1/2 cup packed brown sugar ~ 1/2 cup all-purpose flour ~ 2 or 3 tablespoons butter or margarine ~ 1 teaspoon cinnamon ~ 1/3 cup chopped walnuts. I baked 350 for about 35 minutes for muffins annd 55 for the loafs. Yummy!

country:
None
text:
I made a few changes to this recipe that seemed to work well.  I used 3/4 cup of no sugar added peach flavored applesauce (it doesn't affect the flavor) instead of butter.  I had 4 egg whites, so I used those in place of the eggs.  I cut down to 2 cups of sugar and I think it was plenty sweet.   Lastly, I didn't make the topping or dust the pans with sugar.  I ended up having to bake for about 20 minutes longer because of the changes, but it turned out nicely and you'd never know it was lower in fat.

text:
I butchered this banana bread and it is still great. I was preoccupied and watching a movie when I decided to whip up something sweet. I halved the recipe and did not pay attention so I wound up only using 3 tablespoons of sugar (half of the amount used for dusting the pan DUH).

The bread is still very moist and good. I can only imagine how great it would be if I had done it right.

My bf and I are eating the "butchered" banana bread right now and it is still pretty good! Since it is not very sweet I think it will be good for breakfast with peanut butter.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This had very good taste.  You really can't taste the sour cream.  I made some changes that I often make to recipes without them making any difference to taste in my opinion.  I use 1/2 King Arthur white whole wheat four and half all purpose, 1/2 Splenda 1/2 sugar and I through in about 2 Tbs of ground flax seed.  I also had to half the recipe, I only had 4 bananas.  Technically half the recipe calls for 3 but I used all 4.  I really liked this bread.  It came out lighter/less dense than my traditional recipe and also less moist, which I was looking for.  Obviously the changes I made may have altered the outcome but in my other banana bread recipe they don't. I was looking for a recipe to try that might give me a lighter  result and I think this did.  I also thought this bread was less bitter than my normal recipe.  I usually don't care for banana bread because I find it a little bitter.  I use baking soda without aluminum so that is not the reason for the bitter taste I usually get.  I would make this again and I recommend it.  The only reason I give 4 stars is I think most people like banana bread more moist than mine came out, but again it might be the changes I made.

Thanks for the new banana bread recipe!

text:
A wonderful recipe!  The oven temperature needs to be 325 degrees.  For a healthier alternative, I used a quarter cup of applesauce as a substitute to a quarter cup of better.  My wife did not notice until I told her.  I added a light coating of chopped walnuts to the top of the batter before it went into the oven.  It provides a crunchy topping which I enjoy.  This recipe is a keeper.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-08-15T12:30:29.713
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1037986
Display Name:
OkinawanPrincess
isPro:
False
followersCount:
220
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
513
favoritesCount:
2438
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/661917.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of the best banana breads I've tried in a while. Followed recipe to a "T" and hand mixed everything to combine well.  I used 6 medium size very ripe bananas, mashed up well along with a (16 oz) reduced fat daisy sour cream. Added in some rough chopped walnuts. I don't have any 7x3 inch loaf pans.  I filled up three 9x5 loaf pans (greased) a little more than halfway. I sprinkled a little more cinnamon/sugar on top of the bread right before putting it into the oven. I baked them at 325 degrees for 1hr 20 mins until done. The breads baked up nicely, rising just over the edge of the pan. The top of the bread was nice and brown. The bread is very moist, not dry, soft and flavorful. I think it has to be the sour cream that helps to make it moist on the inside. I could definitely taste and smell the bananas as well as the cinnamon/sugar. The walnuts adds a nice texture to the bread. I love the hint of cinnamon/sugar, nothing was overly sweet, just right for me. The wonderful cinnamon/sugar aroma just filled my house.  Adding the brown sugar crumb topping (from another reviewer) really sounds good. I think I might try that the next time I make this bread. But on its' own, this banana bread is moist and delicious! I am very happy with the way this turned out. thank you esther nelson for sharing this wonderful banana sour cream bread recipe!

text:
Really good.  I halved the recipe & made the healthy substitutions LINDABTX listed in her review.  What I differently from her was to use half honey for the sugar.  I kept the sour cream full fat (it's hard to find natural sour cream in a low fat variety,) but I think that was for the best anyway.  I used 1 egg and 1 egg white for the halved recipe.  FYI, I made mini-loaves and they took 40 min to bake at 325; the full size loaf took an hour.

I had problems with getting these loaves done.  I only have two 2 bread, so I filled a muffin pan and cooked that for 30 minutes at 325 and the loaves for 1 hour and 10 minutes at 325. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3056.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So delicious!  I decided to make this and use up some bananas that were sitting around on the kitchen counter.  I did a few things different than the original recipe: I heated the oven to 350 since I like a nice soft cake-like center and a slightly crispy, toasty brown outside, and this is usually the temperature I use to achieve that; also, I only have one loaf pan so I used a muffin tin, 1 9in round, and my lonely single loaf pan.  I didn't think about quantity until I saw how HUGE the bowl was when everything mixed together.  Glad I had a few different pans on hand!  I filled the muffin pan and put it in first, followed by the 9in round, then the loaf pan.  I left them in the oven for 15 min until the muffins were done and took those out, added another 15 for the round pan to finish cooking and pulled those, and finally another 20 for the loaf pan.  So easy and sooooo good!

None
text:
I halved the recipe and made these into 18 muffins. I used 6 T of butter, 1 c white sugar, 2 eggs, 3 bananas, 1 c sour cream, 1 t vanilla extract, 1 t ground cinnamon, 1/4 t salt, 1 1/2 t baking soda, and 2 1/4 cups flour. Instead of walnuts, I added chocolate chips. I baked them at 300F for 25 minutes. They were perfectly sumptuous!

text:
This banana bread is DEE-LISH!!!  The moist texture makes this bread stand out from all the rest.  I did make a few changes after making it the first time.  First, the original recipe calls for TOO MUCH sugar.  I used 2 cups of ORGANIC RAW sugar.  And I skipped sprinkling the sugar on the pan before adding the batter.  It makes it tastes perfectly well balanced with the sweetness from the ripe bananas.  Also I added a small container of fresh raspberries.  PERFECTO!!!

text:
Best banana bread I've ever had.  I halved the recipe, and following the suggestions of a few other reviewers I cut down on the sugar by a third (still PLENTY sweet) and used about half whole wheat flour instead of all white. I also added 1/2 t. nutmeg (1 t. for a full batch) which adds to an already INCREDIBLE flavor.  This recipe is definitely coming out again. I probably can't review it fairly because of the changes I made, so take that into consideration.

text:
First time banana bread baker. I was skeptical of the amount of mix & the baking temp and turned out to be correct about the time/temp. The amount of mix is matter of personal preference I guess.  The bread was not baked thru at one hour. I left it in much longer. Used 2 small & 1 large loaf pan (*neither* size was cooked thru at 1 hour at 300 degrees).   Might use more bananas for more banana flavor next time. Used 5 large bananas instead of six b/c  of their size, but probably could have used more.  With added baking time, it turned out moist & dense. Very cake-like. I'll experiment with another recipe before making this one again or follow modifications by other, more experienced bakers below.  Gave it 4 stars, b/c I'm inexperienced at Banana bread and want to give it the benefit of the doubt, but I suspect this won't wind up my favorite recipe.

text:
This the BEST Banana Bread I've ever had!  Soft, fluffy, full of Banana flavor and not too sweet.  The only change I made was I omitted all of the cinnamon & didn't add nuts.  I also forgot to sprinkle sugar on the greased pans.  But it is absolutely amazing!  Thank you Esther for sharing this with us!!!

UPDATE:  I have made this Banana Bread TONS of times.  This makes A LOT of bread.  I usually make it in small disposable loaf pans but I have also made it in regular loaf pans.  I spray my pans but do not sprinkle sugar on the inside.  I also recently made it with bananas that were not super brown and ripe and it still came out just as wonderful.  This also freezes very very well which we have done numerous times.  WARNING if you do not add 6 bananas (I never mash mine, just add into my mix in chunks and my kitchen aid breaks them down no problem) you will not get as much banana flavor!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I made this late last night and it really turned out great, except, I didn't know at the time why it had a gel consistency, real moist, but not dry...I watched the video on banana bread making tips and this was the recipe they were making.  My husband and I had halfed the recipe to 16 servings using the conversion tool on this site.  I noticed in the video that the ladies did not use a full 16 oz container of sour cream and they were making a smaller batch as well.  The conversion tool halved everything else, except the sour cream.  We used a full 16oz sour cream and I think that may have been why our bread turned out with a gel consistency.  I think it probably should be 8 oz sour cream when cutting the recipe in half.

text:
I cut this recipe in 1/2 due to the lack of 6 bananas.  I also used 1/2 sour cream and 1/2 banana cream yogurt to kick up the banana flavor.  The dusting of the pans is a wonderful idea giving this bread a sugar-cinnamon crust.  I took this one step further in adding a layer of cinnamon-sugar to the top of the loaf as well.  This forms a thick sugar crust on the top.  The bread is moist and flavorful.  Oh, and I also subbed applesauce in stead of the butter - I almost always do this, and the bread always turns out great.  My husband says this is the best recipe so far.  Thanks!

text:
I got so many compliments on this bread! This is a great recipe. I ran out of white flour and used wheat (about 1 1/2c. wheat and 3 c. white) and I also ran out of white sugar (used 2 c. white sugar and 1 c. brown). I also greased the pans with butter and coated them with flax seeds and then put the batter in the pans, a trick I learned on allrecipes in another recipe, and did not put the extra sugar/cinnamon on top. This bread is excellent and is really moist because of the sour cream. Definitely a do-over!

text:
FABULOUS!  I have been trying banana bread recipes that would measure up to my standards and finally found what I have been looking for!! This was really good!  I baked in two standard sized loaf pans and baked at 325 for about 1 hr and 15 min.  I also did the crumble topping another recommended and it really made the top great.  The bread was really sweet, though not a problem at our house.  Put the bananas in a ziplock bag and let the kids help mash them...this is their favorite part.  I did omit the nuts b/c my daughter is allergic but they are my favorite part of this bread.  Next time i will make one with nuts and one without. Thanks for sharing!

region:

country:
None
text:
This was excellent! I used whole wheat flour, added a dash of nutmeg and cloves, and cut the sugar in half. If you don't like super sweet fruit breads, I would recommend reducing the sugar. I thought half the amount of sugar called for was plenty. Since I was only using half the recipe and only had one largish loaf pan, I increased the oven time to 325 for 65 minutes, which was perfect. Also, I covered the loaf with tinfoil the last 20 minutes of the cook time to avoid having the top get too brown.

YUMMMMMMY! I had allrecipes adjust the servings to 16 - the only change I made to the recipe is 2 eggs (instead of 1 1/2 called for), 1 tsp of nutmeg and a handfull of milk chocolate chips (I didn't have any nuts). text:
Great recipe.  I followed the advice of other reviewers regarding cooking temp/time, and cooked 2 9x4 loaves for 75 minutes at 325.  I note that the author used very small pans (7x3) which could account for the discrepancy in cooking temp/time.  I added 1 Tbsp. spiced rum to the wet ingredients, and used a whole-grain baking mix instead of the flour, salt and baking soda. I added extra cinnamon, allspice and cloves to the dry ingredients.  My loaves came out moist and delicious!  Thank you for a great recipe!

text:
Very good banana bread!  I am trying to lose my baby weight, so I made the following changes: halved the recipe, skipped the cinn/sugar sprinkling on the pan, used only 2 T. margarine and 1/4 c. applesauce.  Cut the sugar down to 1/2 c. sugar, 1/2 c. honey. Used only 1 egg, subbed fat-free plain yogurt for the sour cream (but that was just because that's what I had on hand), used almost all whole wheat flour (except for 1/4 c., which I used white).  Even with ALL these healthy changes, this yielded a sweet, hearty banana bread which the whole family loved!  I baked this in an 8x8 pan and just cut into squares.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/630508.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such a fantastic recipe.  Yes, the sour cream really does cut the sugar and gives it a nice, nice tang although very subtle.  I followed the recipe precisely but I cut out all the cinnamon, only because I love the taste of the bananas and vanilla on their own.    I didn't have but one of the pans called for in the recipe, but I had some LeCrueset bread pans that were very similar in size, so I used those.  I filled the pans a bit too full because it really rose nice and high!  Next time, will fill all the pans only half full and use the remaining batter to make muffins.  I used my kitchenAid mixer and used Speed 1 to stir in the flour.  My bread was still nicely dense and not light.. so the trick is to stir in the flour slowly at the end.  Also, I sifted my flour, which helped to mix it in much more evenly.  Very good.  Thanks for sharing Esther!  Now my ONLY go to banana bread recipe!

My first time making banana bread... it is delicious. It's soft a tasty in the middle and the top has a wonderful crust. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good stuff, but I wouldn't call it "great".  I followed the recipe as stated, but left out the cinnamon/sugar coating.  The resulting bread has a really nice consistency -- definitely a "classic" banana bread feel -- and the loaves remained good even without refrigeration for 3 days.  The taste was a little bland, however.  Surprising, because the BATTER tasted really really good!    I didn't have any 7x3 loaf pans, so I had to use 3 8x3.8 inch loaf pans + a mini muffin pan instead.  Cooking time at 300 degrees had to be lengthened by about 45 minutes to cook the loaves all the way through (muffins were done in 30 mins).  If I were to make this again, I'd probably try adding something else to the batter to give it a kick -- maybe some dried cranberries, or some rum.  It was really nice bread, but it just needs something more.

I halved it- since I didn't think I'd want or need 4 loaves but after trying it I immediately regretted that decision. The texture and flavor are pretty much perfect- I don't feel that it required any tweaking  and will probably use it from now on. Thank you!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3711496.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AWESOME!!! I absolutely love this recipe! Before I began, I was a bit concerned about the batter sticking to my pans-since the only thing between the pan and the batter was grease and sugar, instead of flour. I should never have worried. It didn't stick at all! I made a half recipe and did make some changes (the review by Saralady19 was very helpful): I did not have enough sour cream so had to sub in mayonnaise for about 1/2 the amount, I used 2 eggs, hand mixed the dry ingredients into the wet, used pecans, to half the amount of batter I also added chocolate chips, and on the loaf without the choc. chips I added a streusel topping. Baked it at 325 F. I don't think I will EVER even try another banana bread recipe!! :-)

text:
Great bread, but like others I made a few changes... I made two loaves out of the recipe and had to bake at 325 for an hour and 10 mins then at 300 for another 30 mins or so to get the center done.  The crust didn't burn but was hardened.  Substituted cinnamon applesauce for the butter and 1.5 c of splenda with 1.5c of sugar.  Also used fat free sour cream, and eggbeaters, was delicous warm, haven't tried it cold yet!

I cut down on the sugar by 1 cup, and the banana bread was just sweet enough. I also reserved some of the batter and added some melted dark chocolate to the mix and spread it down the center of the loaves. Great recipe, but like many other members I found that it did take a long time to bake since I baked in 2 9 inch loaves. But it was well worth the wait!  Thanks for the recipe!

If you are tempted to bake this in two large bread-sized loaf pans, DON'T do it. I did and the results were not good. It took an hour and a half at 300. The loaves looked beatuful and released from the pans perfectly, but when we cut into them, they were like a brick of pudding. I'm gong to try this again in smaller or maybe even mini-pans.

Yum! This recipe has now replaced the banana bread recipe my mother used to make and passed on to me. I used Greek yoghurt as I didn't have sour cream and it was deliciou. I also used chopped pecan nuts which I had lighly toasted first. I made two large loaves and 12 muffins. I sliced up one of the loaves and put them in the freezer individually wrapped. I take out one slice each day for packed lunches and by lunch time they are perfectly defrosted and taste as though just baked. A lovely recipe, thank you.

Display Name:
Janice Freedman

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1747077.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was moist, and not as dense as a more traditional banana bread which I really do prefer. I used 7 smaller bananas, and it gave me 2 cups and a third banana mashed. I also added half teaspoon of nutmeg, and quarter teaspoon of cloves. I like to put nutmeg in as many recipes as I can, it adds a great touch to the fall spices and goes beautifully with the bananas. I substituted using brown sugar for half of the sugar, doing half white and half brown sugar for more flavor. I did not use nuts, but added 2 cups of chocolate chips, and made two normal sized loaves, and one slightly smaller. I did not think the adding the sugar cinnamon was a big added factor for taste. The sour cream really does keep it moist. I also baked at 325 and not the lower temp of 300, for an hour and fifteen minutes.

text:
This was really  really good. Definitely a dessert bread. I added chocolate chips to mine. I like to have my banana bread a little  doughy in the middle. FYI you dont need to under cook for that for this recipe. In fact if you dont like your bread doughy I would cooking it about 5 minutes longer or so.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is great banana bread! I was worried about it tasting a little sour, but it wasn't. I halved the recipe, but since you can't halve an egg really and I only had one anyway, I substituted an extra banana in and only added one egg. Delicious breakfast on the go if made in muffin tins! Also baked at 350 and watched them closely so they wouldn't burn. UPDATE: If you can, weigh the sour cream!! I purchased a too-large tub of sour cream for the first batch so I ended up using a scale to weigh the correct amount. It turned out very moist. The second time I just bought the correct size tub and added the ingredients without weighing it. It wasn't nearly as moist. Weigh if you can!

text:
The best banana bread I've ever tried! I used 16 oz of previously frozen (about to expire)strawberry/banana yogurt instead of sour cream, 5 bananas, (all I had) and added 1 tsp nutmeg. It made 2 large 9x6 loaves, baked @325 for 85 minutes. The cinnamon sugar on top is great! One loaf supposed to be given away but kids didnt' know and they devoured both. Looking forward to trying different yogurt flavors.

text:
I have made this recipe several times now, and each time the response I get is "This is the best banana bread I have ever had".  Too bad I can't take credit for the recipe! I do make sure to put the bananas into the mixer so that you don't end up with lumps... The lumps end up looking and feeling like the bread isn't baked completely.  Also, I never have four 7 x 3 loaf pans... I used a regular loaf pan & 1 bundt pan for my last batch, but did have to increase baking time by 30 minutes (approx).  Came out great!  Thanks so much for this recipe!

Display Name:
Squeezer

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/166829.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This truly lives up to its reviews.  Moist, delicious.  My husband, who loves banana bread, deemed this the best he'd ever had.  I don't know why some complained of it being too cake-like.  Mine was perfectly dense and moist.  It helps to add the sugar about one quarter at a time, but it will still be grainy.  Not to fret.  The only time I used my mixer was to incorporate the wet ingredients into the butter mixture.  I incorporated the flour a little at a time by hand.  Maybe this helped it to keep it dense?  I only had two loaf pans, one large and one medium, but they held all the batter.  I baked at 325 degrees for more about 75 minutes.  Absolutely worth trying.  I didn't bother with a crumb topping, save that for coffee cakes!  Enjoy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make quite a few adjustments to make it much healthier and its extra tasty when you know its not so bad. I also do about a half batch because i cant count on 6 bananas in the house that long.   325* oven  -1 Cup applesauce (Motts natural) - 3/4 cup white sugar - 1/2 cup brown sugar (measured without packing it in) - 1 Egg - 1 Egg white - 2 Large overripe bananas - 8 Oz lite sour cream - 1 teaspoon vanilla - 1 generous teaspoon of cinammon - 1.5 teaspoons of baking soda - 2 cups Whole Wheat Flour - 1/2 cup chopped walnuts  I like to bake em muffin style - which takes 25 minutes if you fill the cups half way.  A thinner loaf takes about 45 minutes.

text:
Wow, this recipe is AWESOME!! I read a great many of the reviews, and picked up some great tips...I halved the recipe, substituted some brown sugar in place of white, added a dash of allspice & cloves, and baked it in one standard size loaf pan at 325 for about and hour and a half (my oven sucks, make sure you check yours half way thru baking) and topped it off with a brownsugar/butter/flour/cinnamon streusel topping...and I LOVE IT! So far I'm the only one who's tried it, but I bet my family will flip for it!
I'm adding this to my permanent recipe file, and wish I'd tried it before Christmas!

text:
Absolutely delicious. Be prepared to use a large bowl for prep. I did not have 7x3 inch loaf pans, so I filled up 2 larger loaf pans about 3/4 full, upped the oven temp to 325 and checked after one hour. After one hour the middle was still undercooked, so I added 15 minutes, and checked then - perfect! Very moist, inexpensive to prepare, and makes a lot. I did not have any problem with rising, the bread was dense but not too heavy. I think it would also be delicious with bittersweet or semi-sweet chocolate chips.

text:
I grew up on Banana Bread and I always thought my mom's recipe was the best (which it is great!), but now that I'm out of college and thousands of miles away I figure I would find my own recipes... this bread turned out fantastic.  My boyfriend loved it and he's not as big on breads as I am.  I didn't have the full amount of sour cream on hand, so I improvised and added some Apple Sauce, which only added to the moistness!

*Yummy tip: make it breadfast on the go or a snack by cutting yourself a slice of bread, cut that slice in half, spread cream cheese on the bread, and put the slices together like you would a sandwich... verrry good tip from my childhood!

text:
Wow!! I am not easily impressed but I LOVED how this turned out. I reduced the sugar by 1/2 c. because I made a crumble topping that I got from another review (1/2 c. brown sugar, 3 T. butter, 1/2 c. flour, 1 t. cinnamon). It was amazing. I am very proud of this bread!! I ate a mini loaf by myself haha. It looks beautiful and the crust gives it a wonderful taste and color. I baked at 325 for a little over an hour (the mini loaves were ready in 45 min. though). This recipe made 3 regular loaves and 2 mini loaves. You won't be dissapointed, trust me!

text:
Phenomenal, truly.  I followed the instructions to bake at 325 for 1 hour 10 minutes.  I also added an extra banana because I'll be shipping some of it and a 1/4 cup extra sour cream because we buy it in bulk at Sam's and I need to use it.  

Most fabulous banana bread I have ever tasted or made.  I've been making it for years like my grandmother did.  Hers is wonderful, too, but this truly takes the cake.  Not overly sweet or dense (mix in dry ingredients by hand), intensely moist, and caramelized crust.  I would, however, suggest adding more cinnamon and nutmeg.  Maybe even double it?  Wow.  Delicious.

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/89492.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For a lower-fat/calories modification of this recipe, user "Lisa" posted an EXCELLENT alternative. 
Instead of the butter, she used 1/2c applesauce, 1/4c olive oil, and 1 1/4c sugar.
I went with a no-sugar added applesauce, 'light-tasting' olive oil (mainly to use it up... I have nothing against olive oil flavor :)), and 1c white sugar, 1/4c brown sugar.
I also went with 2 1/2 c AP flour, 2c whole wheat flour. Also 'light' sour cream.
Made the whole thing in my mixer, and it's very moist and spongy, and perfectly sweet...I think backing off on the sugar would still yield a good bread.

text:
I'm going to give this 5 stars, because even with my tinkering it still had great flavor.  I reduced the sugar by a half cup.  I also replaced the butter with applesause and the eggs with flaxseed (1TBS ground flaxseed + 3TBS water to every 1 egg).  Also used half whole wheat flour.  I didn't get my baking temperatures and timing just right (made the mistake of trying to bake it hotter) and the texture wasn't bready enough because of that, in combination with the flaxseed.  But even so, they tasted wonderful and froze beautifully.  Be warned, this is a big recipe.  I baked four mini loafs, 12 large muffins, and 24 mini muffins.  I froze the mini loafs and have been bringing them out to thaw over night for the last couple of weeks.  My kids love them with breakfast.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm sure that it tastes best just using the original recipe without modifications. However, I wasn't looking to impress anyone with a knockout recipe, rather just needing to use up ripe Bananas into a somewhat healthy treat for my family. I took 3 reviewers advice and combined their suggestions.  The results were exactly what I was looking for. I halfed the recipe and these were the measurments I used: 1 T. Butter, 1/8 c. Olive Oil, 1/2 C. Applesauce, 1 C. Splenda, 1/2 c. Sugar, 1 Egg + 3 Egg whites, Light Sour Cream, 1 c. Whole Wheat flour, 1 1/4 All Purpose Flour. I love nuts so I used about 1 1/2 c. chopped walnuts. I also used a dash of Nutmeg and Cloves as one reviewer suggested. I baked it in a bundt for 1 hour at 325. Turned out fabulous! I'm not sure I will be making the "correct version" any time soon as this is plenty sweet and delicious even with the healthy changes!

text:
One word...perfection! Followed the recipe perfectly and it was super moist and had the best flavor of banana. I didn't have four loaf pans so I decided to put some in muffin pans for only thirty minutes and those turned out wonderful too. I will definitely be making this recipe again. I did the low fat sour cream as the only slight modification, but I can't imagine the regular sour cream making it taste any better than it did. The only hard part is waiting days for the bananas to ripen (but putting them in a brown bag does speed up the process).

text:
AMAZING!  This is the best banana bread I have ever tasted - unbelievably moist.  I did follow the advise of others and spinkled sugar and cinnamon on top so I would have a nice crunchy crust but a soft and moist inside.  We prefer our banana bread dense instead of light and fluffy, so again I followed  advise of previous posters to mix in the flour by hand instead of using an electric mixer.  This turned out perfect.  I didn't change any ingredients. I was able to do two big loaves and a big pan of muffins (I cooked those at 300 degrees about 18-20 minutes - depending on the size of your muffin tins.)  Definitely will make again! UPDATE: 7/6/17  I have been making this banana bread since 2008 and it is still my favorite and most requested banana bread recipe!  You can't go wrong with this one!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/278565.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic banana bread!  I make one often (recipe that I have adapted from my mom to make a bit healthier) and liked the sound of this one as it uses sour cream.  Since it makes so much, I cut the recipe in half and made a few modifications to make a bit healthier as follows (cutting recipe in half): instead of butter used 1/8 c canola oil, 2/3 c unsweetened applesauce, 1 egg and 1 egg white, light sour cream, 4 bananas, 1/2 cup white sugar, 1 1/4 c white flour and 1 cup whole wheat, other ingredients remained the same.  I left out the nuts as we don't like them too much.  I was able to get one large loaf (9x5x3) and 6 muffins (loaf baked for 65 mins then turned off the oven and let sit for 15 mins).  Turned out super moist and I loved the hint of cinnamon.  Thanks for sharing!

No one made a better Banana Bread than my "Gram" ... until now.  I thought it would be a nice little gift to send home with my guests who were coming for Easter.  I accidently dropped one of the breads as it was coming out of the oven. The loaf cracked so that was my opportunity. I just had to taste it.  Delicious!  The hint of cinnamon was great. The sour cream made it moist.  And, dusting the pan with the sugar/cinnamon just adds to the crust. I will certainly be making this again.  Thanks,Esther, for a wonderful recipe.

text:
I have been making this bread for a few years. And it really is one of the best ones out there. I use only use 3 bananas, then add 1 cup of drained pineapples, 1/2 cup of drained cherries, 1 cup of coconut, and sometimes even drained peaches in I have them in the fridge. I chop them up. I always use canned fruit. But I bet fresh fruit would be good too. Some people said it wouldn't cook all the way threw. It has happened to me once. Just keep sticking a knife into the center until it comes out clean.  That way you can really get a good look of the inside. It also makes a lot. I like to make small loafs and give them out to everyone.***************

Display Name:
Devoney Wolfe

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/203403.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved it! I combined SaraLady19's suggestion for the topping with LINDABTX's recommendations for a healthier bread (except using Splenda - I don't like it! ;P), and it was amazing!  Oh, and I also roasted the nuts at 350 for 5-10 min beforehand. I used fat-free sour cream, too, and it was delicious! The bread turned out more like cake! I also halved the recipe. I'd do a couple things differently next time to make it that much better: 
1. Use unsweetened applesauce, used less sugar, or both.  The way I did it, it turned out just a bit too sweet for me. OK with a nice glass of milk, though...mmm!
2. Waited until the bananas were just a titch more ripe.  I think it would have given the loaves that extra oomph of flavor. (I got impatient to try this awesome recipe!)
3. The bottoms of my loaves got a little more moist than the top once it sat on the counter & cooled off.  Maybe that's because I had it cooling on a paper towel on top of the cooling rack. I'll try putting it staight on the rack next time next time. I forgot about adding the wheat flour (from LINDABTX's) until my batter was already in the pans, so I just carefully stirred it in.  That could have done it.
Otherwise, this is, without a doubt my favorite banana bread recipe!

text:
Very tasty banana bread - great for a snowy February day!  I'd never had or made banana bread with cinnamon, so wasn't sure how that would taste.  Different, but good! 

For Sanetha D.......

You probably chose to decrease the amount of the recipe by half, which is why 3 Cups of sugar is referred to in the directions and 1.5 Cups sugar is in the ingredient list.  I've noticed that only the ingredients are affected when you change the serving size of recipes, not the amounts in the directions.

text:
I have tried more banana bread recipes than I could ever count, all failures. This was a huge success! My friends and family absolutely loved it! I love that it takes few ingredients and makes 4 loaves.  I gave them away at Christmas. I did not have 7x3 pans, but it turned out well in the larger loaf pans. The only change I made was adding slightly more cinnamon. I'm going to half the recipe right now and make some muffins with a crumb topping. I was sceptical of adding sour cream, afraid that it would give it "bite", but please do not hesitate, it does not take away from the banana taste one bit.  This is definately a great recipe with so many options of things to add to make each time a little different.  Thank you for finally giving me a banana bread recipe that I can bake!

text:
thanks to previous reviewers, I made a few revisions that enhanced this bread.  It is really moist and tender because of the sour cream, so I split the recipe between 2 bundt pans to reduce the weight and cooking time.  I used olive oil instead of butter, used white whole wheat flour, and used splenda in the cake itself.  I also added an 8oz bag of dark chocolate chips.   The cinnamon sugar really adds to the rich appearance and taste.  This is a winner.

The best banana bread I've ever had or made. I've tried about 15 recipes so far but I'm done now. I have found the winner. This recipe is excellent as is with the addition of nutmeg and cloves (and the guilty pleasure of chocolate chips, once in a while).

I fell asleep with a loaf in the oven and it was still good after cooking for 2 hours. The topping carmelized and kept everything moist. Have I mentioned yet how much I love this recipe, lol?

text:
This is absolutely the best banana bread recipe you will find! WARNING: This makes a LOT of bread...I have the 4-loaf mini pans and it made eight of them. One of the best things to do is once you butter the bread pan, just take regular cinnamon sugar to sprinkle all over. It creates this yummy sweet crunchiness on the outer layer of the bread. This bread also freezes really well, just thaw in the refrigerator for a day or so. Thank you for the great recipe!

text:
Tried this recipe and loved the flavor and moistness. I followed the other viewers advice with the changes. The only thing I didn't like about it was after it was baked it felt wet around the outside and I didn't let it sit in the pan very long before I took it out to cool. Even after it cooled and I wrapped it, it still felt wet on the outside. My husband is a picky eater and doesn't care for sweets like I do, but he liked this one and wanted to take a loaf to work to share. Even though this was very good in flavor I don't know if I will make it again untill I can figure out how to get rid of the wetness around the outside. It doesn't make for a very attractive gift when you unwrap it and half the sides peel off. I love to bake but I haven't learned all the tricks of the trade, so I need everything written down and detailed instructions. I'm not a "Fly by the seat of my pants gal." (as Julia Roberts would say) I'm still giving it 5 stars because the flavor and moistness was great and everybody that sampled it wanted the recipe. Maybe they will have better luck than me with the outside.

text:
Love it Love it Love it! I have found I prefer to bake at 325 degrees or its kind of wet in the middle. I use 1 9x5 bread pan and a 10x15 metal pan. I like to sprinkle the cinnamon sugar on the bread and not the pan, because it seems like the sugar cements the bread to the pan. I also like to spoon the flour into the measuring cups after i stir it a bit, so it's not so heavy. I also like to add 2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice. Sooooo yummy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread turned out great!  It was moist, flavorful and just as easy as any other recipe I have tried.  The cinnamon sugar you coat the baking pan with really makes it great, and a little different.  I babysit for a 4 year old and a 6 year old and they went nuts over it.  I did cut the recipe in half and still had a ton.  I followed someone else's suggestion with half the recipe and used 2 eggs (instead of 1 1/2) and 4 bananas (instead of 3).  I think this helped make the bread more moist and have a better consistency.  I also divided up the batter into 5 mini loaf pans and baked them together for about 40 minutes.  Great for sharing!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
My new favorite banana bread recipe! My old recipe used plain yogurt, which I don't have on hand, always had to buy special to make banana bread. I also experimented using Splenda Blend for Baking, turned out great. Not too moist, not too dry. Left out walnuts, my husband hates them. Scaled the recipe down to match the 4 VERY overripe bananas I had, and baked in 5 mini-loaf pans for almost an hour.

text:
I thought the banana bread itself was excellent.  I will definitely use this recipe again and again... but I would omit dusting the pan with sugar mixture.  I found it made it too sweet and detracted from the banana flavour of the bread.  As well, I used the crumb topping that was suggested by other reviewers and again it was just too over the top.  Banana bread in its simplest form is the best and does not need any embellishing. (maybe some chocolate chips for the kiddies, though!)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/40588.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely delicious. I'm diabetic, so I replaced Splenda for the sugar measure-for-measure. (I used a scaled-down recipe and made one loaf instead of 4.)

To make it lower-glycemic, I replaced 1/2 the flour with whole wheat flour, and 1/4 of the flour with vanilla whey protein powder. The other 1/4 I used white flour. (If you're used to substituting some flour in your breads with vanilla pudding, this has the same effect.)

I've missed banana bread, and now I can have it again! I'm keeping this recipe for sure.

text:
WE HAVE A WINNER!!!! I've been trying to find a recipe that my husband likes for 4 years. This one did it! The only thing I changed was to leave off the cinnamon sugar sprinkle on the sides. This bread is perfectly sweet on it's own. If I try it with the sprinkles I will most likely cut down on the sugar in the recipe a little. I've used fat free plain yogurt when I'm out of sour cream and no one can tell a difference. I recently made a bundt loaf for my physician's office. Now I'm known as the "banana bread lady" and I'm jokingly told I can only make an appointment if I bring more bread!

text:
WOW! This is an awesome recipe! I wanted muffins instead of loaves so I reduced the serving size to 11 and it made 18 muffins. I sprinkled the cinnamon and sugar on the bottom of the muffin paper cup and half filled with my batter. I wanted a really pretty topping on the top of my muffins so I used 1/2 cup of brown sugar and 1 tbsp. of melted butter and added some walnuts to that. I added that mixture to the top of the batter and baked them. Oh my! I couldnt stop at just eating one, especially while they were hot! A must try! Turned out very pretty to even give as gifts!

text:
This banana bread is fantastic! I have made it with several variations on the basic recipe and it turned out brilliantly everytime. I cut the sugar down (especially if the bananas I am using are very ripe) and omit the nuts, in place of the nuts I have used choc chips (very yummy, but very sweet) or frozen mixed winter berries (this is my favourite variation, the slight sourness of the rasberrys and blueberries really cuts through the sweetness of the bread and the berries go all soft and gooey). In fact, I am making it for the second time in three days to take to work for morning tea! Fabulous.

text:
Wow, what a moist and delicious banana bread. This will replace my standard bb recipe from now on. I did have to make some changes/substitutions. For one, I used two standard bread pans and had to bake for an additional 30 minutes. I also used light sour cream, and the loaf is still rich and yummy.

text:
I've made this a few times and finally got brave enough to modify the heck out of it.  I used 1/4 c butter and the rest in baby food prunes.  1.5 cups of brown sugar, 1 egg and 1/2 cup of egg whites.  I also used whole wheat flour and apple yogurt instead of sour cream.  I have to admit it turned out pretty good.  I think it needs to be played with a bit more though.  But pretty good for healthier muffins.  This recipe turned out great.  I halved it and baked it in an 8by8 pan.  I needed to cook it for an extra 15 mins due to the pan size.  I also used a mix of yogurt and sour cream b/c it was what I had on hand.

text:
So if you're looking for something a little different from the regular banana bread of your youth.  This is it.  It's just fine.  I like the dense, strong banana flavor like babana bread my gramps and my mom used to make...and this was not it.  It's too fluffy for me to love.  Not enough banana flavor for me to think it tastes like banana bread... very cinnamon-y... but it will be good with coffee because it is very much like coffee cake with a hint of banana.

text:
This is really great banana bread. I halved the recipe and it turned out great. I substituted splenda for 1/2 cup of the sugar and only used 1/2 cup butter. I added an extra banana and a tbsp of extra sour cream (I used light sour cream) to increase moistness due to cutting the butter down. It turned out amazing!! Also, in one of my loaves, I threw in a handful of chopped dates and a handful of unsweetened coconut flakes - this made it even better. I'll use this recipe again - thanks!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this recipe all the time for friends and gatherings.  It's everyone's favorite!  I generally use a teensy bit less flour - too much flour will dry it out and it will taste like every other banana bread out there.  Also, I like to go heavy on the cinnamon and sugar mix in the pan.  One time I made the mistake of getting the cinnamon and sugar mixture a bit wet so that it clumped.  I still dusted the pan with it, though it was obviously clumped in spots.  To my surprise, it was extra good that time!  I will do that again next time on purpose.

text:
This is the most amazing recipe for banana bread. A few things make it exceptional: 1) the sour cream makes it super moist  2) dusting the pan with cinnamon-sugar provides a nice crispy top 3) putting cinnamon in the batter compliments the banana quite nicely. This is wonderful comfort food in such unsettling times. I only had 9 bananas so I reduced the amount of sour cream to 12 oz. and cut out a cup of flour and it came out wonderfully! It took about a half an hour longer to bake than the recipe indicated, however.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
There's a reason this recipe has close to 100 reviews...IT'S TERRIFIC! Not only is it yummy it's also very versatile. I added about 1T of milk and a bit of nutmeg to the base and then made one batch with milk chocolate chips and another with shredded apple. My boyfriend took them to work and reported back that "Of all the banana breads I made for them this was the biggest hit and people wanted the recipe."  We both agreed that the combo of chocolate chips and banana bread sounded a bit strange but I decided to give it a try since there were a few of you who added them to your breads.  Too bad we both declined trying the batch with the chocolate chips because that was the one that was devoured the quickest! Thanks so much for this wonderful recipe...I will never be forced to throw out old bananas or unused sour cream again! :)

AMAZING!! This is the best banana bread I have ever had. I did have to make a few changes because of circumstances. I didn’t have enough of sour cream I used Greek yogurt as well. Next time I may just use the Greek yogurt and see if it changes too much. I also used 7 bananas (I didn’t want to waste any of my over ripe bananas) Lastly I couldn’t find enough of my bread pans. I used a brownie style pan and put parchment paper in the middle. I’m a novice baker at best and I still got this recipe to turn out perfect. This is excellent for a beginner baker.

text:
This has got to be the best banana bread recipe out there. I've been making it for years and anyone who's ever tried it always tells me it's the best they've ever had. I always add an extra banana or two and cut down the sugar down 1/2 C if I'm adding a cup of chocolate chips. I don't even make the cinnamon sugar crust because it's so good even without it. I've tried baking at higher temperatures because 300 degrees always seem so low but then the tops brown too much so no higher than 325. Just stick a toothpick in after 50 minutes. Thank you for sharing this gem of a recipe, Esther. You're the BEST!

I made this recipe today. I found that when the directions and ingredient list are followed it makes four 7x3 loafs perfectly.  The batter i tasted (licked from my fingers) was almost a scrumptious as the finished baked bread. I have been looking for a great sour cream banana bread recipe and i have found it. I cook really well but my baking skills need work. This was easy and made alot.  The only suggestion I have  for anyone making the full recipe and that is once it is time to add the flour, dump the wet mixture into a LARGE bowl that has the measured flour already in it.  Thanka for the recipe!

text:
I added the pinch of nutmeg and ground cloves, as recommended by another Baker. Because I live at a lower sea level, I turned up oven to 350° and baked loaves for 1 he 15 mins. (It's likely sea level that doesn't allow the bread to bake at 300° for an hr. I recommend baking the tea bread as you would any other tea breads)

The bread is moist and DELICIOUS!!! The recipe made 4 loaves, as recipe states.  I've made banana nut bread for years. This is absolutely the best recipe ever. I intend to try the lower fat version another time.

This recipe worked well for cooking with my grandkids. We made our muffins egg-free (3 flax “eggs”), gluten-free and nut-free. Also subbed 1/4 c. butter + 1/2 c. unsweetened applesauce for all butter and only used 2 c. sugar. We mixed entirely by hand and baked 35 minutes at 350. Very good. BUT, paper cupcake wrappers stuck to muffin. Silicone would be better.

I made this recipe in disposable mini loaf pans because it seemed like way too much to have out at once and this way it would stay fresh longer. I used brown sugar instead of granulated sugar and I added a streusel topping and a little bit of coffee to give the bread a richer color. Some of the best banana bread I’ve ever had!

text:
This was a good recipe! I love making mini muffins. Since this recipe makes a ton of batter - I tried of a portion of it making mini muffins, but since the bread is so soft it didn't hold the shape of the mini muffins well. It did hold a normal muffin size well and the bread loaf was beautiful.

Due to the ingredients I had available, I cut the sugar down to 2 cups vs 3 cups and I put in 7 bananas (I had 7 very ripe bananas that I wanted to use). I also did half white flour and half wheat flour. I increased the cinnamon to 3 tsps (we love cinnamon!)

Very good, and I would make it again.

text:
The best ever! I tried others only to throw them away. This recipe is so good, it makes a lot so what I do I make individual breads, in personal pans that are 4" x 2" by  2" deep filled about 2/3 full, bake @300* for about 35 to 40 minutes, my family just gobbles them up.. I freeze what is leftover, they taste just like I made them that day after thawing from the freezer.   I normally put my bananas in the fridge to get them to turn brown right away.. it works great and quick. I also add about 1 1/2 cups of chopped pecans.  1st time I made this recipe I thought that it was going to be too much mix, but I found myself wanting to make more.. def deserves a 5 star rating.. no changes just did exactly what was written and I have probably made this a dozen times over or more..

text:
My family enjoyed this bread. I made a number of changes to lighten it up.  I followed someone else’s idea and used unsweetened applesauce instead of butter.  I also used Swerve granulated “sugar” for 2/3 of the sugar amount.  I used regular sugar for the other 1/3.  Then I substituted all of the sour cream for Fage 0% plain Greek yogurt.  It all worked!  I made two large loaves so did follow someone else’s suggestion and cooked it at a higher temperature and for quite a bit longer.  
Note:  I haven’t made it the regular way so I can’t compare.  ??

This turned out delicious but I did make changes just because I can. I cut the recipe in half and instead of 1.5 eggs I used flax seed for the .5. I also used brown sugar in place of plain white, and added a TBLS of frozen orange juice concentrate. Then instead of adding walnuts to the batter, since I forgot, I sprinkled the top with cinnamon and sugar and a liberal covering of chopped walnuts. After baking iced with maple buttercream. Everyone thought it was great and all the flavors kept the banana flavor balanced. (Although I love all things banana.)

text:
I really like this recipe just as it is, but the best thing about it is just how malleable the recipe is. The second time I made it I substituted one cup of brown for one c of white and thought it better. I also added the topping that another reviewer suggested, half c of brown and half c of white sugar with a spoonful of cinnamon and a third to half a cube of melted butter and a bit of flour to make a topping was a must do. And lastly, I took a que from another reviewer and went crazy with the spices, ground cloves, nutmeg, allspice, added ginger and at least one, perhaps 2 secret spices [ones I forgot obviously] and the end result just always seemed to be better than the last. Only bad thing was that I kept making it and had so much laying around that I had to start giving it away....and so then you have more friends and they want more or the recipe and...it's madness I tell you!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I noticed a lot of comments on here about it being a very moist recipe and people were disappointed with how it cooked inside. To counteract that all you need to do is add a little extra flour. Remember banana bread batter should NOT be runny. It should be very thick. So if you have a runny batter, just add a quarter cup of flour until the consistency thickens up. You should bake bread like this at 325 degrees, not 300. It will make all the difference. Also, I added 1 teaspoon of baking powder. For my picture, I had seven bananas so I used 5 cups of flour and 1 teaspoon of baking powder. I also used a little extra cinnamon and an extra teaspoon of vanilla.

text:
Yummmm! Love it! I used what I had on hand, as I usually do :)... so I subbed 2 med shredded apples for the missing 2 1/2 bananas (total about 4 cups of fruit); I didn't have enough sugar, so I added 1/2 c agave syrup.  It's very sweet, so 2 cups would be sufficient;  I used 1 1/2 c oatmeal in place of the same amount of flour; and I used whole wheat flour for the rest.  I only had 2 loaf pans, so I used an 8 count muffin tin!  And I baked @ 350 degrees for 1 hr.  30 min for the muffins.  Next time I'll use all muffin tins!

I made this recipe exactly how it's given with a few exceptions: I hand whisked everything because I don't have a mixer, baked it for 1 hour 10 min at 325, I didn't add nuts because I didn't have them, and added the flour last, a cup at a time. This recipe made three large loafs and they all turned out perfectly! Seriously moist, sticky, and 100% delicious.

None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good banana bread recipe.  i have made few times as is but this time I skipped dusting the pans with sugar and cinnamon and just used my regular coating with butter and flour.  The reason is that the ones  I made before, when they cooled  down and were left at room temperature, the  sugar that adhered to the crust kind of melted and made the crust  little wet ! Another thing you should do is make sure the walnuts are finely chopped or else the slices  will crumble when you heat a piece of walnut with the knife and won't be neat.

text:
I’ve made this recipe several times and they’ve always turned out great. I usually make them in muffin form and can get 40-50 muffins depending on how full I make my cups. My most recent batch I substituted the butter for coconut oil. I didn’t notice a big difference compared to the times I’ve made them with butter. The sour cream can also be substituted with Greek yogurt; so far I’ve only tried vanilla, with yummy results. These are also great with chocolate chips and extra cinnamon.

text:
It's SO moist. You might think it's undercooked but if a toothpick comes out perfectly clean, it's fine. Just let it rest and cool before slicing. I halved the recipe and lessened the sugar to around 1 cup, then added milk chocolate chunks and chopped walnuts to mine. I also added around 1 1/2 tbsp cocoa powder to half of the batter and ran a spoon through it to marble it. SO delicious. 10/10.

text:
This was perfection!  I wanted only 2 loaves so I used 3 eggs, 4 bananas, 1/3 cup butter, 1 1/2 cup sugar, 8 ounces of sour cream, 1 tsp.Vanilla, 1 tsp. Cinnamon,  1 1/2 tsp, baking soda and  2 1/4 cup flour. All other ingredients were halved. I baked the two loaves at 325 degrees for 1 hour and 10 min. They turned out perfectly.

Display Name:
NaomiNerd
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great, and very moist. Moist to the point my mom was concerned it was underdone, though it was definitely done baking. I made a couple small adjustments, but otherwise followed to recipe to a T. 
I didn't make the cinnamon-sugar coating for the pans.
I used 2 1/2 cups of sugar instead of 3, and it turned out perfectly sweet.
I used 2 cups of very finely chopped walnuts instead of 1. (thank goodness for blenders) 
And instead of splitting it between 4 pans, I just put the batter in one very long pan, a little over halfway full, and the remainder in a small pan. 
Instead of taking 1 hour to bake, it took about 2, but I think it was because I put it in such a big pan. 

Either way, everyone who tried it (in all age groups, child to elderly) really enjoyed it, I highly recommend this recipe. 
Just bear in mind, it makes a LOT of banana bread.

5

text:
I followed the advice of the first reviewer and mixed the dry ingredients by hand, as well as adding the crumble she suggests at the end. I only needed to make one loaf and so had to quarter the amounts suggested (who makes that much banana bread in one go??). I baked it for over 1hr 20 minutes at 300 degrees to account for the crumble on top keeping the bread doughy. It turned out beautifully, very thick, dense, and moist. The crumble should not be ignored! Very good bread and easy to make.

text:
I love this recipe!  It’s simply perfect.  The sugar/cinnamon crunch added to the backing pan adds terrific flavor and texture.  I also added 3/4 cups chopped Pecans for taste and texture.   And since I only had about half of the sour cream recommended per the recipe , I substituted 1/2 cup whipped cream cheese to make up the difference. My favorite Allrecipes recipe so far for backing//sweat goods.  My husband (who does not typically like sweats) had several portions (he recommends heating up the banana bread with some Maple syrup and/or butter Thank you, all, for your support so fat.

This recipe is absolutely amazing! I’ve made it many times over the last couple of years, and it is wonderful! I even gave it as a gift to coworkers this year for Christmas. I stick pretty strictly to the recipe, except for adding a little extra vanilla and cinnamon. Every now and then I will also substitute some coconut oil for some of the butter, but those are pretty much the only exceptions I ever make. I freeze bananas when they go bad, and defrost them to make the bread. It is always super moist. This will always be my go-to recipe for banana bread. Soooo good!

text:
Delicious!  I love banana bread and I have found it to be something that can easily be changed, here and there.  To make it a little healthier, I used 3 cups whole wheat flour, 1 cup oats and 1/4 cup  'Whole Grain 10 Grain Hot Cereal' (I used Bob's Red Mill).  I used half white sugar and half brown.  I added  1 and 1/2 cups raisins.  I preheated the oven to 350 and cooked it for an hour.   It was moist and fabulous.  I really liked that it made two pans. I actually had 6 overripe bananas.  Perfect! I will make it again.

region:

country:
None
text:
The best, moist, delicious banana bread I've EVER TASTED! I usually get the Starbucks banana bread slices and these are better.  SO glad I found a recipe I like. I cut the quantities in half. This is a huge recipe. I just wanted enough for a single loaf pan not 4! I was able to pull it off with ease. Mix the wet ingredients first like it says but mix all the dry ingredients together in a bowl. It helps with rising if you do it this way. Saw some people complain about it being raw in the middle. Never has happened for me with dry ingredients mixed separately. Man I should sell this stuff!

text:
We made the bread according to directions - no additions, eliminations or substitutions with regard to the ingredients.  I'm wondering if the issue so many were having with the loaves not being fully cooked was because people weren't paying attention to the size of the loaf pans the recipe called for.  This recipe calls for the pans to be the smaller size (7x3).  I used both large pans and small pans, and the bread turned out perfect baking it for an hour at 300 degrees in the small loaf pans, but I had to add 15 minute to the baking time for the larger loaf pans.

userID:

Display Name:
Kristy Pathakis
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1238471.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've used this recipe a bunch of times, usually tweaking something a bit, always with success. I replace the sour cream with greek yogurt and it comes out really well. This time, I also dissolved the baking soda in a very small amount of hot water and mixed it in before adding the flour. Not sure if this is what made a difference, but the texture was perfect! I also added some butterscotch chips and they go really well in the bread. I've added a lot of things instead of and including walnuts and it's always good, but the butterscotch flavor just went really well! (I just wouldn't over-do it as the flavor can be overpowering, which I've learned with other 'experiments'.) I think other reviews have pointed this out, but 1 hour isn't enough time. Put it in for 1h 10mins and check it.  Putting it in muffin tins works really well, and takes only like 30-40 mins (check them after 20 to get a feel for how much more time they'll need) and they freeze really well and it's easy to thaw as many servings as you'd like.

text:
This is a great base banana bread recipe that you can alter as needed, but bake at 350, not 300. Swap the sour cream out for yogourt if you want, half it and add apple sauce to make up the rest or throw in some chewies like plumped dried fruit. Whatever you like! Its pretty versatile. I would recommend baking this in three smaller loaves or muffins rather than one giant loaf. I did my muffins for 45 minutes, my loaves for 1 hour.

userID:
4468718
Display Name:
Brenda
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/350958.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is THE BEST banana  bread recipe I've  ever made.  After reading the reviews I made some modifications.
For the sugar I used 1 -1/2c brown sugar & 1- 1/2c white sugar,
For flour I used 2-1/4c white flour & 2-1/4c wheat flour.
I used chopped pecans instead of walnuts.
I am not high altitude.
Baked @° 325 for 1 hr instead of °300.
Everything else was exactly to the recipe.

I had different size loaf pans, recipe states it bakes 4 loaves,  I used the pans I had on hand which made 3 perfect loaves.
My pans were glass
1- 2 1/2 Qt shallow 11x6 loaf dish,
1-9x6 shallow loaf dish,
and
1-10x6 deep loaf dish ( had to bake this deep loaf dish 10 min longer to make it 1hr and 10 min)

I filled all loaf pans half full which made for 3 perfect loaves, all were moist.
I'm  not sure why others had such a hard time with this recipe, even with my modifications this was very moist and baked evenly with beautiful color.
Everyone raved about the bread, normally they won't  eat banana  bread.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5359972.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe (as I have the other times I've made this bread), but I also added a pinch of nutmeg with the walnuts.
I poured the batter into two square pans. It came out perfectly delicious!! I was able to cut 60 pieces for a gathering and it worked out great! I used one 7x13 pan and a 8x8 pan to get 2"- 3" tall pieces instead of loaf size. I also put foil around the edges for the last 20 minutes of baking to get the center cooked through with the same color as the edges. I highly recommend the square pans if you don't want such large pieces. It comes out so moist, but check a few spots with a toothpick to make sure it's fully cooked and don't worry if it takes a little longer. Great recipe for delicious banana bread!!

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My Grandma lived with us when I was growing up.  She and my mother were the WORLDS BEST COOKS and I was always a kitchen klutz.  So I've muddled along for 69 years with TV dinners and "heat it and eat it "food.  The only time I can recall baking anything was in Home Economics in grade school and a Dutch Oven Dump cake at scout camp.  But I couldn't pitch those 6 brown bananas this morning and found this recipe.  I made some MAJOR modifications to the recipe but it came out PERFECT.  I only had 2 metal pizza pans, and 3 silicon baking molds.  I had a 4x9x3" loaf mold, 6 cupcake mold, and a round 10x2" cake mold.  Modifications were a carton of vanilla yogurt instead of sour cream.  I greased the molds with cooking oil instead of dusting with sugar and spice.  I used almond extract instead of vanilla, pecans instead of walnuts, and added a cup of raisins.  With no expectations of success I mixed it all by hand, ending up with a small dishpan of batter.  [I think it was breeding or something because it kept getting bigger. ]  I spooned all the molds half full and miraculously it all fit perfectly!  The muffin and cake molds were floppy so I placed them on the pizza pans.  The loaf mold went directly on the oven shelf.  I set the timer for 1 hour.  Checking online I read reviews saying only silicon cupcake molds were practical.  I called a friend who told me to expect a doughy center in the round mold.  I checked them at 30 minutes and they were all doughy.  At 45 minutes the too

text:
Normally, I don't post reviews because I so often make numerous changes to the recipes I find on this site and it does bug me a little that people make so many changes and then rate the original recipe.  However, even though I made a few very minor changes,  I still decided to rate this one. Esther, this is a great recipe. Thank you so much for sharing it!  I have been baking various forms of banana bread for almost as long as I can remember baking so I am always looking for a new recipe to try. What intrigued me about this recipe was the dusting of sugar and spice on the pans before putting the batter in.  I wanted to make the recipe as it was originally written but I was prevented from doing so partly by my own faulty memory. When I went to the grocery store I meant to buy sour cream and forgot so all I had was about a third of a container of light sour cream to use for this recipe. To make up for the difference, I used plain nonfat Greek yogurt. I did not find that doing so compromised the flavor or texture at all.  I made two other changes and they were: I had just ground whole wheat for a bread recipe and had some left over so I substituted one cup of whole wheat flour. And, because I don't ever make anything banana without nutmeg,  I added a little bit of that to the quarter cup of sugar for dusting the pans and a couple of shakes into the batter. I mixed  the flour and sugar for the dusting in a bowl and had a little bit left at the end so I mashed the  bananas in that

text:
Since I'm not from the US i haven't had bananebread before I made this recipe.
So in all fairness I have noting to compare it with. 

I had to change a few ingredients. 

1- I did not have sour cream on hand so I substituted full fat (that's 10%) Greek Yoghurt. 
And 2- Bevause I was afraid I would find it to dense. (After seeing all the photos ) i added halve a table spoon of baking powder to get a more airy result. 
We are more accustomed to fruit cakes then fruit breads. And I want to ease my fam into American style dishes.

I made 2 flavours 1 original with the cinnamon and a pinch of nutmeg  (I read it in one of the commends and I like that it deepens the flavour and adds a bit of extra spicey warmth ) and i sprinkled the sugar cinnamon over the top of the loaf. 

And i mixed halve the dough with a cup of semisweet chocolate chips and 150 grams of sweet grated coconut. for my husband who doesn't like cinnamon. (And for my 6 year old daughter who likes everything chocolaty ) I did mixed an extra egg to compensate for the extra dry ingredients. 

And prayed I did not mess up the recipe since I'm a beginner baker and wing a lot of my creations. 

I know I should not but thats how I'm used to cook and it's hard to realy figure out what effects an extra egg or additional ingredients do to a recipe when your just starting out the journey of backing. Specially foreign recipes. 

But....

Both where amazing. I baked 2 loafs and had left over batter from both flavours. (I don't ow

text:
OMG I thought I died and went to Heaven.  I've made a lot of very good Banana Breads but this one is the BEST of ALL and deserves SIX STARS!.  While you are making it, it doesn't seem to be so spectacular but the magic occurs in the oven and you and your Mother-In-Law will NOT be disappointed.  I tweaked by adding 2 teaspoons Banana Flavor (Hard to find) and I am completely sold on substituting Badia Pumpkin Pie Spice instead of Cinnamon for all of my recipes.  Don't laugh till you try it, it's a superior exotic blend.

PS take a taste of the batter before you bake it,  then fill your pans, and while they are baking, sit down and lick the whole bowl clean!!

text:
My 6-year-old and I made this banana bread endless time.  That most probably the best banana bread we had ever had.  It is very moist.  There was a time I even cut everything in half to cook a smaller batch.  It came out perfect, too.

I did try to use vegetable oil instead of butter once.  It definitely doesn't taste as great as with butter.  But if you want to go for a healthier version, the taste may be ok with you.  Just the matter of getting use to it.

All in all, I highly recommend for anyone looking for a great banana bread recipe to try this one out.

text:
This was fabulous!  So easy and very delicious- I did omit the salt because I don't care for extra sodium in my food.  Note that this does make a LOT of bread so don't start thinking you will have just one loaf.  The sugar and cinnamon dusting was a nice idea because it caramelized in the pan and made a crispy sweet crust on the bottom, great and noted by everyone.  The other side to that is being careful if you try this in the very dark metal pans.  They cook far hotter and this can burn the sugar.  So glad I found this!

Very good, flexible recipe. I used whole wheat pastry flour and whole milk greek yogurt, just because that's what I had on hand. text:
This was delicious!  I am not a baker but I am looking for some yummy yet semi-healthy recipes for school snacks so, when I had some browning bananas on my counter, I gave this one a shot.  Thank you to all of your for your recommendations and substitutions.  I also halved this recipe and, with only 2 mushy brown bananas, I baked a third in the oven for 20-25 minutes to get it to "ripen."  I substituted 2% Greek Yogurt for the sour cream so that it would be higher in protein and lower in fat and it turned out fantastically.    I left out the nuts so my son could bring it to school (where some have nut allergies).  He and a friend just came home from school and polished off 4 slices of this bread.  Will definitely make again.

300 for 1 hour was not enough. Took 1 1/2 hours at that temperature in my oven. 350 for an hour gave great results.

Hands down our favorite banana bread recipe!! I make 6 loaves at a time because my guys go through it so fast (in the spring I stock the freezer to have all summer)! I usually make 2 plain, 2 chocolate chip (use mini chips) and 2 blueberry (use frozen berries). I make them in 2 - 9x3 pans. They need to cook for 1hr 20-30min (depending if you're mixing in choc chips or blueberries).  I also add the crumble from the Banana Crumb Muffin recipe. Yum!! They freeze great!! Now trying to figure out how to make them in my mini muffin pan. As my kids won't eat any other banana bread/muffin recipe!

text:
Very nice banana bread.  I'm pretty picky when it comes to banana bread since I've been making it for years. This makes a lot of banana bread, so I made two loaves and 16 muffins.  I topped the muffins with the cinnamon sugar mixture, using brown sugar instead of white to make it pretty.  I also didn't have sour cream so got creative and used a splash of milk and cream cheese instead. My oven bakes best at 350 or 375, so I baked at 350 for 1 hour for the bread and 350 for about 35 minutes for the muffins.  Turned out very well; I'm either going to freeze a loaf or two or take it to work.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Will definitely make it again.  I brought one loaf to a neighborhood party and it was gone so fast, I went home and brought the other loaf that went just as fast.
I halved the recipe, added lots of cinnamon, cloves and fresh nutmeg; chopped walnuts; and I substituted greek yogurt instead of sour cream.  For sugar I used a scant cup of Splenda for Baking and 1/3 cup brown sugar.  
I baked them in two 7" X 3" Pyrex dishes w/ oven set at 320.  
At  60 minutes they were ready.

text:
This was very good, moist bread. I halved the recipe & didn't need to change the cooking time/temp - I did use a convection oven though. While the recipe will make a great banana bread, I was a bit disappointed since I was hoping it would have a bit of sour cream flavor. This is not the case. Also, the bread was a bit sweet for me. I think next time I'll cut the sugar a little.

I've never coated a bread pan in cinnamon/sugar before & WOW! It's really amazing. It created this crispy layer on the outside that gives the "crust" an unbelievably yummy texture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tough for me since I've been using a different recipe for YEARS and everyone said it was great. Well, today I randomly tried this one (mostly because I had SO many ripe bananas) and my husband now insists I stick with THIS recipe. 
This is a HUGE amount-- i made two loaves plus six big muffins out of it.  But not too much butter, which is nice. I suppose I will halve the recipe next time. I think you could probably go a little lighter on the sugar, but it is pretty tasty this way. The other thing is that I was out of sour cream. So I went with greek yogurt-- about half vanilla greek yogurt and the other half plain. I did add a bit of nutmeg and probably could have added a full teaspoon. My loaves started browning a little fast so I covered them with tin foil. I stuck with the tried and true wooden skewer test for doneness rather than using the time-- and I think my oven was a little hot too. In any case, the texture was perfect.

Great recipe!  I followed other contributors suggestions and  cooked at 325 degrees for nearly 1.5 hours.  But I only made 1 large bundt cake and 1 other small loaf with the batter.  I did cover them the last 25 minutes to avoid having the tops overcook.  I added nuts and raisins. It got raves from the family.  Moist and tasty.

This was the moistest banana bread I've ever made!!! it was so soft and delicious!! I made 3, 7 1/2 by 4ish loaves and then 12 muffins, so it made a ton! Display Name:
