https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2358558.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yes, I would make this again.  Somehow i goofed and used four eggs plus only had a half container of sour cream but it made no diff.  Spiced rum replaced vanilla and i used a full tsp of salt.  Toasted the chopped nuts and added 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice along with 1 tsp cinnamon. Sounds like lots of changes but I've bee stirring up many loaves of banana bread thru my life and I know what we like.  Oh, another change was to sub one cup of white whole wheat flour for all purpose.  I think it could have been up to half with no taste difference. My hubby likes to eat whole wheat so that way I could say that yes, it has whole wheat :-). As others said, you should 'probly loosely cover the loaves with a sheet of tin foil after half the baking time. These baked 50 min in 325 degree oven but please, always check several times before time is up.

text:
This was really good. Omitted the nuts.  Cut the recipe in half and filled a 9 x5 loaf pan. Didn't change the cinnamon/sugar topping amount. Used it for dusting the bottom of the pan and the rest put it on top before baking. Baked it for one hour in a glass pan at 325 then tented it with foil and reduced the temp to 300 until a knife put through the center came out clean about an additional 20 minutes. It was so moist and delicious.

text:
I made 2 of the 9x5 loaves with this recipe. I cooked it at 300 for 75 minutes.  I took it to school for the first day of class and my students --all college students--couldn't believe their teacher would make them homemade bread. The loaf was gone almost instantly. I even cut the slices down the middle, and they all took seconds. My family loved it and I loved how moist it was. The only change to the recipe was that I used pecans instead of walnuts, because it's what I had on hand.

text:
This was fantastic! Very moist but also very sweet. I'd decrease the sugar a bit next time (my bananas were extremely ripe and probably added extra sweetness). I divided the batter in half-  made one with chocolate chips and pecans, the other plain banana, both were great. I didn't bake@300° rather, I divided the batter and placed in two brownie pans and baked @350° for 30 min.
*Update: added peanut butter, about 1/4 to  1/3 cup, gave it a nice hint not too overwhelmingly peanut buttery taste.

country:
None
text:
This is, by far, the best banana bread I have ever made.  I divide it into 2 large loaf pans and add extra batter to one mini loaf.   I cut the sugar down to 1 1/2 cups and it's still plenty sweet.  3 cups is way too much sugar!  I have made it with the sour cream and it's great but I also substituted it with full fat plain yogurt and my family liked the result better.  Everything else I leave the same!  Don't skip out on that sugar/cinnamon dusting of the loaf pans...it adds a nice crusty crunch that's unexpected and delightful!:). Great recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at a banana bread and I absolutely love it!!!!! It was moist and indeed melted in your mouth. After reading the reviews however, I decided to tweek the recipe a bit. I substituted the 3/4 cup butter with 1/4 cup butter and 1/2 cup oil and instead of 3 tsp baking soda, I used 2 tsp baking soda and 1 tsp baking powder. Took less than an hour to bake so I didn't experience the issues other reviewers had with the uncooked middle..... My only issue is that 3 cups sugar is wayyyy too much so in ny next attempt, I'm cutting that down to 1 1/2 cups seeing as the bananas have a sweetness of its own.

text:
My new go-to banana bread recipe!  I halved the recipe and it made one very large loaf... and three very large muffins (from the 6 muffin pan).  Might even have been able to do 4 muffins.  Loaf took right around an hour, and I pulled the muffins around 45 min.  (Maybe slightly less time on the muffins next time.)  Otherwise, made exactly as written - and delicious!  2/10/2016: Eating one loaf that we had frozen from the fall - amazing!  Have to say it again... probably the best banana bread I've ever had.  So moist, lots of flavor.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THE BEST BANANA BREAD!!!  I have made this recipe twice and it is quite delicious!!!  My friends and family just love it.  I can't make it fast enough.  They keep asking when I'll be baking it again.  The only thing I did different was I added a teaspoon of banana extract to the ingredients.  I still put in the 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract as the recipe calls for.  I wanted to be sure the banana flavor would be there.  It was perfect, just the right amount of banana flavor.  I did turn the oven up to 325 degrees and lengthened the cooking time to an hour and fifteen minutes because I used larger loaf pans. You may have to adjust cooking time according to your own oven.   This is the best banana bread recipe I've ever tasted.  It is so moist and please don't omit the dusting of the pans with the cinnamon and sugar mixture because it gives the bottom and sides of the loaf added flavor.

I have made this recipe several times and it's a BIG hit when I do. This bread is sooo moist without being too sweet. I do not make any changes to the recipe, except to add choc chips to a portion of it at times, depending on who I'm making it for. I have also used part of the recipe for small loaves and part of it for muffins. The muffins are easier to ship to my kids in college. The kids LOVE getting that surprise and the muffins stay moist for many days. If you love banana bread I highly recommend this recipe as its written

text:
I have been making this banana bread for years and haven't used any other recipes since.  Everyone loves this recipe!!  My daycare children will even bring me bananas so that I will make it and they can take some home!  I put bananas in the freezer when they start to get a little to ripe for eating then I take them out and let them defrost in the refrigerator.  Yes they will look so nasty but they are extra sweet and make the most amazing banana bread.  I read one of the comments on the recipe about the baking time and the temp of the oven.  I honestly don't ever set the timer...i just test the loaves with a cake tester until it is done.  I also wrap the loaves in plastic wrap after they cool and the become so moist and irresistible.
Hope my post was helpful!!

region:

country:
None
text:
Healthier version & just like my mother made:
This turns out even better if you substitute 2 of the cups of white flour with whole wheat flour (leaving 2 1/2 cups as white.)  And if you also replace 1 cup of the white sugar with dark brown sugar, it tastes deeper, richer.  325 degrees between 50 mins & 1 hr 10 minutes, depending on loaf pan size.  I used all medium & small, no full size pans. Don't fill pans too full, since this is dense bread.  Refrigerate loaves.  Tastes gourmet!

My husband made this banana bread.  He is really the backer in the house.  It was outstanding.  We gave the loaves to a sick friend and it was a welcomed treat for them.  It was moist, not undercooked.  I always check my oven temp before I use it.  I always eyeball and toothpick test before I take anything out of the oven.  This bread baked in a little more than an hour, but I checked it every 8 minutes or so there after. We did use regular loaf pans and recipe made 2 loaves. This will be my go to recipe for banana bread.  Thanks for sharing Esther! and Thanks SaraLady19 for the info on pan and time changes.

text:
The recipe as written is great. To cut down on some of the fat I substituted yogurt for the sour cream. I have used plain,vanilla and peach flavored yogurt..all were loved by my family. You might want to cut back on the sugar if you use a flavored/sweetened yogurt. When I used the pea h yogurt I I cut back 1 banana and used some diced canned peaches in place of that banana.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe.  I've made banana bread in the past, several recipes all pretty tasty.  This was the first time I used sour cream in making banana bread, and I was pleasantly surprised how well it turned out.   I did very slightly tweak the recipe after reading reviews especially SaraLady19's.  

-- 1.  I used 1tsp cinnamon & 1tsp all spice --- 2. I turned this into muffins (made 3.5 - 4dz regular sized muffins).  --- 3. I did bake at 325 for 20-25 for muffins.  --- 4.  I used the electric beater, and loved having a lighter cake fluffy muffin which Sara Lady did mention would happen.   --- 5. I mixed in pb chips, and chocolate chips into some of the muffins after I made 2dz regular ones.---6. I made the crumble topping SaraLady19 mentioned (it was very good!) 

-- Side Note: make sure you use a really large bowl, I had to transfer before adding in the flour to a very large bowl I use when making bread.  --

text:
This is the only banana bread recipe that is moist and fresh-tasting the next day, although it rarely makes it to the next day.  The sour cream keeps the bread moist, and adds exceptional flavor.  I have a small family of 3, so I made only a third of the original recipe.  This made one loaf, and 4 nice sized banana muffins.  To top off this recipe, I added a 1/2 tsp of nutmeg, which was a splendid idea, if I don't say so myself ;)  I used real butter to grease my pans, and sprinkled on the sugar mixture which makes the sweetest most delectable crust ever!!!  I will use this from now on in all of my breads and pastries.  I must go have a slice now...  Thank you for this javascript:void(0);wonderfully tasty and moist recipe!!  One more thing...  I have substituted the sour cream with greek yogurt when I ran out of sour cream, and the results are great, as well!  Great way to add protein to my meat-hating children.

text:
I only had 2 bananas so had to cut this recipe in thirds. Also used 4 small foil loaf pans (the kind you get in your Christmas goody basket from Aunt Edna) instead of larger loaf pans & since I'd read several reviews that said this recipe was too sweet I sprayed & floured them instead of using the cinnamon sugar mixture to coat them. 
The banana bread turned out moist, tender & flavorful. I like it a lot & will absolutely make this again. Maybe for my Christmas goody baskets....:D
Making it again tonight. Had 3 bananas this time so I did 1/2 recipe this time & used 2 loaf pans size 3 X 7. I can tell I'll be making this a lot.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3422281.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe.  I made some large loaf so I increased the temp to 325 as someone suggested because I did not want a doughy center.  They came out beautiful.  I would just change the cinnamon/sugar grease pan coat to just a greased/flour coat because the sugar tends to cook quicker than the bread itself, increasing the chance of over doneness on the outside.  Overall a super moist and delicious bread.  It yields quite a bit doughy batter so hope you have a really large bowl.  It helps to cream the sugar/butter in a processor and combine the dry ingredients in a separate bowl, of course.  Wet and banana ingredients were in a third bowl.  Combine all of the ingredients in a super large bowl.

text:
Wonderful recipe. I cut the recipe in half (but using 2 eggs) and used one 9x5 ceramic loaf pan. At 300, I found that I had to bake for about 1 hour 45 minutes (possibly due to ceramic vs. metal). Following other suggestions I topped with a cinnamon crumble (sugar, cinnamon, flour, butter)  before baking and it melted into the middle of the loaf making it even more delicious. I found that dusting the loaf pan with sugar and cinnamon after greasing, not only gave it a crisp outer edge, but also helped it to slide right out of the pan. Thank you for the recipe. Definitely one I will make again.

The reviews on this had me nervous. So many mentioned it not baking evenly, having a mushy middle, bad consistency, etc. I followed the recipe closely, changing only the amount of sugar (2 cups instead of 3). I used two large loaf pans - 11+ by 5+ because that's all I had on hand (EZfoil). One hour and 10 minutes later, perfect banana bread - perfect consistency, fabulous taste. All in all, very easy to make and totally worth it.

Awesome recipe, I made this exactly as written, and the second time i made it i made i wanted a more healthy banana bread so i made these adjustments, I used only whole wheat flour, I added 3 TBS of ground flax seeds, 1 teaspoon of nutmeg,  extra 1/4 teaspoon of salt because of the whole wheat flour, an extra banana ( be sure to use really brown banana's ) and kept the rest of the ingredients the same.  Awesome Awesome! My husband who can't stand it when I use whole wheat flour didn't even notice the difference!

text:
Unbelievable!  I made it with the recipe and Saralady19's tweaks.  Brought one loaf to a friend as a thank you and another to work and now I have multiple people asking me when I am going to make banana bread again.  The one change I made to Saralady 19's tweak was that I baked the bread for 10-15 minutes, then added the topping so the topping would stay set on top.  I froze the batter for the other two loaves and baked them later.  They come out great - as if I just mixed them up.  Simply put the frozen batter in the refrigerator the night before and allow it to thaw naturally, then bake the next day.

text:
This is the best banana bread Ive ever tasted. However, every time I make it the cook time varies and I never know if it will turn out mushy, dry or just right. Who has a 7 x 3" loaf pan? Trying to guesstimate how much bake time is needed is frustrating and i never get it just right. Reviewers on the site suggest increasing the temperature to 325 degrees and/or extending the bake time. I wish the owner of this recipe would rewrite it using the more common 8 x 4" or 9 x 5" loaf pans and adjust the time and temp accordingly. Yes, I know about using a cake tester. 
Sorry about the 3 stars but trying to figure out when the loaves are done is always a shot in the dark.

I was planning on keeping one and taking one to work, key word being WAS.  After tasting it my loaf, I threw that bad boy in the freezer to keep for myself! This is the banana bread recipe I've been searching for all my life.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
make sure not to completely mix dry ingredients to wet like you would a cake. Instead use the muffin method; make a ''well'' in the centre of the dry ingredients, add the wet, and gently fold just until the wet ingredients coat the dry. you want to make sure you have lumps of flour, not smooth. over mixing causes a dry, tough, odd shaped product. I learned this from my friend. Excellent bread!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-01-05T16:47:30.323

city:

region:

country:

text:
This is delicious.  This year we "made" Christmas.  I made a loaf of this bread to add to every relative's gift basket and for each of my child's teachers (I did mini loaves for my son's teachers as he is in middle school and we had a LOT of teachers, assistant teachers and administrators) - we also made chocolate drizzled popcorn.  Because we made SO much of this recipe, I froze the loaves until we were ready to make the baskets.  They freeze/thaw out nicely.  I will do this again next year.  We got so many compliments on it.  I did what the other reviewer suggested and added a topping: brown sugar (1/2 cup), flour (1/2 cup) and walnuts (1/3 cup), 3 tbsp butter and 1 tsp cinnamon mixed and crumbled over top of bread to bake.  When I ran out of tins I had some pretty tulip shaped muffin tins and I made some of those, too... they puffed up beautifully.  I am on my way to make more of this now for breakfast tomorrow.  YUM!

text:
Very good! I followed the recipe exactly. Be careful not to fill the pans too much, the bread will rise quite a bit. It may be because I am high altitude that my pans overflowed, but maybe not, so be careful. I did 1-1/2 the recipe and baked some in mini loaf pans and some in large pans. If you do 1-1/2 the recipe, make sure you have a VERY big mixing bowl, I mean VERY big! The cooking time was considerably more for large pans, but that is to be expected. Very good recipe, no need to "tweak".

text:
We love this recipe. I usually do cookies for my father and husband for Christmas to take to work but this year I am WAY to pregnant to mess with all that. So I thought I would do bread instead. I followed the recipe for the most part. I used 3 tsps of vanilla instead of 2 and used pecans instead of walnuts ( I have never had walnuts in banana bread ). 

I used a mini loaf pan instead of regular sized loaf pans and baked for 18-20 minutes. I re greased the pan and dusted with the sugar and cinnamon mixture for each batch and used about 1/4 of a cup batter for each mini loaf cavity. These came out prefect sized to fit into little treat bags after they cooled completely. They are absolutely delicious: very moist, not to sweet.

text:
I didn't believe this recipe would be any different than my previous favourite banana bread recipe. I was very wrong. This recipe is perfectly balanced. It is light, tasty, and by far the best banana bread I've ever made. I made a few changes but I am sure it would be just as good without them. I substituted greek yogurt for sour cream, added a 1/8 tsp of cloves and a 1/4 tsp of baking powder. I added the powder because I prefer a less dense bread. I regret not trying this recipe years ago... so just go ahead and make it and enjoy. Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
I did not read any other reviews prior to making this Banana Sour Cream Bread or prior to writing this review. 

I only utilized 5 bananas as that is what I had on hand, and that was perfectly appropriate. I used real vanilla extract with the actual vanilla beans in it, which gives the bread tiny bits of crunch (much like poppy seeds). I did use walnuts. I did not have 7 x 3 bread pans, so I used Wilton Professional 9 x 5 pans. I did have to bake the loaves for approximately 40 minutes longer (nearly 1.75 hourS) to get them to come out appropriately at the same temperature setting. I should have turned up the heat.

Regardless, the bread was absolutely wonderful, moist, tasty and I will make it again, likely in 9 x 5 loaves. I took it to a potluck, and it was a hit. The recipe makes a large volume of bread (Two huge, very full 9 x 5 loaves).

text:
The only reason I'm giving this a 4* is because I think a few things in the recipe need to be tweaked.  I added, (Mexican)vanilla, allspice and a hint of nutmeg and 2 drop of lemon  to the recipe.  Instead of baking @ 300 I chose 350 and cut the baking time down by about 15 mins.  Other than that the recipe comes out perfect everytime.  Also I do this recipe in batches of two using two full eggs instead of 1 1/2.I also bake it in the oven over a cookie sheet with water. It comes out very moist and light.  It will not last 2 days.  So make sure you plan to make more before the last piece is eaten:)

userID:

Display Name:
EROSPERT
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've used this recipe ever since I discovered it. However, I can tell you it never comes out the same twice. Over the years I've discovered that it all has to do with the size of your bananas and eggs. When I've used large bananas and only had extra large eggs on hand, this bread doesn't turn out when the recipe is used as posted.  There is too much moisture/fat and the bread doesn't rise nicely. If the batter is very light in color while it's baking I can be guaranteed that the loaves won't turn out and will be heavy like bricks. I've thrown many loaves out. I've tried using extra large eggs with smaller bananas and using 1-1/2 to 1-3/4 cups sour cream and had good luck with that. I'll continue to use this recipe even if I haven't tweaked it to perfection. The flavor is perfect and if you can get the moisture/fat content right it's delicious. My family can't get enough of it.
Review:
Rating:
5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1049420.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had a problem with this recipe. I grew my own bananas and needed a recipe for making a lot of banana bread for freezing. I followed the recipe very closely and therein lies the problem. How much banana? For this recipe it depends completely on which type of banana you use, now doesn't it. I grew Lady Finger bananas which are about 2inches shorter than the length of the normal Chiquita brand found in stores but much sweeter. So the fact that only the number of bananas is given and not a measured amount is problematic in the outcome. The main issue is that one look in the bowl after mixing and I knew I did not have four pans worth. As I stood and scratched, I could see almost two full loaves or three very skinny loves but in no way would there be four loaves to fit the pans. So, in the absence of a measured amount, I added two more bananas mashed. I filled two 7x3 pans allowing for rising. In the end I got just these two loaves. I can't imagine how many bananas it would have taken to make two more whole loaves. The quality of the resulting product was average, nothing to get excited about. But I did use up a portion of the banana bunch, which all come ripe at the same time. So, I'll keep looking and see if I can find a recipe that has a measured amount of bananas and compare this recipe to that one.

text:
I loved this recipe. I did cut it back a bit. I made muffins instead of loaves. I used 2 cups of sugar, 1/2 stick of butter, 1 stick of Parkay, 1 tsp vanilla, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice, 2 cups flour, 1/4 tsp of salt, 2 tsp baking soda, 1 cup light sour cream, 4 bananas, 2 eggs, and I added in a package of Martha White Banana Nut packaged mix. No walnuts or sprinkling of the sugar and cinnamon in the baking pan. I just used baking spray. I almost cooked them a bit too long at 350, so make sure you watch the oven. They are moist and delicious!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/379157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not sure if I should give this recipe 4 or 5 stars. The original version is way too sweet for my taste, and even when I cut the sugar in half, it was still very sweet. Next time, I'll just use 1 cup of sugar, just right for my preference.
I like the generous amount of bananas, I used very ripe ones, and the banana taste was delicious. I used only 4 Tbsp of butter, and 1/2 cup applesauce, whole wheat flour, and low-fat sour cream, and I added a brown sugar crumb topping. It came out wonderful.
I baked the bread as one huge loaf (I don't recommend this unless you have a really big cake tin, because the bread rises quite a bit), and it took 2 hrs and 15 min at 325 degrees to be done just right.
Thanks for sharing this wonderful recipe!

None
text:
I had to change this recipe slightly, so I give it 4 stars.  The way I made it came out spectacular, so I saved a custom private copy to my recipe box.  This recipe yields 2 loaves if you use an 8x4 or larger loaf pan.  I increased the temp to 325 degrees Fahrenheit, and increase the cook time by 15 extra minutes.  I covered the bread with aluminum foil for the last additional 15 minutes to prevent the top from burning.  Also I didn't quite have 16 oz of sour cream so I used 8 oz sour cream and 8 oz vanilla yogurt, roughly.  I eyeballed this ingredient amount.  Great recipe thanks you!

text:
Great!  I only had 8 oz. sour cream and added about 4 oz, vanilla yogurt. Also added about 1/2 cup more flour as batter seemed  too runny. Also used chopped pecans , no walnuts on hand.  Put 1 tsp baking powder as well, and did topping with brown sugar/cinnamon on top. I used baking powder as well as baking soda because I had read on review it didn't rise quite enough.  Rose great! I think it also depends on size & ripeness of bananas.  Mine were large and dark skinned so pretty liquid when mashed!

text:
I made this banana bread this morning and it was awesome.  I used this recipe as a base because I have to eat gluten free.  The changes I made were 1) 2 cups GF Bisquick + 2 1/2 c rice flour in place of the regular flour (one box of GF  Bisquick only holds 2 cups..Who knew?) 2) I only had 5 extremely ripe bananas, so I stirred in 2 single serving cups of cinnamon applesauce (about 1 cup). 3)  The GF Bisquick already has the salt and baking powder in it but the rice flour did not so I added 1/2 the baking powder and salt called for in the recipe 4) One of the reviewers said to blend the flour into the wet ingredients by hand because doing it with a mixer makes it more cake like so OF COURSE I used the hand mixer to blend all the ingredients.  Any little bit helps when cooking GF!  5) I  skipped the cinnamon sugar dusting and just greased my pans really well.  6) I stirred in an ENTIRE bag of chocolate chips (remember, this makes four loaves!).  7) I only had one regular loaf pan and 3 smaller ones, so the regular loaf pan wasn't quite full, but the others were.  I adjusted the temperature per another reviewer to 325 and set the timer for an hour.  I had all four loaves in the oven at once.  2 of the smaller ones were done at about 50 minutes and the 1 semi full larger one and other smaller one took an additional 5 minutes.  Hands down the BEST GF Banana Bread EVER.  My family (who does NOT have to eat GF) devoured two loaves! I had planned on freezing three of them....lol.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-03-18T05:09:10.603

country:
None
text:
I don't usually like to make banana bread--always turns out underdone and mushy for me, despite cooking much longer than recommended.  This recipe turned out great.  I halved the recipe and made two loaves (using 2 eggs).  A prior post recommended 325 deg for 75 minutes.  My oven cooks a bit hot, so I checked at 55 minutes--the toothpick was clean and they were done!  After cooling, both loaves easily came out of the pan--no chunks of left-behind mushy bread.  I had added the brown sugar crumble topping, and the taste is quite good.  This will be a go-to banana bread recipe.

text:
I tried the recipe...and I am soooo in love with this one! 
It certainly is a keeper. Like some I too had a concern about the creaming of the sugar and the butter and the Temp and Time. I just thought it was me being anxious to get these bananas going. As I have waisted afew bananas in my time. Of course with the best of intentions to making bread. And not having the butter at room temp. is my fault. Getting back to the results of my Bread...Wonderful. Longer than 1 hour baking time. I used a larger set of pans {8 by 4's?} The recipe made two loaves then with the bit left over I made 3 small sized loaves for my daughter and added semi sweet mini chips. She loved it. In fact, I baked them in my toaster over at 300 as not to interupt my reg oven. Just awesome. And in closing, I guess they would of been over the top if they had the nuts in there but my Husband likes them without so thats the way I baked THIS batch. LOL I may do a NUT overload next batch. Thanks for the recipe and look forward to making Holiday cookies next!

country:
None
text:
We LOVED this recipe. I had 8 bananas, so I used them all. I cut back the sugar by 1/3, and then used light brown sugar for 1/3 of the remaining sugar. (1 1/3c white, 2/3c brown). Also, with the additional bananas, I felt like the batter was a bit wet, so I added nearly 1 cup more flour. I baked it at 350, rather than 300. It was excellent! The sugar and cinnamon in the pan really added a nice extra crust to the outside. A great recipe for sharing!

text:
The taste of this banana bread is phenomenal.. this is the best one i have found on this site.  The only thing I didn't like is that the bread didn't rise.  It wasn't the fault of any of the ingredients, I just don't think it's meant to.  I filled the pans about 2/3 full. The texture is perfect.  This time I halved all the ingredients (except I used 2 eggs), and used 2 regular sized bread loaves. Next time I may increase the ingredients and fill the pans almost to the top, since they don't rise.  I wouldn't skip the dusting of cinnamon sugar.. I loved this part! Thanks for the great recipe!

I made this pretty much exactly as written except I didn't have the same size pans. I used 3-8x4 pans and baked them at 350 for 55 minutes in a convection oven. My only criticism is that I'm not so much a fan of cinnamon and banana together. It's not bad, but the next time I make this I think I'll leave the cinnamon out. I love the two separately but not together. Otherwise it has great texture and flavor, and will definitely make it again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this bread 100 times, and it has never failed me.  I do, however, agree with the baking time and oven temp.  If you use a loaf pan that is not deep, the time and temp should be ok.  I, however, used a pan with four loaf compartments.  Since this is a very dense bread, I cooked for 1hr/45min on 300, then covered the loaves with tin foil and turned up the temp to 350 for 15.  This seemed to do the trick.  I used half the sugar and 1/2 whole wheat flour.  Also a small container of applesauce to sub for some of the butter.  DELISH!  LB fromGlenRock

text:
This recipe was absolutely delicious!!  I had left over bananas that were going bad if i didnt use them so i found this recipe.  I only had about 8 oz of sour cream so i substituted the remaining 8 oz with approx 8 oz of sweetened condensed milk and it was outstanding.  I only had 2 loaf pans so I added about a cup of semi sweet chocolate chips to the rest of the batter and placed in muffin cups.  I put cream cheese frosting on the muffins and took them to my husbands work and they all cant stop asking for more.... I will be making this again and again!!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, this bread was amazing! I thought it was quite odd adding the sour cream but boy was I wrong, it turned out great. I had 8 x 4 loaf pans so I managed to fill up three. The instructions do not inlcude how much to fill the pans so for a first time baker this can be confusing. I filled them up about 3/4 of the way and they turned out perfect, however if you try to bake them all at the same time plan on adding about 15-20 minutes more. I actually baked them all together for an hour and they were not done so I stuck them in one at a time for 5 minutes more and then did the trick. Thanks for sharing a great recipe!

This was a fantastic recipe.  I took the advice of some of the other reviewers - cutting the recipe in half and used 6 oz greek yogurt, 3/4 cup of sugar, 1 cup of whole wheat flour (1 1/4 all purpose flour), 2 tsp of cinnamon and 4 well ripe bananas.  I baked in at 325 degrees for one hour.  Thank you to Esther and a few others for the great tips.

text:
I made this, substituting a cup of molasses and a cup of brown sugar for two of the cups of white sugar, which made for a darker batter.  I used light sour cream without any ill effects.  I made this in a bundt cake pan, and I added chopped walnuts to the batter.  I substituted sweet sorghum flour and rice flour and a half-teaspoon of Xanthan gum for the wheat flour to make it gluten free.  It still rose and made for a great bread/cake.  I mixed everything in an electric stand mixer.    Cooking time takes longer than an hour.  Check it in the middle with a toothpick, and keep cooking 15 minutes extra, recheck with toothpick, and repeat until the toothpick comes out clean.  Mine took an hour and 40 minutes.

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe over and over again.  It never fails me!  It's become expected that I bring it to my department's potlucks and nobody else dares to attempt banana bread!  My family looks forward to the holidays when I show up with little loafs for each of them.  It is, by far, the best banana bread recipe I have ever tasted.  I can't understand some of the reviewers that had issues with it as I have baked it so many times, in so many different pan types.  The only person that didn't like it, doesn't like bananas!  If you know ANYTHING at all about baking, adjusting the temp and times for varied pan sizes is quite simple.  And I'm a novice baker.  In conclusion, if the recipe fails, it's YOU not the recipe!!

text:
I just finished making this (I made it into a 3 story cake instead of loaves) and it is great! And really very easy! I´ll definitely do this recipe again. Though next time I´ll use less sugar (I highly recommend this...it was a little bit too sweet for my taste) and make less servings. I used 2 1/2 white flour and 2 wheat flour; also, I combined white and brown sugar, added some nutmeg, and used more than the 2 teaspoons of cinnamon. Everything turned out great :)

text:
The best banana bread I've ever made!!! I did two small things differently:  1 - Sprinkled more cinnamon and sugar on top of the uncooked loaves. 2 - After cooking at 300 for an hour, I turned up the oven to 325 for another 10 minutes since, as #3 states, "Back for 1 hour, until a toothpick inserted in center comes out clean," and mine did not.  With the additional time at a higher temp, they were perfect!

text:
Delicious! In an attempt to make it a bit more healthy, I used 2 1/2 cups white flour, 2 cups whole wheat flour. I reduced the sugar to 2 cups. I also used low fat sour cream. To counterbalance all this hard work, I then added mini chocolate chips rather than walnuts. Result: Heaven! My fiance would have eaten the whole loaf if I hadn't have stopped him!  *Side note: I made 2 loaves and 12 muffins out of this recipe. I took someone else's recommendation and baked the loaves at 325 for 1 hour 10 minutes, the muffins took 45 minutes. Turned out perfect!

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe sounded amazing and with such a high rating, I thought I couldn't go wrong.  too much sugar, too much flour, and the cooking temp is so not right!  When I took this out of the oven, it was completely raw in the center and done on the edges.  I bumped it up to 375 and cooked for another 20 minutes.  I ended up with 4 loaves of bread with moist, perfect centers and overcooked edges.  The taste is okay, but not how I like my banana bread.  Will not use again, but if you use this recipe, cook at 350 for maybe 1hr 15 min and cut back on the sugar!

text:
This is PHENOMENAL!! All our family and friends love it! And I make it for them every two weeks or so (it's that good!) I've tried a bunch of different banana bread recipes and this one is by far the best. I don't change anything about the actual bread, but I do use Saralady19's topping of butter, brown sugar, cinnamon, and flour, and I make home made whipped cream on the side for each person to top their piece with - 2 cups whipping cream, 1/2 cup sugar, 2 teaspoons vanilla.  Thanks for this amazing recipe! :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This Banana bread is fantastic. My husband doesn't care for banana bread but went crazy over this recipe! I halved the recipe & made 2 loaves. I used 3.5 large bananas & just sort of squished them in my hands for a few seconds so I didn't completely mash them up. But the chunks in the bread made it even better! I didn't feel like using 1 1/2 eggs so I just used 2 eggs. I used light sour cream & also used half splenda and half white sugar. I left the 2 loaves in at 300 degrees for 1 hour, rotating the loaves in the oven half way. I also lightly covered the loaf pans with foil after 40 minutes. Wonderful, wonderful, Wonderful!

Best banana bread I've ever made!  Loved the texture. Used 2 c. white sugar & 1 c. light brown sugar.  Substituted mini chocolate chips for nuts due to allergies.  I only had regular-sized loaf pans, so I adjusted oven temp to 325° and watched closely toward end of cooking time.  Perfectly browned but not quite done at 1 hr; covered lightly with foil and baked an additional 7 minutes.  Made 3 regular loaves & 6 muffins.

userID:

Display Name:
1stephanie
isPro:

2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/900597.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of the BEST loaf/breads I have in my arsenal now.  LIke many, I made changes to suit our lifestyle & taste.  We eat a certain way and one serving of this bread & a glass of milk or piece of fruit make a meal of us (we eat 4/5 meals, approx 4oo c. each throughout the day.   I have calculated each serving to be approx 305cal.    3 loaves @ 10 serves each.  2 tbsp butter + 1/4 c applesauce  1 1/2 C. Br sugar Splenda  Bananaa remain the same - 6  16 oz container Fat Free sour cream  vanilla, cinnamon, salt, soda - same  4 1/3 c. Nutriblend flour (in Canada - like W.W. pastry flour)  2 C. chopped walnuts  2 C. semisweet Choc Chips   (@ 30 servings, the nuts & choc. works out to 2 tbps. per serving, which is exactly what I intended)    I put a little cinnamon/sugar mixture on the bottom/ sides of the pans (after coating them with Pam Baking (flour) spray, but I don't find it necessary.  This bread is FABULOUS and stands on it's own as a cut above others.  Freezes   incredibly well and is really moist.      Be prepared to let cool (try some :) - cut in to servings and individually wrap w/ seran, freeze and have to eat when you want ...   All the best ...

I halved this recipe and it made 4 mini loaves of bread.  I cannot say that this recipe is bad or I disliked it, but I didn't like the cinnamon in it and I thought it had way too much sugar.  I did like the addition of sour cream as it does make it very moist.  It also seemed like it took a long time to bake as most breads are baked at 350.  I will go back to my tried and true banana recipe bread (not on this site) and experiment with the addition of sour cream to moisten it up.

Wonderful! I made this for a EcoPeace event at my college, so I lowered the sugar to 2 cups, and added some wheat germ to the mixture used to flour the pans, as well as to the mix itself. Fantastic recipe! The cinnamon sugar on the pan was such a delicious addition! I increased to 7 bananas and substituted 2c whole wheat flour and 2.5c AP flour for all white flour. I made the full recipe in 2 loaf pans and a 4 mini loaf pan which was great for teacher gifts. I baked the mini loaves 45 mins and the big loaves 1hr. 15mins. Delicious and not too bad for you :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this bread! I made for our church but I only have one loaf pan so I did the rest in muffins. I did make two changes however. Since I was making muffins I only put in 2 tsp of baking powder and added 3/4 tsp of cream of tarter. They puffed up pretty well, and they were really fluffy tasting. I just put them in with the loaf at 325 and they went for about 25-30 min and when the second batch of muffins came out the bread was done too. I also saw the review to add walnuts, I am not the biggets fan of them, so I added 1 cup crushed pecans. Oh they are good in there. And my five year old eliminates things from his diet regularl, he is now a vegitarian while we  are all meat lovers, and he loves these. I am going to make these all the time and freeze them for his breakfast.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe!  I made half the recipe and used wide-mouth pint size glass canning jars to bake it.  (Add lid when slightly cooled and they make great gifts!)  I will use a little less cinnamon next time as I'm not a huge cinnamon fan.  I decreased the sugar by half a cup, increased the vanilla by 1/2 tsp, added 1/2 tsp almond extract and used 1 cup of pecans.  This bread rose a lot more than I'd expected (maybe b/c my sour cream had been opened for a few days) so be sure to leave plenty of room for rising.  (Mine overflowed the jars and filled the oven with smoke!!)  Even with my oven mishap this bread came out great!

text:
Great bread!I've tried many banana bread recipes and this one is by far the BEST! I did decrease the sugar to only 2 cups and it was plenty sweet enough. I also used Rapadura instead of white sugar to make it healthier. I only put in 4 bananas instead of 6 because that's all I had and it was fine. Next time I will try it with the full amount. I used 2  9 by 5 glass pans filled 3/4 full and with the rest of the batter I filled 6 mini rectangular muffin pans. I baked those for about 40 minutes and the      9 by 5s for 1 hour all at 325 degrees. I frooze some for my husbands lunch for a later date and I'm glad I did because he loved the bread and can't wait till I make some more. Thanks for the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe makes a pretty good, moist banana nut bread! But like a lot of people who gave lower ratings, I had a lot of trouble trying to get the bread to bake all the way at 300 deg for an hour. I had to let it sit in there for 300 deg for 1.5 hours and the top started to get too crisp so I turned it down to 280 for another half hour. Took about 2 hours total but still turned out pretty good.  Also, I noticed it's easier to mash the bananas PRIOR to mixing in with the rest of the recipe.

text:
Wonderful recipe.  I used 8oz fat-free sour cream and 8oz lite sour cream, and it was very moist.  Sprayed pans with Pam and then sprinkled 1/2 the sugar mixture on bottom and sides.  Other 1/2 of sugar sprinkled on top of the loaf once poured into pans.  Instead of mixing the walnuts in I put them on top of batter with the sugar mixture.  They rose perfectly and tasted fabulous.  Definitely a keeper!

text:
This is the best banana nut bread I've ever had since it's perfectly moist. Instead of using the full amount of sugar, I used 1/3 of what is called for and the rest was splenda (full scale: 1 cup sugar, 2 cups splenda). I also used light sour cream and cut out the salt. It comes out perfectly after an hour. This is a very easy recipe even when you scale it down to one loaf.

text:
I printed this recipe years ago. I make it often throughout the year. During the holidays I end up making it about 2-3 times per week! My husband (and his friends) love it, so do the kids. I have never had problems making this recipe. I also spinkle the cinnamon & sugar on the top and then spinkle some more walnuts in a row on top before baking. The recipe makes 9 of the small or mini loafs, I've also make 3 mini loafs and the rest in a small rectangle (my brownie) pan. Then I cut it into 4 loafs. I love this recipe, it's my all time favorite from this site. Thank you!

text:
I accidentally sort of massacred this recipe, and it still came out fantastically. I wanted to halve it, but I ended up using 1/2 cup butter. I also used brown sugar Splenda blend, about 6 oz of yogurt in place of the sour cream, and two large bananas. I also added some oats instead of the nuts. Baked at 350 for 65 minutes in a 9x5" pan.

text:
I had sour cream and banana so I was searching for a recipe which contain these two main ingrediants! I tried this recipe and It is really wonderful! This bread is really soft, moist, light! I took half of the ingrediants and I deduce little amount of suger. Recipe suggested 1-1/2 cup suger and I used 1 cup + 1 table spoon suger also 1-1/2 eggs were suggested I took 2 eggs and It came fluffy and perfect sweet. Everybody Loved it! I don't eat cakes usually but I had one bite of it and I gobble another one :)! Its delicious! Thank you for a wonderful recipe!

text:
These loaves were really moist and my husband is saying this is the best banana bread I've ever made.  A few changes that I made: I used 3 standard loaf pans and baked at 325 for 1 hour and 10 minutes. Unlike other reviewers, the loaves were perfectly cooked, not doughy.  I didn't have sour cream so I used non-fat plain yogurt, I added 2 tsp. of nutmeg and 1 tsp. of cloves.  Thanks for the great recipe, I will make this again!

text:
This is a FANTASTIC banana nut bread! I made nine 5 and 5/8'' X 3 and 3/16'' X 1 and 15/16'' mini loaf pans with the above recipe. It is so moist and flavorful! The dusting of cinnamon sugar on the pans creates a wonderful flavor around the edges of the bread. This was the first time I have ever made banana nut bread and I cannot believe how easy it was. I gave the loaves out as gifts and have received rave reviews and EVERYONE wants the recipe. I kept one for us to try before we gave them as gifts and my husband devoured it! Again, this is a wonderful recipe and so easy a beginner, like myself, can create something delicious in the kitchen!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious bread but I messed it up.  First of all I halved the recipe and made two loaves.  I was supposed to put in 1 1/2c sugar but I accidentally used 2c.  I don't use regular sugar, instead I used turbinado sugar aka raw cane sugar. I used this sugar for the dusting of the pans and it provided a slight crunch to each bite.  Taking the bread out when there is just a little dough on the knife after baking allows for a more moist bread. I am a novice baker but I think this bread turned out well.  Other than the sugar change and using 5 bananas instead of 3.....I love the banana flavor, it turned out well.  I baked it at 325 for 55 minutes.  Happy baking.

text:
Very tasty and freezes well. The cinnamon and sugar dusting makes these really flavourful and the sour cream add a good amount of moisture. Have made these into full loaves, mini loaves, muffins, and mini muffins. All were good. Make sure you  use FULL FAT sour cream or you won't be getting the best part of what this recipe offers. I give this 4 stars because while it is a great recipe, it isn't the best I've had. This does freeze the best of any other I have tried, though.

text:
So when I saw this recipe I was blown away with the sour cream idea... I tinker in the kitchen, but not much more...BBQ is where it is at for me!  I cut this recipe in half and put the mixture a larger bread pan.  With the leftover batter I made cupcakes to have my 6 year old take to neighbors just to tempt them about what we were doing.  Both turned out perfectly.  One thing I did different is brush butter on top of loaf with about 10 minutes to go.. I got a great crust and then when it came out, we brushed some and put the cinnamon/sugar mixture lightly on top... Huge hit!  My wife said she only wanted a slice but finished a couple and was snooping around the kitchen to see what was left.... Thanks for the recipe..

text:
This banana bread is pretty good.  I halved the recipe and used three 7.5 inch x 4 inch loaf pans.  Some previous reviewers claimed that they had trouble getting the bread to cook all the way through.  It seems like this batter yields more than stated in the recipe. I used whole milk plain yogurt instead of sour cream because I had it on hand.  Next time I will try with sour cream to see if it makes the recipe better.

text:
Well, I hate to go against the grain, so to speak, but I have a MUCH better banana nut bread recipe that I'm going to submit to allrecipes.  I had the same problem as others with this one not getting done in the middle. I cooked at 325 for 1 hour, 35 mins, and the middle still wasn't done.  I shielded the bread with tin foil after about 45 mins in the oven to keep the top from burning.  I was just disappointed about the inconsistency of the loaf after so long in the oven, however, the part that did get done tasted fine.  Not "knock your socks off" or anything, but ok.  I did enjoy the cinnamon sugar coating that was on the bottom and sides of each piece.  :)  Ok to try, but I think I'll stick with my tried and true. Thanks though!

Display Name:
CCLUCKYME

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best recipe for banana bread ever.  It is very moist, not overly sweet and extremely easy to make.  This recipe makes four loaves that freeze beautifully. Some in my family cannot eat nuts so I make a crumb topping similar to what other users recommend except I use coconut instead of nuts.  For four loaves I use 1 c. packed brown sugar ~ 1 c. flour ~ 6 T. softened butter ~ 2 t. cinnamon ~ 2/3 c. shredded coconut.  Mix these ingredients together with a fork until crumbly and spoon evenly over loaves before baking.  My family goes "bananas" over this bread!

I made my first banana bread a couple weeks ago, my husband wouldn't eat it.  This recipe was gone(I had one slice) is a day and a half.  I was worried about a couple reviews that said it didn't rise, so I added some baking powder as well, had no problems.  I used a 9x5 loaf pan, halfing the recipe, which was perfect for the size of the pan.  My second loaf is in the oven now, making my kitchen smell wonderful...thanks for the great recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such good bread! i cut the recipe in half. I used only 1 cup of sugar instead of 1 1/2, 1 egg and 1 egg white, fat free sour cream, coconut instead of vanilla extract, and whole wheat flour. It ended up being healthy , filling and amazing tasting. My sister said she liked it better with the coconut than regular banana bread. I will definatly make this again and maybe add some crushed pineapple so its like a hawaiain bread. mmmmm! 

Update: When i made this a the second time, i made the whole batch. For that i used 1/2 cup of applesauce and 1/4 cup of olive oil in place of the butter, 1  cup of sugar, fat free sour cream, and whole wheat flour. I also used 1 egg and 3 egg whites. 3 cups of sugar would be WAYYYY too sweet. I think the key to adding the sweetness without the sugar is extremely ripe bananas.

userID:
902039
Display Name:
MissChievous
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This banana bread is the bomb! I have tried out 2 other mediocre recipes from this site (despite great reviews), but this one is def the best.

I made some changes: I baked the entire batter in one large bundt pan, adjusted the baking time to 165 Celsius and baked for 1 hour, then on 150 Celsius for another 30 minutes. It definitely needed the extra time to be thoroughly done.

I also reduced the sugar, about 200 grams less in metric form, and it was definitely sweet enough with the very ripe bananas. So I would suggest using much less sugar at first, and adding more if you find it not sweet enough. I think it would be too sweet for my taste with the called for amount. I also added extra spices like nutmeg, clove, and cardamom.

This cake really tastes like bananas! It's very flavourful, moist, but still fluffy. I left out the walnuts and am glad I did, the banana flavour is enough for me. I used completely brown, mushy bananas which were ready to be thrown away, which were perfect for this! Great recipe, thanks for sharing. :)

Don't use the sugar/cinnamon coating on the bread.  It's too sweet!  Besides that, this bread is really good.  Extra vanilla and cinnamon.  Lots of walnuts.  Used only whole wheat flour and brown sugar.  EXCELLENT!!!!  Husband devoured a loaf all by himself in less than an hour.  Family and friends love it.

UPDATE: 2014--Delicious!!!  Used Greek yogurt and applesauce instead of the sour cream.  Moist and tasty!!!!

text:
I love this recipe!  My husband and I like denser banana bread so I followed the suggestion from previous reviewer to fold dry ingredients in.  Kind of had to anyway because this is a SERIOUS amount of batter and wouldn't have fit combined in my kitchenaid mixer bowl.

I decided to use Chinese Five Spice (anise, star anise, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg) instead of cinnamon/nutmeg in recipes and previous suggestions and love the little spicy bite it gives.

The idea of the sugar/cinnamon "dusting" was wonderful.  I think I used too much but don't care because as it cooled it formed a crunchy crust!  Mmmmm...

Thank you so much for this wonderful recipe!

text:
Excellent banana bread!  I made it with whole wheat flour, added flax meal and reduced the sugar by 1/2 cup to make the bread healthier.  I also add rasins to one loaf because I love rasins in banana bread.  I poured the bread into two regular sized loaf pans and the loaves cooked up nicely and came out moist.  I'm so glad I tried this recipe because the last two times I made banana bread with a different recipe the top came out too brown and the inside didn't cook enough.  I was beginning to think I couldn't make banana bread!

None
text:
Although I was disappointed because I accidentally put in no fat plain yogurt instead of the reduced fat sour cream I was planning to use, this bread/cake still definitely rated a 5.  Sixty minutes in the oven wasn't enough, so I left it in for an additional ten or so, and it still seemed a bit "damper" on top than I would have liked, although by the end of the seventy minutes the toothpick came out clear. The bread also didn't rise as much as I would have liked, but that too might be related to the age of my baking soda, plus the fact that I was so anxious about overcooking the bread and kept checking the oven (I know, a no-no).  I definitely want to make this bread the way it was intended to be made, with sour cream, and I may even use full-fat sour cream next time!  This bread  has tremendous potential with more practice on my part, particularly if I incorporate the ideas of other reviewers here in terms of toppings, substitutes, etc.  Will definitely make this again!

I'm not usually a banana bread fan but I had a few ripe bananas I'd frozen for just such an occasion. I had a slight issue as the bread overflowed my small loaf pans, so I'd advise against filling anywhere approaching 3/4 full. I made three muffins in large muffin tins using leftover batter and they turned out beautifully. Other than my ugly loaves, the recipe was a winner. As an aside, the overflow that baked onto the baking sheet I used tasted amazing. It had gone crisp and I called the bits banana bread cookies. ;)

I made 3 standard size loaves from one batch of batter. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This is wonderfully moist, and stays moist.  I did make a few changes, though.  My bananas were very ripe, so I went with the amount of sugar in my "old standby" recipe--I started with 1 3/4 cups sugar.  3 cups would have been way too much!  Then I added 1/4 tsp. ground cloves and a couple dashes of nutmeg.  I also added about 1/2 tsp. baking powder.  I never would have thought of putting sour cream in my banana bread, but this just might become my new favorite!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!  My family loves this recipe.  It's more like a cake, which they were all about.  It was very simple, and tastes like a gourmet bakery treat.  

Sprinkling cinnamon sugar both in the bottom of the pan and over the batter makes a perfect treat, as the sugar on top gets a bit of a crust to it, which traps moisture in the cake.  Yummy!

I did make this gluten-free to accommodate family allergies(adding 2 tsp of baking powder to help it rise better).  I also thought I'd be clever and add a 2 tsp of rum extract, but it wasn't discernable in the end. I'll be making this often. Thanks for sharing!!

I will definitely use this recipe again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! I made this for some friends who came over after dinner, and everyone raved. 
I skipped dusting the pans and just greased them instead because my husband doesn't like much cinnamon. I only used a dash of cinnamon in the batter itself too--still incredibly flavorful and full of banana goodness. I'm sure it's great with the cinnamon too, but it was excellent without as well. I cut back on the sugar as well, only using one part brown sugar and one white. 
When I halved the recipe, I used one whole egg and one egg white--came out perfect. 
This is my new favorite!!! Thanks for sharing!

text:
This was REALLY good!  I made this in 6 mini loaf pans, and had just a bit of left over batter.  As others suggested, I reduced the sugar by 1/2 cup.  I used 4 large very ripe bananas (that's all I had).  I also replaced 1-1/2 cups of the flour with 1/2 cup of soy flour and 1 cup whole wheat flour.  I sprinkled some cinnamon sugar on top of each loaf for a nice topping.  Give the recipe a try, you won't regret it

I don't know if it is the best ever, but it is tasty. I omitted the nuts, used 1c of brown sugar and 1 1/2c white, 1c low-fat sour cream 1/2c yogurt and 1/4c black coffee (approximates) and moist...oh boy it took FOREVER to bake, at least another 20 minutes if not longer. It really puffed up (don't bake too close together)and then flattened a bit, so no nice dome on top, but really yummy still, more like a cake.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/239672.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best banana bread recipe. Extremely moist. I modified it to add raisins. 

Here's what I did: Put 1/2 to 3/4 cup of raisins in a small sauce pan with 1/4 cup of water and boil it until almost all of the water cooks off of the fruit. Turn off the heat and pour Amaretto (you can probably also use brandy) into the pan and light it with a long match to flambe it. Light it and swirl the pan a little to make sure all of the alcohol has burned off. Drain it and add it to the batter. 

It needs more baking time than what the recipe calls for - or maybe my oven needs to be recalibrated.

text:
WOW...i butchered this recipe - and it still turned out EXCELLENT!  i only had about 3/4 of a 16 ounce container of sour cream so i topped off the container with some vegetable oil and skim milk.  i only had 3 bananas so i doubled the vanilla. i forgot to coat one of the pans with the sugar cinnamon mixture so i spread it on the top of the batter.  i mistakenly set the temperature too high in the first 10 minutes but turned it down.  i also don't remember how long i baked it.  guess what?!  it really didn't matter - all of these things worked!  my altered recipe yielded 1 large bundt and about half a large loaf.  the taste and texture is really very good - the little cinnamon crust is a something i'll use over and over again in other recipes too.  of course i will try to make the recipe as printed the next time and will post another review but thank you so much for sharing this winner!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a delicious recipe!  The previous ones I have tried (not from this site) have all been typically dense and dry.  This recipe is SO moist and perfect in density.  I halved the recipe to make two regular sized loaves (I also only had three bananas) and baked at regular temp for regular time.  Turned out perfect.  The only thing was I couldn't get the cinnamon-sugar to stick to the pans so I lightly greased and then sprinkled the cinnamon-sugar.  I think that was a problem later though as my loaves ended up too moist and sticky on the outside.  We also sprinkled extra cinnamon sugar on the top of the loaves before baking.  Yum!  Next time will probably NOT grease the pans, skip the cinnamon-sugar on the pan and just sprinkle on top and see if that helps the outside be a little drier.  Thanks for a fabulous recipe!

None
text:
I like this better than the popular Banana Banana Bread on this site.  I made a 4x8 loaf and baked a little over an hour about 8-10 minutes minutes more (ovens vary).  A sure way to make sure your bread is done is to stick a toothpick in the middle and if comes out clean its done.  I will make again adding chocolate chips and reducing back a little bit of the sugar because this bread is a little on the sweet side.

None
text:
I added 1 tsp of allspice to add more flavor. I also substituted whole wheat flour for the half of the flour and added 3/4 cup of water because whole wheat flour makes the batter so thick. The cinnamon/sugar pan coating sounds good in theory, but in reality the sugar carmelizes and makes the bread stick to the pan. I made one 9x5 loaf and 12 large muffins. My boyfriend said "they're good" and ate 2.

text:
Not bad, not much better than my usual recipe. Made these changes, I used 1 cup of butter, 2.5 cups sugar, and 3.5 cups of flour. Less flour gives it a more delicate crumb, i think. Dont use less than 2.5 cups of sugar, it is necessary to balance the tang of the sour cream.

text:
This was a wonderfully moist bread!  My husband couldn't wait to eat it, and it disappeared quickly!  I added some lemon juice to keep the bananas from turning brown, and to reduce some of the sweetness from the bananas.  I reduced the sugar, as another person put in their review and took the remaining sugar and cinnamon mixture and sprinkled it on top.  All in all a great recipe!  Thanks for sharing!
